TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Assessment and Collection) Bill 1997 and amendment 51 of sheet 466 and amendments 1 and 2 of sheet 472 moved by Senator Sherry.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I confirm it is sheet 466? There has been no update of the running sheet?
—You are correct.
—Could I check with Senator Kemp whether there are any further amendments? We were expecting a further amendment to be drafted—not necessarily on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been discussions between a number of officers in relation to one matter which I think you raised in relation to shares and ETPs. Those discussions I think were fairly intense on the last working day. When in fact those matters have been resolved, my understanding is that you will move that amendment and that then will be a matter for debate. I think that is the amendment that you are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding is, apart from a number of amendments which you now have on the table and apart from the amendment that Senator Allison has on the table, that Senator Harradine has an amendment, and then there is that possibility which I suggest we should deal with at the last stage of this debate. That is it as far as I am aware.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is fine. I sought to clarify that because I anticipate and hope we can move pretty rapidly to a conclusion. I was worried about the pace we move at in the context of that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the amendments before us, we have made a contribution on whether the surcharge is a tax. The issue has been extensively canvassed over the last seven months, as I am sure at least Senator Kemp will agree. We do not have any further contribution to make; we concluded our remarks on Wednesday evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was on my way into the chamber when the amendments were being mentioned. In fact, I have an amendment to the consequential amendments bill. I do not think that was mentioned amongst the amendments we still need to deal with.
—I would like to mention, whilst not going over what has been said previously, that I will be supporting the amendments put forward by Senator Sherry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be opposing these amendments. We simply do not accept the proposition that has been put that the superannuation surcharge on high income earners is better described as a tax. That is the contention of the non‐government parties; it is not the view of the government. The surcharge is defined as an additional charge, and that is the nature of the superannuation surcharge. On the other hand, a tax can be defined as a compulsory unrequited payment demanded by government for its support. There is a distinction between the two, and Senator Sherry's amendment seeks to obfuscate that distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of different measures imposed by all governments for the collection of revenue, and some come within the definition of a tax. They are taxes, and they are called taxes. But the superannuation surcharge is clearly not of this nature. It is properly described as a surcharge, and no amount of rhetorical posturings in our view will change that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not let it pass without saying that it is disingenuous of the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) to suggest that this is not compulsory. I think it is quite clear that it is.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Faulkner did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, amendment Nos 7 and 47 are still outstanding. I seek leave of the Senate to withdraw those. They have been superseded by Democrat amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Amendments withdrawn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are certainly ready to go back to the Democrat amendment that was circulated in respect to low and middle in come earners. Should we go back to that now?
—Yes.
—On this issue—and I will make some further comments shortly—I do not want to get into a lengthy exchange with Senator Allison. Some others may, but—
—Senator Sherry, these amendments are yet to be moved. Perhaps it might be appropriate for Senator Allison to have the call and to move them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 19, page 23 (after line 8), after subclause (1), insert:
(1A) This section also applies if:

PARA.TAB: (a) under an assessment of surcharge on a member's surchargeable contributions for a financial year, the rate of surcharge that applies to the member on particular surchargeable contributions for the financial year was assessed to be nil because paragraph 5(3)(e) of the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge Imposition Act 1997 applied to the member; and
(b) the rate of surcharge that applies to the member on these contributions for that financial year is afterwards determined to be greater than nil; and
(c) the person to whom the nil assessment was directed is still the holder of the contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 19, page 23 (line 11), at the end of subclause (2), add "or paragraph (1)(c)".
(3) Clause 20, page 24 (after line 13), after subclause (1), insert:
(1A) This section also applies if:

PARA.TAB: (a) under an assessment of surcharge (the previous assessment) on a member's surchargeable contributions for a financial year, the rate of surcharge that applies to the member on particular surchargeable contributions for that financial year was assessed to be nil because paragraph 5(3)(e) of the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge Imposition Act 1997 applied to the member; and
(b) the rate of surcharge that applies to the member on those contributions for that financial year is afterwards determined to be greater than nil; and
(c) the person to whom the previous assessment was directed is no longer the holder of the surchargeable contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: In moving these amendments, the Democrats want to again say that this is about ensuring that low income earners do not end up paying the surcharge. In so doing, we also want to make sure that high income earners do not avoid the tax. This amendment seeks to provide a fair balance between these two objectives. It provides the $2,000 contributions exemption for all superannuation accounts out there as at 7 May 1997, but it then rules a line and says that from now on if employees fail to provide tax file numbers to their funds they could be liable for the surcharge.

The Democrats acutely understand the problems of the funds in relying on members to voluntarily provide their tax file numbers. In evidence to the superannuation committee, the funds advised that response rates from workers to their funds' requests for information very rarely exceed 30 to 40 per cent. Applying this response rate to the super surcharge, 60 to 70 per cent of workers could or would end up paying the super surcharge simply because—I should say tax at this stage, I suppose—they fail to return a form. This would create a massive tax windfall for the government running into billions of dollars. Billions of dollars would be taken out of the retirement savings of low income workers, Mr Howard's battlers, under the compulsion of this legislation.

The 7 May cut‐off is, we think, very important. Superannuation funds only received the statutory authority to ask for tax file numbers in February this year and they are now obliged to ask members for them. Up until now, members have not systematically been asked to provide their tax file numbers. We do not believe that the four million workers on below average earners who having set up a superannuation fund without being asked to provide a tax file number should, at this late stage, have the rules changed.

Like the ALP amendment that has been withdrawn, our amendment setting a threshold at average weekly earnings of $33,000 per on annum does leave the possibility that many workers who have not provided their tax file number could end up paying the surcharge. That is why, unlike the ALP's amendments, we have asked for several requirements of the tax office. The tax office will be required to take all reasonable steps to try to find the member's tax file number. Senator Kemp has already outlined the data matching capability of the tax office and the advertising campaigns planned by that office. We think that this and more will be required.

The tax office will be required to write to the member formally warning them and then and only then, having been warned in writing by their super funds on their tax assessment and directly by the tax commissioner, will the surcharge apply. For those people who open a super account after 7 May, the $2,000 threshold does not apply. There will be no advantage to high income earners splitting their super accounts but, before the commissioner can apply the surcharge to a person with low superannuation amounts, the tax office will have to write to them a second time—this time at both their residential and business address—to warn them. That will be five warnings altogether and we think that that is fair.

This amendment is not perfect and I wish to reiterate that all of these problems could have been avoided if the government had agreed to the majority recommendation of the Senate superannuation committee and implemented the tax through the PAYE tax system. They failed to do so and we are, in effect, reduced to bandaiding the very worst aspects of the cumbersome collection mechanism.

I reiterate that, with this amendment, we protect the workers already in the super system, we provide a range of extra protection in the form of additional warnings and we oblige the tax office in respect of workers yet to come into the system. We also ensure that tax planners miss out on the opportunity to avoid the surcharge for high income earners by rearranging their affairs to fit into an exemption intended for low income earners. I think this is a fair amendment and I commend it to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask for leave to ask a question as a consequence of the passing of the last amendment?

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister: will the change in name from a charge to a tax have any consequential flow‐on effect in terms of tax credits now available by virtue of calling it a tax rather than a charge?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an important question. Once bills are played around with, of course, we have to examine the full implications. The preliminary advice I have received from officials is that the short answer is no. Income tax credits will not be available, because the surcharge is not imposed under the Income Tax Assessment Act.
—We now return to Senator Allison's amendments. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Senator Allison referred in her comments to the fact that we had withdrawn our amendments in respect of low and middle income earners. We have not. Our withdrawal went to amendments Nos 7 and 47, not Nos 6 and 8. We still intend to pursue our amendments Nos 6 and 8, and they will obviously come to a vote in due course. I have already indicated that the proposed solution that the Greens had put forward by way of their amendment was better designed to take care of this problem with lower and middle income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: The next point I wish to make is relatively minor, but I think it is important in the context of this debate. I understand that the amendment of the Democrats has the support of the government and in fact has been drafted largely with the assistance of the government's advisers. The date of 7 May is important because, as I understand it, the date on which funds can start asking for tax file numbers for the purpose of this legislation is the date on which the legislation becomes law, whenever that will be—a week or two; I do not know. So we would have thought that if you were going to adopt this approach—I do not agree with this approach, and I will come to that shortly—logically you would choose a date at some time in the future, in the next two weeks. I am sure that Senator Kemp would have had some idea on what date this would have been presented to the Governor for signing. I think it has to be formally gazetted—whatever that date may be. It is a minor point, but I think it is important in the way in which this date of 7 May was designated.

The proposed solution of the Democrats is not satisfactory to the Australian Labor Party. I would like to remind Senator Allison that last week she indicated publicly that the Australian Democrats would be supporting our proposed amendments. I have a copy of the press release from Senator Allison dated 6 May which says:
The Democrats will support the two sets of amendments announced by the ALP today and call on the government to accept these amendments.

The new Democrat position is a substantial retreat from that position that was enunciated by Labor and the Greens and clearly by Senator Harradine on this particular legislation. We find that very disappointing. We find the proposed `compromise' of the Democrats very messy. It has a significant number of flaws in itself, putting aside the problem that is going to be confronted by people earning between $35,000 and $70,000 a year, and I will get to that shortly as well.
The other point I would like to make about the latest Democrat position is that I do take exception to one particular clause in Senator Allison's media release of 8 May in which she says:

Senate debate on surcharge legislation will continue on Monday with Senator Allison expressing disappointment that the bill had not been dealt with by now, blaming the ALP of filibustering and time wasting for the delay.

As I recall it, we received a final copy of the amendment we are currently considering—which is a very important amendment—about an hour before we were to adjourn on Wednesday. It simply was not possible to complete this legislation on Wednesday night. If we had not co-operated and gone on to other provisions in the bill, we would not have been able to deal with the amendment that the Democrats and Mr Costello's office were attempting to cobble together. I make that point. I think your accusation about alleged time wasting on our behalf is incorrect. It simply would have been impossible to have concluded the debate on this package of legislation given that we had only one hour to go on your amendment.

Your amendment did require careful examination. Frankly, when we are dealing with the taxation of potentially millions of people who should not be caught in the tax net, I do think we need a little more than one hour in order to study the detail of your proposed deal with the government, particularly when my advisers and I and everyone involved in consideration of legislation is in the chamber, including the Democrats and Senator Harradine and Green senators. I think it was extremely unreasonable to have expected us to have that amendment—going to a very important area—plonked in front of us an hour before the conclusion of debate on a Wednesday and to have concluded debate on it and everything else in that remaining hour. I think it was very unreasonable, Senator Allison, and I reject your assertion of a filibuster. We do not want to delay the time of the chamber any more than necessary, and that will be further evidenced in the approach we take to the RSA package of legislation later where we will be, by our actions, saving a considerable amount of the chamber's time.

I turn to the substance of the deal between the Democrats and Mr Costello. Let me deal with the issue of the warnings from the tax office. If you are going to give these warnings to what are defined as lower and middle income earners, why does the Democrat‐government amendment not provide the same level of warning to people earning between $35,000 and $70,000 a year? Even if we are not attempting to exclude—and we are not—people earning less than AWEs from the collection of the superannuation tax, why should we not give the same level of warning—that is, four letters from the tax office—to those people earning between $35,000 and $70,000 a year?

BREAK.PARA: It would seem to me that that is a critical flaw in your approach. If we are not going to exempt them from the collection of the tax, we can at least provide the same level of warning vis-a-vis the tax office to that group of people as we are giving to that group of people earning less than $35,000 a year. I see that as a critical defect in the logic of your approach on the warnings from the tax office itself. There are two million taxpayers earning between $35,000 and $70,000 a year. Why should they not be given the same level of warning from the tax office as people earning less than $35,000 whom we are trying to exempt from the collection of this tax? I make that point first of all.

Secondly, the problem with the Democrat‐government approach is that it will still bring some people who earn less than $35,000 a year into the surcharge tax net. You have a cut-off date of 7 May. What you are effectively saying is that superannuation accounts prior to 7 May can be excluded and that low and middle income earners with no tax file numbers can be excluded and can go through the warning process.

However, there will be a significant number of lower and middle income earners who will have new superannuation accounts from 7 May, which is your cut-off date. We do not know what the total number will be, but I point out to the chamber that in 1995-96, the last year for which we could obtain figures, there were one million new superannuation accounts in this country. If you think about that issue and the fact that we are going on to RSAs—which the government wants to encourage—we are going to have a considerable number of new superannuation accounts opened up after 7 May. I do not necessarily think that is a good thing, but that is the reality we face.

There will certainly be a significant proportion of people who earn less than $35,000 on the basis of encouragement from the government in respect to the retirement savings accounts vehicles, which we will consider next. There will be a considerable number of people who will earn less than $35,000, even with the warnings from the tax office and the warning from their own funds, who will be caught. We do not know what the total number will be. But, given that there have been one million new superannuation accounts in the last year for which we can obtain accurate figures and given that we will have RSAs because of a further deal between the Democrats and the government, there will have to be some people caught who earn less than $35,000. This does not deal with the issue of people who earn between $35,000 and $70,000—some two million of them.

This package that has been cobbled together by the Treasurer, the government and the Democrats really highlights the general chaos that is going to ensue as a result of the passing of this package of legislation. It appears certain that it is going to be passed. It highlights the problem of a collection mechanism and the indirect collection of this tax using tax file numbers that superannuation funds do not have.

We have dealt with this earlier in the debate. On top of the letters that the funds will have to send out—most funds which I have consulted with and have listened to say that they will have to send out two or three letters—there will also be up to four letters from the tax office. The approximately eight million taxpayers in this country and the 16 million superannuation account holders are going to be bombarded with material over the next year—absolutely bombarded. They are going to get at least four to seven or eight letters. If nothing is going to highlight the shambles of this legislation, that issue certainly is.

We believe this is grossly inefficient. Consider the costs involved in the sheer volume of correspondence that will have to be sent out by both the tax office and superannuation funds. We are given figures of between $20 and $100 million by the funds. There will be extra costs involved by the tax office. I certainly hope that it will not be taken off some other area of the tax office's budgetary allocation. That is a question we would like Senator Kemp to inform us on. What are the extra costs involved for the tax office?

This serves to highlight the gross inefficiency of collecting a tax in this way and why our threshold amendment on the second reading debate to refer this legislation back to the government for a rewrite should have been passed. We are dealing in a piecemeal fashion, bit by bit, with some success from the Labor point of view and the other senators in the chamber who have supported our particular amendments at times.

This legislation is still a shambles. The Democrat-government deal on this particular provision highlights the shambles that is going to occur once this legislation is put into law. Labor will not support the Democrat-government compromise for the reasons I have outlined. Firstly, it is evidence of the further shambles. Secondly, there will be extraordinary extra costs involved. Fund members in this country will be bombarded with letters.

The other undesirable side effect of all this is the enormous uncertainty that has been created out in the broader community about superannuation, but not amongst higher income earners, although there certainly is significant uncertainty amongst them. Because of the collection mechanism and the volume of correspondence, everyone in this country is wondering, `What on earth is going on with my superannuation as a consequence of this legislation? Why am I getting letters from the tax office saying, "Provide the tax file number voluntarily" or I'll get hit with a new tax? I'm not supposed to pay this tax because I earn less than $70,000.' There is uncertainty about people's superannuation. I saw a survey last week. Uncertainty levels are increasing rapidly—in significant part because of this debate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting the amendment that has been proposed by the Democrats. We, of course, felt that given the design of this bill and the collection approach such an amendment was not needed. But it is clear that the Democrats in particular—this reflects some other views around the chamber—felt that additional assurances needed to be given that the surcharge would not be imposed on low and middle income earners. We entered into discussions with the Democrats to see whether it was possible to have an amendment which provided that assurance but did not open up a massive area of tax avoidance. I think that the amendment as it stands addresses that particular issue.
—Do you mean the surcharge or tax avoidance?

—If I cast my mind back, Senator Sherry was very worried about what efforts the tax office would make to inform people about the surcharge. He was keen to see what could be done to upgrade those particular efforts. Senator Allison has put forward an amendment which no‐one could argue does not upgrade those approaches, and now Senator Sherry thinks it is all too much. Talk about the old flip‐flop! Could we have some consistency from you over two working days, Senator Sherry? Last time you were worried that we were not doing enough to inform people; today you are worried we are doing too much to inform people. Talk about a flip‐flop!

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry is also worried about people's confidence in superannuation being undermined. Physician heal thyself. I do not think confidence is being undermined in superannuation. But, to the extent it is, Senator Sherry, I think that you would be the key suspect because of the way you have behaved in trying to sow enormous seeds of uncertainty over this particular issue. I do not believe that it is the case but, if it were the case, on those grounds you would be the first person charged, I would think, with attempting to do that.

The next point I would make is on the old furphy which is rolled out relentlessly: that there is a better way to do it. We looked at the other options, including those which Senator Sherry `seemed' to be supporting, but would never quite put his moniker to, it has to be said. Senator Sherry's options would have involved very substantial costs on one million employers, additional work for 10 million or so taxpayers, and the superannuation funds would still be involved in a very similar way. Whatever glib arguments you trot forward, Senator Sherry, neither you nor the Labor Party were ever able to come up with any feasible alternative; not surprisingly, because all options were carefully considered by us. This is the option which we feel meets the appropriate criteria. It is certainly vastly more efficient than the mechanism which you put forward.

Senator, I do not know how we can ever answer you. Last week you felt there were too few warnings; this week you feel that there are too many. I do not know what the balance is. When you really do not know what you believe in it is very hard to fix a position. I am not one noted in this parliament for being constantly on his feet praising the Democrats, but I will say this for the Democrats: they believe that the 15 per cent surcharge is a principle worth supporting. They believe that we need to address the issues of equity in superannuation. The Democrats at least came to this debate uncluttered. You, on the other hand, Senator Sherry, never believed in the 15 per cent surcharge. You ducked and weaved and made every attempt you could to undermine this particular measure. It is the dilemma of the modern Labor Party.

As I said, we will be supporting this amendment, although it was not one which we felt was necessary. We felt we had taken all reasonable steps to cover the particular concerns which had been raised. Nonetheless, we recognise the numbers in this chamber. We worked with the Democrats to see whether we could work out an amendment which addressed the central issue and at the same time did not open up a major area of tax avoidance. We believe this has been done. The date of 7 May was chosen because that is the date on which this material became public. We certainly did not want to leave a gap where some high income earners could, if they wished, split their contributions into new accounts so that each new account had contributions of less than $2,000. In other words, I think it was a reasonable measure in order to stop the splitting of contributions into accounts so the surcharge would not be imposed.

We have had press releases from Senator Sherry over this and we have had Senator Sherry on the radio over this. Senator Sherry has been here, there and everywhere talking about the low and middle income earners. Despite all your rhetoric, Senator Sherry, despite all your worries about low and middle income earners, what happened when the Democrats proposed an amendment to protect them? You went missing in action again. It is a poor effort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that low income earners will actually be protected by the Democrat amendment on sheet 513. It seems that there is very limited grandfathering, but the wording seems unclear. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: if contributed amounts in respect of contributions began to be paid for or by the member . . .
We have not put this legislation through yet so we are talking about some window of opportunity of grandfathering. Paragraph (f) of the amendment states:
if contributed amounts in respect of contributions began to be paid for or by the member to a superannuation provider on or after 7 May . . .

They are still having to pay it if they have not put in their tax file number. I am not sure what the battler is actually gaining. I would like to think there was something substantial being gained by the battler whom this imposition is being put on, but I am not entirely sure that much has been gained at all as a result of this amendment on sheet 513. I am happy to be disabused of my doubts, but I think the endeavour to put a date in makes this nonsensical and virtually cuts out most people from benefiting from it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to a couple of comments by Senator Kemp, as I said earlier we will not be supporting the Democrat and the government compromise. Senator Kemp, why were there not provisions in the legislation dealing with this particular problem in the first place? You continued to deny until last week that there was even a problem. You kept asserting that there was no problem.
—That is what I said today. I said we have addressed that. You did not listen to what I said.

—Senator Kemp, I accept you had consulted. The problem is you did not listen to the people who were in volved in having to collect the surcharge, now a tax. If you had listened to those people, all the experts—it is not me, Senator Kemp; I have been very humble about my part in this issue since—
—You are quite right to be humble.

—I am very humble about my role in the debate on this budget announcement from August last year because, frankly, I did not have to try hard. I have got my list of quotable quotes from super experts—I am not going to go through it. Some 23 experts up until November last year—and there are a lot more to add—comprehensively bagged the government, most of them dealing with this very issue we are considering today. I did not have to go out and find people who were concerned about this; they found me.

SPEECH.PARA: We will not be supporting the Democrat amendment, because we do not believe it is comprehensive enough. We believe it has a number of flaws. I will raise an issue. Senator Kemp, I was not complaining about the new tax office provision; I was highlighting the cost of it and the limitations and the flaws in that approach.

Let us assume that the tax office has to send out two letters to everyone. That will mean a minimum of 20 million items of correspondence—I think that is a good average—going out from the tax office alone at a cost of 45c each. There will be more correspondence because there are many more superannuation accounts. That will cost $10 million, not counting all the extra administrative costs incurred by the tax office in sending all this correspondence out.

I would like Senator Kemp to give us some ballpark figure of the extra costs involved in this level of correspondence. You must have worked out some sort of costing of this amendment. We do not have a problem with greater correspondence with members; in fact we think it is going to be very useful because it highlights the incompetence of the government on this package of legislation. We would like to know your preliminary costing for this extra mail‐out from the tax office and where the money is going to come from. This does highlight the extra costs that funds will have to incur, because funds are going to have to follow a similar process as well. So you have not answered that question Senator Kemp.

I would like Senator Allison or Senator Kemp to tell us how the tax will affect people who open a new account after 7 May and who have accounts already opened prior to 7 May—many people will have accounts prior to 7 May. How will the tax treat the pre-7 May accounts if they have not provided their tax file number on their post-7 May account? I think there are going to be some significant complexities arising from the cut-off date. I would appreciate some advice on that issue.

I will conclude my comments because we do not want to prolong this debate unnecessarily; it has had a considerable airing. I want to touch on the final issue of tax evasion that Senator Kemp has mentioned and the reason why the cut-off date of 7 May is in this amendment. We are looking at relatively small amounts in tax that will be collected from low and middle income earners, depending on their superannuation contributions.

Let us say their contribution is $2,000 a year, which will be the maximum because that is the maximum cut‐off, then 15 per cent of that is $300. I do not know how the Democrats have been conned by Mr Costello on this. Is anyone seriously suggesting that low and middle income earners in particular are going to set up new superannuation accounts to artificially avoid $300 maximum in tax? They will not do it.

I understand the norm is an average of $1,000 to get advice and to set up your own superannuation account. It is quite possible to do it—I accept that. But does anyone seriously believe that lower and middle income earners are going to dash out and avoid the new 15 per cent tax, given the level of tax that will be incorrectly collected?

I think this tax evasion issue is a furphy. Every time Mr Costello gets in trouble and every time he tries to justify some particular significant change, it's a cry of `Tax evasion! Tax evasion! We've got to crack down on the tax rorters.' And in this case the alleged tax rorters are going to be low and middle income earners—even those people earning between $35,000 and $70,000 a year receiving superannuation guarantee contributions. We just do not accept that it is going to become a fundamental problem with the amendments that we have put before the chamber.

We have received advice from accountants and tax lawyers in this area since the amendment was provided to us last week, and we do not believe it is possible for it become a significant problem. So we do not accept this spurious argument mounted by Senator Kemp on behalf of Mr Costello that our amendments, if passed, would lead to any level of serious tax evasion. I would suggest that Mr Costello's approach on this, the last refuge of a scoundrel, is the cry `tax evasion!'

There are two issues that I would like the government or Democrats to address. The first is the cost of the mail‐outs and, if possible, the extra administrative costs the tax office will be involved in. We would like at least a ballpark figure about that. Secondly, we would like some explanation about accounts that are open prior to 7 May this year and a person having accounts prior to 7 May opening a new account after 7 May and how their total superannuation contributions will be treated in that context.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of preliminary comments. I thought Senator Sherry just went completely over the top in some of those comments on tax avoidance. He suggests that people throw up their hands every time a hard issue comes up and call `tax avoidance!' but I think it is great pity that the former government did not take a more serious approach to these issues. Of course, it left a tax system in need of repair—and that is something this government has done and will do. Tax avoidance is not the last refuge of the scoundrel—a very unfortunate and uncalled for comment by you, I thought. It is one that again reflects the dilemma of the modern Labor Party that it does not take these issues seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: We checked with the tax office and our experts, and the reality is that they saw a major problem. As a result, we have carefully worked with the Democrats to hopefully ensure that an amendment is crafted which tackles this issue. I do not have any forecasts for you of the additional costs involved as a result of this amendment, but I did take from the debate last week that there was a general desire that more not less contact should be had with people who hold superannuation accounts.

In your first remarks you said, `What are people going to think, that they are going to be buried?' And in your next contribution you said you welcomed the additional contact from the tax office. Frankly, Senator, you are all over the place on this issue.

For contributions less than $2,000, if a person was a member of the fund before 7 May, then no TFN is required. If a person joined a fund on or after 7 May, a TFN is required and the fund can advise the member on joining of the consequences of not providing a tax file number. Of course, we have indicated the sorts of contacts which will be had from the tax office and, for particular groups, the letters which will be sent out.

It is an amendment which the Democrats felt very strongly about and which we worked through with them. It does address the concern that I did not think was based on fact but, nonetheless, I recognise the numbers amongst the non‐government members of the Senate and a concern that they needed greater assurancein this area. I think that is what the Democrat amendment has sought to provide and, recognising the numbers, we will be supporting that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one group of people that seem always to fall into the hole of these kinds of considerations, especially in relation to superannuation, and they tend to be the growing number of people in casualised work. We have had various discussions about the implications of their having to go into potentially different schemes each time they work and the problems later on of having to amalgamate various tiny accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: The group that gets it in the neck are the same people. They have no job security through no fault of their own and have to go to different jobs because work is not available that has any tenure whatsoever—they are lucky to get work when they can get it. More and more people in our society are in this category.

Those people will be left out in this amendment because there is no way for them not to be left out. Basically, once again they are being punished for the economic and unemployment situation in which they find themselves. They are also the people whom the tax department has hardest trouble getting hold of because, as a casualised work force, they may have to move to get work, and that might be seasonal work. Once again, these people will be punished. It will probably be harder for them to try to wheedle out any refund because they are certainly not likely to have access to accountants to help them out. I just think it is totally unfair.

Once again, if there is to be any vestige of fairness within this, you could say that total contributed amounts in respect of contributions made are $2,000. You know that our preference was average weekly earnings, which would have dealt with that. So, in order to prevent what the government thinks may be another push for tax avoidance in relation to higher income people, who could split their superannuation contributions into several different sorts, perhaps all they needed to put was the word `total', for heaven's sake! Instead of this, we are deliberately saying to at least one major and growing group in our society, `Once again you are going to get it in the neck because of the economic situation over which you have no control.' Perhaps the minister could point out why, instead of using a phrase like `total contributions', this group once again is being left out in the cold as a result of this mess.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested to hear the minister's response to Senator Margetts. But the minister also owes it to the committee to advise us of the government's estimate on the questions that have been asked by Senator Sherry. I refer to his quite reasonable request for advice as to the expected cost to revenue of this amendment—if it were passed—bearing in mind that there are quite simple ways of making the collection if the government acknowledges that it is a tax.

BREAK.PARA: We have had it from the minister that the government does acknowledge that it is a tax. The minister has said that one of the reasons he has taken this approach is to stamp down on tax avoidance. But, according to him, we are not talking about a tax—we are talking about a surcharge. Surely he should really say `surcharge avoidance'. I noticed that in the latter part of his contribution he did desist from calling it tax avoidance and just called it avoidance.

If the Democrats are going to persist with their amendment and not agree to support Senator Sherry's amendment and refinement, which clearly would protect low and middle income earners, I feel that the committee ought to be advised by the government of the cost of the government‐Democrat amendment. I would also like to know from the government at some stage what will be the overall cost to superannuation funds of this collection measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some concluding remarks. I need to indicate, firstly, that I spoke to our package of amendments earlier rather than to the three amendments which are on sheet 515. These amendments, of course, are consequential to the amendments which I foreshadowed to the imposition bill; I hope I have corrected that. Of course, these amendments allow the commissioner to amend an assessment and to impose the surcharge on a high income earner if it later emerges that they had not paid the surcharge because they fell within the $2,000 exemption. It makes it clear that high income earners cannot avoid the surcharge. It ensures that the $2,000 threshold does not bring with it a revenue cost in the collection of the surcharge on high income earners. For that reason, we have put this forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I need to make a response to Senator Sherry's remarks a little earlier about the fact that this does not catch, if you like, or address the question of those with incomes higher than $33,000 but lower than the level at which the tax applies. I remind him that his own amendments also chose this threshold of $2,000. We thought that was reasonable and that is the reason that we put this into our amendment. So I think Senator Sherry is being rather mischievous in suggesting that this is something that he would not have supported.

Thirdly, I also need to say that I would agree with Senator Sherry's remarks about lower and middle income earners not being tax dodgers. But I remind him that all those income earners need to do—and we think we have put in adequate provisions to see that they are informed about this—to avoid paying this tax is to send their tax file number to their superannuation fund. So it is a simple means by which they can avoid this surcharge and our amendments seek to put those protection measures in place. I am disappointed that the opposition is not going to vote for our amendments because we think that they are fair and they are workable. I have to say that it has transpired that the opposition's amendments are not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up Senator Sherry and Senator Harradine in making sure that Senator Kemp has a third request for a costing of what it will cost the tax office to mail out letters. Have you done a costing and, if so, what is it? I would have to say in response to Senator Allison's contributions that I am looking forward to the photo of Senator Allison and Rod hugging later, like Senator Kernot and Mr Reith did. I will add that to my collection on the wall.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of why we are not supporting your amendments, as you well know as a member of the Superannuation Committee, your amendments go no way towards protecting and addressing the unfairness of this package on people who earn less than $70,000. It may have reduced some of the overall unfairness but, as you well know, this package is an administrative joke. You are going to vote for it. Do not sit there and nod, Senator Allison. You are going to vote for it. You are going to vote to put a $12 charge on every single low income earner's superannuation account and ongoing costs of $3.50 a year. You are going to vote for that, Senator Allison. Your protection, as you describe it in these amendments, is pitiful. Senator Kemp, I repeat: have you done any costings for what the tax office will have to pay and, if so, are you prepared to give them to the committee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think your comments were as unfortunate as the earlier comments of your colleague Senator Sherry. This is a serious matter. The rhetoric should be kept under some control, and I think that your comments frankly went over the top again.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is you just have to accept that the Labor Party wanted to sink the surcharge. You wanted to sink the surcharge, and you are bitter because it looks like the surcharge will go through. You wanted to sink the surcharge because you are under huge pressure from a variety of interest groups. The Democrats can speak for themselves, but I take it that the Democrats generally accepted the principle that it was important to restore some equity in the superannuation system. So there is a difference.

I have to tell you, Senator Conroy, that you have come late to this debate, although I know you are an expert on superannuation. You were the Superannuation Officer for the Transport Workers Union for a number of years and presumably supported by the contribution of workers in that particular job, so I understand that. Senator, my initial advice from the tax office is that there is no cost to revenue forecasts, which have been put forward, as a result of these measures. Of course, if you send out more letters, there will be some more administration costs. We will need to review those. There may be a later stage when we can give you some figures, but I do not have those figures available now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I apologise for using the word `revenue'. I thought you and your advisers would not act smartly like that but give us a response to the question that I asked. You knew, or your advisers should have known, what I meant. I clearly meant and referred to the question that was raised by Senator Sherry. He was referring, as Senator Conroy said, to the cost to the Australian Taxation Office. Frankly, we do need to know the estimated cost.

BREAK.PARA: Through you, Madam Temporary Chairman, the minister has said that he has taken this matter to the Taxation Office. They had considered that there were some problems with the issue and actually did not say that this particular measure that is currently before us had come from the Taxation Office. I would have thought the officers from the Taxation Office would have been far more perceptive than that.

I do insist—in fact, I will call a quorum if you do not, and we will go on from there—that you give some respect to the committee when it is considering a measure such as this and that we do need to have an idea of what this may cost. When it comes to my amendment, I know you will reveal what the Treasurer (Mr Costello) says it will cost, so why don't you do it with this amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, with respect, I do not think you listened carefully to what I said. As I have the note here, I will read it. I said that there was no cost to revenue but, yes, there will be some administrative costs. What I said is that the ATO will need to make some estimates of those.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator, let me throw this into perspective. The debate all last week was that we needed to upgrade the efforts of the tax office in order to make contact with contributors. That was the whole thrust of the Senate's attack on this surcharge from non-government members. I read through the six to 10 steps that the tax office was taking, and there was a lot of debate whether that was sufficient and whether more needed to be done. The whole thrust of the attack today is that somehow more is being done and it is going to be costly. If you do more, it is going to cost some extra revenue. So we will have to assess just what those costs are.

I am not trying obfuscate; I am not trying to be difficult. The reality was that the Senate wanted more to be done. That is what the Senate wanted. The government felt that sufficient amounts were being done, but the Senate wanted more to be done. The Democrats believed that more needed to be done. We discussed the issue with the Democrats and have reached what we think is an amend ment which we can wear. It was the Senate that wanted more contact to be made. If you want more contact and more resources to be put in, it will cost money.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—We will look and review and see what the additional costs are. Are you opposed to the additional costs being made?
—You have agreed to the amendments. What is it costing?

—I have said that we believed that the way we had set this up properly addressed this issue, but that was not the general feeling of the Senate. We are often accused of not responding to what the Senate wants and of being arrogant—Senator Sherry has chucked the `arrogance' word around from time to time. Then you respond and the issue is, `You are doing what we essentially wanted—more contact with people—but now we are worried about the cost.' Well it will involve costs but, looking around at my officers, I do not think we have an estimate of those costs available now.
—Senator Allison, could you give a brief explanation of your amendments about the tax commissioner taking all reasonable steps? Could you give a brief outline of what you think is meant by that?
—The amendments already cover those. In total, there are five approaches by the commissioner to those people who have not provided their tax file numbers. That seemed to us to be very reasonable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to persist with both our request and Senator Harradine's request about the cost. I make this fundamental point: we believed from day one that your collection mechanism was a shambles. It imposes enormous cost not just on the tax office but also on superannuation funds to collect what was supposedly a tax aimed at higher income earners. But it has turned out to be not a tax aimed at just higher income earners; it is, in reality, going to collect tax from a lot more than the 360,000 people who are higher income earners as you define them. That does not mean we should not pursue the issue now that you have accepted there is a problem by accepting—
—No, we haven't.

—You do accept there is a problem. Why else did Mr Costello draft up this amendment with the Democrats in consultation with your advisers? You are accepting there is a problem. You have at last admitted it.

SPEECH.PARA: For the last nine months the Treasurer has been saying, `No retreat. No change. Plenty of consultation but no change. Never amend anything. Don't admit we're wrong. Everyone else says we're wrong, but don't admit we're wrong.' That has been the consistent approach, particularly of the Treasurer. You very valiantly tried to defend that position on occasions.

We would like to know the cost. It is important. I make the point, Senator Kemp: you have been very willing to throw at us the cost of all our amendments. You had them all costed. You complained that you did not have the amendments for very long. You could cost all those amendments in a day or two.

Here we are today asking about the cost of this from the tax office. You had your amendment for three days. You did the deal last Wednesday. Why hasn't the tax office got estimates of what this will cost? Not down to the last dollar, or even the last million dollars; we would not expect that. But certainly is it $10 million, $20 million or $30 million? Some ballpark estimate would be useful.

The other point I have raised, Senator Allison and Senator Kemp, is what happens to people who have superannuation accounts open prior to 7 May who do not provide a tax file number with an account that is opened after 7 May? We have not yet had that issue addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, we have not had your amendments costed, so you are wrong on that basis. Your amendments were designed essentially to undermine the workability of the surcharge, and of course we opposed them on those grounds. You did not have to have them costed to see the effect of those amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to this incredibly complex, as you describe it, collection approach, I wonder whether you understand what is being asked of the superannuation funds. Let me take you through it again. Superannuation funds have to supply the contributor's name, they have to supply the contributions and the tax file number as amended as a result of this. They send that to the tax office. What is so dramatically complex about that? Then the tax office matches the income and the contributions. Where a debit has to be raised, that is then sent back.

Get real. This is not impossibly complex. Let me tell you that what you were trying to do was complex. I do not suggest that there are not some complex issues involved here. Of course there are, as there would be with any attempt in this area to bring greater equity. We have been talking about unfunded defined benefit funds. Those issues would always arise. But get real. This is not all that complex in essence. Sending a person's name, their contributions and their tax file number to the tax office is impossibly complex? I mean, get real, Senator.
Let me tackle the second issue you raised. You asked what happens to a person prior to 7 May and after 7 May. I wish you would listen because, at least from my perspective, we answered that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —You forgot one step. They have to collect it, don't they?

—Senator, where contributions are less than $2,000, if a person was a member of the fund before 7 May, then no TFN is required. That is what the amendment says. If a person joined the fund on or after 7 May, a TFN is required and the fund can advise a member on joining of the consequences of not providing the number. That is not complex. Then we have mechanisms which have been put into place as a result of the amendment that Senator Allison has moved.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the pressures on Senator Conroy. I understand them, Senator, don't worry. The Hansard will show that you got up and fought the good fight, but I understand the pressures on you. The reality is that this is not complex. Senator Sherry says that the government has admitted there is a problem. The government has admitted nothing. We recognise the numbers in the chamber. Senator Sherry on the one hand says that the government is arrogant and never seems prepared to discuss issues. When we discuss an issue, recognising the numbers, Senator Sherry says it is a flip‐flop. Well, Senator, I have to say you have been all over the place on this issue from day one. But boy, today you are totally all over the shop.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just done a quick back‐of‐the‐envelope calculation which might assist the Senate. If we have a notice on the group certificates going out to people, and if we already have some of the tax file numbers in the hands of the super funds, we think that will possibly mean that around 50 per cent of people still would not have provided their tax file numbers to the superannuation funds. Then the tax office has the opportunity to data match—we are persuaded by Senator Kemp that its capability to do that is very good now—and we believe that ought to knock out a further 20 per cent or so.
—There is the cost of data matching.

—Well, perhaps it is not as much as sending letters out to people. They will then be required to write to people and this may involve three to four million employees. The cost of that could be somewhere between $5 million and $10 million. In any case, we would argue that that is a lot less than what Senator Sherry would suggest—that is that we vote down this bill, which would mean that a tax on high income earners would not be collected. We think that, by and large, even if that sounds like a fairly large sum of money in order to collect the tax file numbers and make the scheme work, it is still a long way short of the measure that we are looking at. It might be useful for us to have more accurate figures than those, but that indicates fairly clearly that we are not talking here about an enormous sum of money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Allison for providing those figures, which Senator Kemp, with all the resources of the Taxation Office sitting next to him and with hundreds of employees, could not provide. The Democrats have made a valiant effort to cost this particular aspect that we are dealing with today. Of course, Senator Allison, that comes on top of what has already been allocated to the Taxation Office for this measure. Senator Kemp, what was that figure—$20 million or $10 million?
—The advice I get is that it is $9.5 million for the first two years and $3 million after that.

—Okay, so it is on top of that figure plus the extra cost to the superannuation funds which they tell us is between $20 million and $100 million. What is that all up? Let us assume a $100 million round figure approximately—to collect half a billion dollars in revenue from supposedly high income earners only. In the meantime, what are all these high income earners doing? You pick up the Business Review Weekly and tax advice newsletters and you will see they are all looking at repackaging and getting out of superannuation. So we have what might be $50 million—I think that is on the low side, as the all‐up cost of collecting this tax; it might be $100 million—to collect half a billion dollars in revenue from supposedly just the high income earners earning more than $70,000. And those high income earners are out there repackaging as quickly as they can and pulling out of super.

SPEECH.PARA: Treasury is saying that there will not be one dollar lost from high income earners repackaging—they have told us that. No wonder they do not want to give us advice on what this is going to cost to collect. They told us that there would not be one dollar of revenue lost from high income earners—they told us that either in the select committee hearings or the estimates hearings. I predict there will be a significant loss of revenue in the second and third year from high income earners repackaging. We know they are doing it at the moment. All the anecdotal evidence supports that and, again, if you would listen to industry, you would know that, Senator Kemp.

So we have $50 million to $100 million in extra administrative costs to collect what might turn out to be $300 million from high income earners—maybe $300 million or $400 million. We do not think that the government will get the half a billion dollars in the second and third years from higher income earners. It might get it from people earning less than $70,000 a year. That makes it an extraordinarily expensive and inefficient tax to collect, extraordinarily so by any measure. One of the fundamental approaches to tax is to at least have an efficient collection mechanism.

Senator Kemp is not going to provide us with the figures. That is regrettable. History will tell us in a few years whether or not this is an efficient tax, as well as disclosing all the other problems that we foresee arising with it. History will tell us that, and we will look back in a few years, after this has all been implemented, at the total true cost and the total true revenue from high income earners and at the total revenue collected from people earning less than $70,000. We will also be able to measure the effect on confidence in the superannuation industry. By then we might have one state that is willing to say that it is going to pass state laws to collect this new tax. We do not have any yet. By then of course it might have been challenged in the courts. It might all disappear into history in the Federal Court and possibly the High Court. All these are unresolved issues.

Anyway, we have debated this enough. I understand our amendments Nos 6 and 8 were put and defeated. We are not happy with the Democrat‐government deal, for the reasons that we have outlined. We will be voting against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow up a question I asked Senator Allison a few minutes ago. What happens if the Taxation Office and the super fund are unsuccessful in contacting a low income earner via the mail? As Senator Kemp is fond of telling the Senate, in my previous occupation I was a super officer for the TWU super fund. I have been involved in trying to track down members whose address you do not have. Senator Allison, I am interested in what protection you think your amendments give to low income earners who do not have a current address that either the Taxation Office or their super fund is able to reach them at.

—The intention of the amendment is that there be two letters: one to the employee's home address and another to the workplace. Presumably the tax office knows the address of the workplace, so that should be a straightforward matter.

—Having been involved directly, as I mentioned earlier, in trying to track people down when I have their former workplace and their former address, and then trying to move on from there to find them, I repeat: how and where in this legislation—which you say is protecting low income earners because you are voting for it now—is there protection for a worker who is not aware because the mail has not reached him because he has moved his workplace as well?

—We believe we have put in as many reasonable measures as we can. I would be interested in your own suggestions if you think these are inadequate. It would be interesting to know what you could come up with in place of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could make a brief contribution. For contributions less than $2,000 prior to 7 May, if there is no surcharge there is no TFN. This measure provides protection. I honestly wish people would listen to what Senator Allison is saying. Protection is provided. It is no good you getting up and asserting that this is not the case. If there was a new account after 7 May and no TFN, after taking all the required steps, including writing to the member twice and so forth, the fund would tell the person, `If you open up an account after 7 May a tax file number may prevent you paying the surcharge'. Then, if all those letters are written, at the end of the day if you do not respond to what the superannuation fund says, if you do not respond to the letters—and you complain that too many letters are sent out— the answer is clear from what we have put down. What we are doing is taking all reasonable steps.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry says that everyone will get out of superannuation—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say everyone.

—If they listened to you on the radio last week, they would have heard you giving a bit of free advice that that may be the way to go. I might refer to the Business Review Weekly of 28 April which says that money is pouring into superannuation. Even taking into account the surcharge, it is still a very effective investment. There have been articles in the Financial Review , and I will not go through them, saying that it is still a very effective investment, even for high income earners. Even people in the superannuation industry, quite rightly, are getting very annoyed at this constant scare tactic.
—Who?

—I think there was a manager from the National Bank who came out and made a very useful point in relation to this issue, that it is time for people to settle down and get on with the job. What you said on the radio and what you are saying here in this chamber is not demonstrated by the press articles which are coming out. It is just not demonstrated, so why keep on saying it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Time will tell, and time is running out. I might say to Senator Allison that the solution for dealing with these problems was to have referred this back to the government for a total re‐write before Easter. You did not support us in that approach. Had we done that, the government would have been forced in the intervening period to re‐write all of this legislation, and here today we would have had a re‐written package of bills that would have provided, I am sure, if the Treasurer (Mr Costello) had genuinely wanted it, half a billion dollars from high income earners. We would have been considering a much more simplified approach to this legislation today but, regrettably, we are dealing with it in the way we are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to correct one statement made by Senator Allison. She said that if we do not like the proposals put up in this amendment which has been agreed to by the government—and I am not sure where it says amendments in such bills have to be agreed to by the government; I thought it was by a majority of the Senate—this could have been dealt with. If there were people who believed that the government was leaving out a whole lot of people through unfair requirements—that they should have to be proven guilty before they could prove themselves innocent in relation to having to pay a tax—together in the Senate we could have worked out how to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: We had some amendments—opposition amendments 6 and 8—which in fact provided a model, but they were voted down with the help of the Australian Democrats. There were also our amendments, the Greens' amendments, which looked at average weekly earnings. So there have been models put to the Senate. With assistance from the Democrats, the Senate chose to refuse to deal with those.

Let us put this fairly and squarely on the table. We have been left with an inadequate response to a ghastly bill. I have to say that this amendment is marginally better than nothing. I will support this amendment as we have been left with no other option since the other options were voted down. So this is what the Senate is left with. We know the numbers are there. We know it means that the government then will get to decide how many of the real strugglers in our society will have to squirm under private and public bureaucracies to get themselves out of this. I would like to say that the Greens were not responsible.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Allison's ) be agreed to.
Noes 23

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Neal did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to amend my amendment which has been previously circulated in the chamber. It is necessary to slightly amend this amendment by reason of the fact that the amendment was drawn up on the basis of the legislation that was previously before us. I wish to amend `page 11' to `page 10' and `after line 18' to `after line 27'. It does not alter the intent of the measure one iota. I move:

BREAK.PARA: Clause 10, page 10 (after line 27), at the end of the clause, add:

TAB.EMPHASIS: No surcharge is payable on pensions or annuities

PARA.TAB: (5) If benefits financed by otherwise surchargeable contributions are payable as non‐commutable pensions or annuities, the surcharge is not payable.

BREAK.PARA: This is a serious amendment to an unprincipled piece of legislation. I believe that the Senate should at least ameliorate the disorder that will emerge from this unprincipled legislation.

Pensions and annuities are already taxed at ordinary income tax rates in the hands of the recipients. There is no concessional tax treatment of pensions and annuities. Lump sum payments do attract a maximum of 30 per cent tax. The only part of an annuity or pension which is not subject to the tax is that part which represents a refund of a person's own undeducted contributions. The effect of my proposal is to try to ensure that income is taxed once and once only when it is received into the hands of the recipient and not before. It is a fair taxation principle that income should only be taxed once and once only when it is received into the hands of the recipient. That, I believe, is fair, equitable, reasonable and just. This is what my amendment seeks to do.

The superannuation surcharge represents further taxation. It is in effect double taxation. When it comes to Commonwealth public servants and state public servants the surcharge also applies to people—we will deal with them later—who are part way through their careers and as such it will be a retrospective charge because it will result in the reduction in a promised employer contribution. Those who entered into the schemes did not do so on the basis that there would be such a surcharge as proposed in this legislation. They entered into an agreement with their employer to enter a superannuation scheme which would recognise the contribution that they have made to the public. I am talking now of Commonwealth public servants.

These people have given years of service on lower salaries than they could earn elsewhere. There are many of those. They chose to go into the Public Service because it gave them some sort of guarantee. Superannuation was a very big factor in the minds of many public servants when they chose to go into the Public Service. They could have received higher salary packages outside.

You will be aware, Madam Temporary Chairman, and other senators will be aware, especially those in the government, that I have not always considered that the Public Service provided the best advice to various governments. I have questioned them constantly in estimates committees and elsewhere. Surely the government's senior advisers do not deserve retrospective double taxation of their pensions and that is precisely what this measure does.

On a technical level, the surcharge can only operate for unfunded pension schemes—for example, for public servants, government schemes and the armed forces—by creating a notional or hypothetical surchargeable employer contribution. And If we debate the third reading of the bill or if we come to a situation where we have to declare a vote for or against this legislation I will come to the problem of the constitution with respect to that matter. I just wanted to refer to the fact that there are quite serious constitutional problems in imposing a tax on a notional amount. For example, I raise the question: what is the `subject of taxation' as required by the constitution?

Surely sensible government policy would encourage superannuation to be paid as a pension or annuity instead of by way of lump sum. But what the government is doing here with this measure is discriminating against those who take their amounts as pensions or as annuities. That policy of the government surely will force people to prefer lump sums to pensions. According to the government, in the long run only private pensions can do the job of replacing public pensions, and that is what this is all about. But in this legislation the government is discriminating against those who take the payments as annuities or pensions.

I know that time is on the wing, but I would like to ask a number of questions of the minister. In the case of pensions or annuities not paid out of a fund, the surcharge can only operate by forcing a reduction in pensions promised by the employer. I would ask the minister: is that just; is that proper? For example, take a Commonwealth public servant. Why is it equitable to impose a second tax on a pension which is already fully taxable? Is it not retrospective for an employer such as the Commonwealth to cut the pension promised to a public servant halfway through the term of his or her service? What is so wrong with attempting to provide for one's own retirement that one should be punished with retrospective double taxation for doing so?

I will leave it at that. I do feel that it is very important not to discriminate, even if this is a discriminatory bill as a whole. I feel that the minister should respond to the questions that I have asked him—particularly as he is representing the employer of Commonwealth public servants—as to whether it is just to do what he is proposing to do and as to whether what I am proposing by this amendment will at least ameliorate that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting the amendment. The amendment proposes to exclude non‐commutable pensions or annuities from the application of the surcharge. In order to be equitable, the surcharge should not discriminate between various categories. In other words, it should be applied in an equitable fashion amongst the various ranges and types of superannuation schemes which are in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The surcharge does not discriminate between pensions or lump sums. It does not alter the current balance. Pensions are commuted to pay the surcharge, whereas the surcharge is funded from the lump sum. It does not discriminate. Senator Harradine's amendment would discriminate strongly in favour of a particular class of pension schemes. Senator Harradine mentioned the Commonwealth Public Service and the state Public Service, and I endorse the good work which is done in the Public Service. I have great respect for the work which is done in the Commonwealth Public Service, with which I have closest association. But this is not about the Public Service. This is about fairness and equity.

Senator Harradine, I know this is not your intention, but if your amendment were accepted, let me tell you what the headline on the front page of all major newspapers would be tomorrow: `Senators vote to exclude themselves from the application of the surcharge'. That would be the headline, because the effect of your amendment is to exclude Commonwealth schemes, which includes the schemes paid to senators and members of parliament. It would be contrary to what the Treasurer announced in his budget speech last year. We do not think that is fair, and we will not be supporting your amendment. This is not a retrospective amendment; it applies from 20 August last year when it was announced. It affects the contributions of high income earners from that date, but it is not retrospective.

As I have said, we believe that, on the contrary, this is a principled bill; it is not an unprincipled bill. It is a principled bill because it attempts to address the fact that most of the concessions available to superannuation flow to upper income people. It attempts to address what is an inequity, so it is not an unprincipled bill. It is quite the reverse, in my view. It affects public servants in the higher income group just as it effects all other members of the community in the higher income group.

There are a number of technical issues involved. For example, I am advised that with your amendment it would not apply where an eligible termination payment is rolled over to purchase a non-commutable pension or annuity, unless the previous surcharge assessments were reopened and amended.

Senator, we listened to what you said. We think your amendment would bring in discrimination between various types of funds, which we do not support. We believe that this bill attempts to ensure there is equity between all type of funds. Therefore, we cannot support the proposal that you have put before the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps, to start with, the minister could advise whether or not parliamentarians are covered under this bill.
—Yes.
—Federal parliamentarians?
—Yes, federal parliamentarians.
—So federal parliamentarians do not come under the exemption applicable to High Court judges, and so on?
—No. I am sorry about that.
—I was just checking. I thought somehow you had managed to draft it and leave yourselves out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats have looked very closely at this amendment of Senator Harradine and we have listened to what he has had to say about pensions and annuities. There was, of course, some evidence which came to the Senate committee on this issue. We do share Senator Harradine's desire to see that pensions and annuities are clearly preferred over lump sum payments. But that is not the issue with this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is about the fairness of what goes into superannuation, not the fairness of what comes out. The Democrats have long been on the record supporting the changes to rules to prefer pensions and annuities over lump sums. But we believe that the best way to do this is by the tax treatment on final end benefits and the preservation rules.

I do not believe this is about a second tax. This bill is about fairness of the massive tax concessions flowing to high income earners on their superannuation contributions. It does not matter whether they take their final benefit as a pension or a lump sum, as the simple fact remains that high income earners enjoy a very large subsidy on their superannuation—so large, in fact, that EPAC estimates that over half of final benefits flow not from the contributions paid but from the accumulation of the tax concessions themselves.
On this basis, while we are sympathetic with Senator Harradine's intent, the Demo crats advise that we will not be supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just double-check this issue in relation to 72(iii) of the constitution in relation to those who fall under the category that includes currently serving federal judges.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) has made an announcement on that: that there is a constitutional provision which will prevent the surcharge being imposed on currently appointed existing federal judges. But new appointees are not so protected, I am advised.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask the minister: will state politicians be affected by this package of legislation?
—It is our intention that they will be.
—Whilst we are on the subject, do we have any update about the position of the states and their attitude to this package of legislation from last Wednesday?
