SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I know you are interested in this ball-by-ball description in relation to the states. Frankly, I am not able to give you any significant change on the advice I have given you already, which is that we expect the states to move once we have a bill which has been passed by the parliament. The sooner this bill is passed, the more effectively we can encourage the states to sit down and discuss this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The intention of the bill, as I have said, is that a surcharge should apply to high income earners, regardless of what particular scheme they happen to be involved in. Following the passage of this bill, we will discuss with the states the application of surcharge to contributions to state schemes that may have constitutional protection. But, as I have said to you, I think the attitude is that we have to have a bill that has been passed so that we can then encourage adoption by the states—and it is my hope and expectation that that approach will prove to be very constructive.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just on this issue—and we have questioned you about this in question time and estimates—you commenced discussions and had a meeting with the states in January or February about this issue; that was four or five months after the initial budget announcement. I would just make the point that here we are in the middle of May, and there is as yet no agreement. But, Senator, could I ask you: have you checked with both the Prime Minister's office and the Treasurer's office on this matter of what the states do or do not intend to do?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have checked with my advisers to get an update on this matter, and I am not in a position to provide you with further information. We are well aware of comments which have been made by some of the state leaders from time to time. But we believe that the Australian community expects the surcharge to be applied in a fair and equitable manner, and that means that it would be applied to state schemes. Once this bill is passed, I believe that that will provide the impetus to ensure that we can, hopefully, quickly finalise matters relating to the surcharge with the states.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Your advisers are here. You have said that your advisers have told you that there has been no further update. Could you check with your advisers now to see whether there is any further information from either the Prime Minister's office or the Treasurer's office—yes or no—about the states' attitude or any state in particular?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are well aware of the attitudes of the premiers. A number of premiers have gone on the public record and made some comments. The reality is that, once this bill is through, it is our hope and expectation that we will be able to finalise the discussions with the states. But I think it is important that the bill go through so that people know precisely what they are talking about.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right. It is important the bills go through, because time is marching on. I ask you again: will you check with your advisers now as to whether any view has recently been conveyed—in the last two weeks—to either the Prime Minister's or the Treasurer's office by the states about their attitude, yes or no, to this package of legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have turned to my advisers. I do not think that anyone is able to provide me with any updates. I know that a number of premiers have gone on the record on this issue. Some have not been entirely favourable or complimentary—I understand politics, so I am well aware of that, Senator. I do not think that, apart from the general approach we are adopting, I can assist you any further.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Good. I note in concluding that point that I think I have asked you on no less than three or four occasions over the last week in debate about this issue. Watch further developments. Does the government support the principles of encouraging individuals to take their superannuation as a pension or does the government believe that individuals should take their superannuation as a lump sum?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have the procedures in place and people have options. The fact of the matter is that those options are in law. Until the government decides to make changes and until it has a majority in the Senate I cannot add any further to what I have said. There are options available to people. People have a right to exercise those options.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In making a number of comments about Senator Harradine's amendment, I should indicate—I have not had a chance to go over to Senator Harradine and mention this to him—that we will be moving an amendment to Senator Harradine's amendment. It is only one line, and it will be words to the effect: `this provision shall not apply to the parliamentarians superannuation fund'.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor introduced the superannuation guarantee charge in order that Australians would be self‐funded or partially self‐funded during their retirement. Labor believes that our superannuation system—and it is our superannuation system—in contrast to the approach of the Liberal government to superannuation, encouraged security and stability for individuals in their retirement. More will be said about this as a consequence of what is obviously Mr Costello's view that the additional three per cent government contribution will not be paid to Australian workers' superannuation. That will be an argument after the budget. We believe that the government's tax will contribute to undermining security and stability in retirement. A range of other issues has contributed to this lack of security and stability.

We believe that the Liberal government's approach to superannuation seeks also to remove incentives for individuals to take their superannuation as pensions. That is one of the undesirable consequences of the package of legislation we have before us. Why would you take superannuation as a pension when you could take it as a lump sum, therefore minimising your surcharge debt? We believe that will be one of the consequences of the passing of this legislation.

It is not just an issue for the public sector; it is an issue for the whole community. There are schemes relating to BHP, Coles Myer, CSR, Amcor and Coca‐Cola. A considerable number of private sector superannuation funds have pension provisions within them. The members may receive pensions; we believe it is a good thing that they receive pensions. The whole of government debt establishes an income scheme that is taxed at whatever the marginal tax rate is later in life. We believe that is a good approach.

We believe that the fundamentals of Senator Harradine's approach on this issue are correct. We do not believe that we as politicians should in any way be seen to be favourably treated by any amendments that we consider before the Senate, and that is why Labor is excluding the parliamentary superannuation fund. We will support Senator Harradine's amendment if our amendment is carried. He may accept it; I am not sure. It is up to the will of the chamber.

I finish on the point I raised earlier. This legislation does not cover state politicians or, for that matter, state government employees. Despite your bland assurances that we have been hearing for some six months now, Senator Kemp, we are not confident that, at the end of the day, state government employees will be covered by this package of legislation in whatever form the states choose to implement legislation at the state level. There has been no sign to date that they will move in this area—in fact, all the signs have been negative, as you have alluded to.

We will have a grossly unfair situation where employees in the private sector and employees in the Commonwealth public sector, except for current serving judges, will be hit by this new tax. We will have emerge a new tax that will exclude certain classes of employees in this country by virtue of being state government employees. We make that prediction now, Senator Kemp. I hope it does not happen, but we believe it will on all the evidence that we have before us. There is no certainty that the states will act to pass complementary legislation at the state level.

As I have said, we think the theme and the thrust of Senator Harradine's amendment is correct. We do not believe that parliamentarians should be treated differently and we intend to ensure that they are not. For that reason, I move:
At end of amendment, add the following subsection:
(6) Subsection (5) shall not apply to members of the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Scheme.
Hopefully, if we establish that principle very soundly, this amendment of Senator Harradine's will be passed by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel inclined to support the opposition's amendment, which means that an amendment will not go through which puts parliamentarians' superannuation schemes and pensions in a different category to other people who are on high incomes and who are subject to the surcharge.

SPEECH.PARA: I am caught between the devil and the deep blue sea in this case because there is still the assumption built in that we are going in the direction of self-funded retirement. I guess we are very much in the minority in this chamber because the Greens do not believe it is ethical to cease as a society to look after our elderly. We have accepted holus‐bolus the idea that there should be benefits for those people who have the ability to fund their own retirement.

That does leave me between the devil and the deep blue sea. I can see what Senator Harradine is getting at here, but I am wondering whether that is going to push us more in the same direction and we will end up with pensions as a form of charity and more and more assistance given to those people who will have the ability to pay for a reasonable old age.

I will still listen further in the debate, but at the moment I can certainly guarantee that I will support the opposition's amendment in relation to parliamentarians because people will be expecting that we are not doing all this and exempting ourselves. They were specifically the questions I was asking Senator Kemp to clarify earlier. I need to listen more to the debate to see whether or not we are as a total package still moving towards giving some subsidy or assistance to the rich and ending up with a system where we are not funding retirement properly and are not making any guarantee, except for people who have a demonstrated poverty, that we are going to look after the elderly in our community.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond briefly to some of the remarks that Senator Sherry made. I said the Labor Party is all over the place on this bill. The Labor Party, apparently, pretends to support the application of the 15 per cent surcharge on the contributions of high income earners but attempts through a whole range of amendments to undermine that principle.

BREAK.PARA: We have to remember that the vast amounts of concessions flow to people on high incomes. That is why this is an equity measure. This does not undermine ultimately the attraction of superannuation. I quoted a number of recent press reports which make it quite clear that superannuation is still a very attractive option for many people, including people on high incomes.

Senator Sherry naturally had to move as rapidly as possible when I pointed out to him that he was about to support an amendment which would have meant that politicians were not going to be liable for the surcharge. I have never seen faster footwork than I saw on the other side of the chamber as Senator Sherry suddenly realised that he had got the Labor Party into a totally impossible position and could witness the headlines in the newspapers the following day. Senator Sherry attempted to exclude MPs from the surcharge. The public would not have worn that, Senator Sherry, one little bit. I notice the attempt to rectify a problem which is in part totally of your own creation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not our amendment; we did not create the problem.

—But you said you were supporting it. Then I pointed out to you that you were about to exclude politicians from the surcharge. That is when I pointed that out to you and then you rapidly had to do a backflip. That is how careless you have been on this whole measure. This shows the lack of thought and application which has gone into this fairness measure that should be applied equitably to high income earners regardless of the schemes they are in.

BREAK.PARA: It does not alter, Senator Harradine, the balance between the funded and unfunded schemes. In fact, the whole point is to ensure that there is equitable treatment right across the system. In my view, Senator Allison was correct to point out that the concessions which are available flow in large part to people on high incomes. That is why this measure is about equity. That is why it is a principled measure, and that is why the government supports it.

Indeed, most people in the community support the principle of it. It is only the modern Labor party which does not believe in equity and which has been all over the place on this issue. Senator, I have noted before how you have flip‐flopped on this issue because you are from an unprincipled position. The principled position is that we have to address the issue that most concessions in the superannuation area flow to high income earners and therefore it is not unreasonable that the 15 per cent should be applied. I would have thought that any traditional Labor Party, noting that it applied to high income earners, would have found no difficulty in accepting that principle.

You have been all over the place on it. Your leader has said that he accepts the principle, but you have done everything you can in this chamber to undermine and to defeat this bill. You almost made a complete goose of yourself, frankly, by supporting an amendment which would have meant that MPs did not have to pay the surcharge. That is the position that you got yourself and the Labor party into.

I know that was not the intention of Senator Harradine, but with your interest in this matter, Senator Sherry, you should have been quite aware of what you were voting for. As a consequence, you have been forced to move an amendment—much to your own embarrassment, but noting the howls of rage that would have come from the Australian public when it saw that the Labor Party was attempting to support MPs being excluded from the application of this surcharge. We believe this surcharge should be applied across the board to high income earners, regardless of the particular schemes they are in.

Senator, you mentioned the states to me and whether we had received any recent communication from them. I am advised that there has been some correspondence from the states. This forms part of the consultation process and will obviously be progressed when the legislation is passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution just made by the minister must be answered. There is absolutely no principle behind the government's superannuation legislation that is currently before this chamber. Every time that this is pointed out, the minister starts diversionary activities; he takes a populist line.

SPEECH.PARA: When it is pointed out to him that there is need to protect low income earners from paying this surcharge, what does he do? He cans that on the basis that it might mean that there will be tax avoidance. That term `tax avoidance' is a prejudicial term, and you are using it for prejudicial purposes. Then, when we are attempting to get some equity into this inequitable piece of legislation, you say, `Oh, look at the politicians. This is going to let them go scot‐free.' That is another prejudicial statement.

Let us get down to the principles that should be applied, those principles have been enunciated by philosophers and economists over the years. Let me remind you, Mr Temporary Chairman, and the committee of what I said in the second reading debate. I referred to this question of principle and John Stuart Mill in his Principles of Political Economy.

I referred also to Professor William Vickrey who is now a Professor Emeritus of Colombia University and former President of the American Economic Association. He examined this question of equity as far back as 1947. The principle of lifetime income averaging did find favour with him and with economists such as J.S Mill. Professor Vickrey makes the point in his treatise, Agenda for Progressive Taxation, at page 166—and I ask you to deny whether this is a proper principle or not, Minister—where he says:
There would still be a very serious doubt of the equity of taxing each year's income as a separate entity.
And underlying this whole measure that is what you are doing. He continues:

With progressive rates, an individual whose income fluctuates from year to year will, under this method, pay a heavier tax than an individual having the same average income more evenly distributed from year to year.
Vickrey goes on at page 186 to point out that it is logical in fact to average a taxpayer's income over his lifetime.

I want the government to come back to the question of principle. Senator Sherry—or it may have been Senator Margetts—asked the minister whether the government supported the taking of the amounts by way of pension or annuity, or whether they are supporting the lump‐sum approach. If they are wanting to have an equitable arrangement then they have not got it in the legislation because, as you know, there is a maximum amount of tax payable for persons receiving lump sums. That maximum figure, that ceiling, does not apply in respect of pensions and annuities. Those pensions and annuities, in fact, will be taxed at a greater amount than will the lump sums. Is that fair? Is that equitable? I ask the minister to respond to what I have said.

Why is it not retrospective double taxation? A person who has worked half his life with a set idea of what his pension will be will now be taxed at a new rate. Why? You are taxing at an extraordinarily high rate the sacrifice that that person—he may be a Commonwealth public servant—has made to the public of Australia. That person, who has struggled on lower rates of pay, now may have a particular rate of pay that appears on the face of it to be substantial. Also, regard has not been given to the number of dependants that a person on that income may have.
May I refer to what Senator Margetts said. She asked whether the government is really moving towards the ultimate elimination of the age pension. I think she is right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that's right.

—Senator Sherry is nodding. I have been of that view for years. I read of a leak in the morning press that tomorrow night in the budget the government is going to put forward a lunatic idea to provide incentives for people to stay in the work force until they are 70 or 80.
—Until they're dead.

—Of course. They will not need to be paid pensions then. I have the figures: of more than 143,000 employees reaching eligible pension age in 1997, 12 per cent of males and nine per cent of females will die before they are eligible to receive the proposed full cash bonus. Great saving, Minister, great saving! Death is very handy for the budget, is it not? And this at a time, would you believe, when we have high unemployment and when you have heaps of people whom I know desire to retire at 60 or 65 but cannot because of economic pressures. What the government ought to be doing is to allow those persons who desire to retire to do so. It ought to give them the incentive to retire so that they can carry out their socially constructive work in voluntary organisations and enjoy their retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead, this government is using death to bolster its budget. I think that is disgraceful. We will hear more of that, of course. I hope the press have got it wrong—I really do—because such a proposal is ludicrous when you have got such a great number of unemployed.

The description of unemployment is that you have more people seeking paid work when there are no jobs available and new jobs have been slashed as a result of technological change and a number of other economic reasons. Under those circumstances, surely you would encourage people to leave the way open for others to enter the paid work force and so ensure that those people are able to do what they really want to do. That would be beneficial to voluntary organisations throughout Australia. I know a number of people who would love to retire if they could do so, if that sort of incentive were available the other way around.
Finally, I must say that I can count the numbers in this chamber. I am not going to press this matter to a division but I do commend it to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Arising from some of the questions put by Senator Harradine, I would like to ask: can the government give any assurances in relation to non‐commutable pensions or annuities? If a person has been paying into a scheme from the age of 20 until the age of 50—paying into superannuation schemes of some sort which in the end come out as non‐commutable pensions or annuities—can the government reassure the committee that anything they have contributed, and any expectations that they would have had up till the royal assent of this bill, will not be subject to retrospectivity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I make the point, and I made it before, that the surcharge only applies to contributions made after 20 August 1996—the night on which it was announced—so there is no retrospectivity involved there. Senator Harradine, you made a wide ranging speech. I listened carefully to it. You then strayed into press speculation on the budget, which I make no comment about and which you would not expect me to make any comment about.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have to say—and this is not always the case with me—that I do not agree with you. I profoundly disagree with a fair amount of what you said, Senator Harradine. This is about equity. It is about cutting down on the undue amount of tax concessions which flow through to high income earners in relation to superannuation. It is about treating different types of schemes in an equitable fashion.

I am surprised that the Labor Party has decided to support your measure, and I expect to be thanked by Senator Sherry for saving him from himself as a result of what he was about to do. I expect that not to be recorded in Hansard, Senator Sherry. I will accept the thanks later because you were about to make one hell of a blunder—make no mistake about it. So, Senator, we will not—
Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you are very frisky today. I know we are getting into the budget session and we are in training for that but, Senator, I notice that you will not be pressing your amendment to a division. We will oppose your amendment. Your amendment is marginally better with Senator Sherry's amendment—
—You support that, do you?

—We believe that politicians should not be exempt from the surcharge—make that absolutely clear. You were about to exempt politicians. That is what you were about to do. We believe you are dead wrong. So, Senator Harradine, without recanvassing the arguments that have been put, we will not be supporting your substantive amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that Senator Kemp did not foreshadow any amendment to ensure that federal politicians were not covered by this amendment. It is an absolutely outrageous approach from Senator Kemp to attempt to divert attention from his appalling attempts to exempt politicians from the coverage of this surcharge. The majority of politicians in this country are not going to be affected by these bills. Senator Kemp cannot—

—Temporary Chairman, I rise on a point of order. I would request that be withdrawn. The reality is that we were the ones who believed that politicians should have the surcharge imposed. You were the ones who were trying to exempt them.
—There is no point of order.
—Temporary Chairman, I rise on a point of order. That is not a point of order. You should have sat him down immediately.
—I just said there was no point of order.

—It is absolutely outrageous for Senator Kemp to come in here and make claims about exempting politicians when he knows full well that the majority of politicians in this country are not covered by this legislation—state politicians. Senator Kemp, assure the Senate, give a categorical undertaking, that state politicians will be covered by provisions reflecting this package of legislation. Assure us today that every politician will be covered in the same way as every private sector and public servant employee—with the exception of currently serving judges—by this legislation. Come on, Senator Kemp, get up and assure the Senate that every state politician is going to be covered by this surcharge.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, let me make it absolutely clear, in case people are not clear, about your wavering which attempted to sink this surcharge bill, which would have exempted all politicians. We believe that all politicians, state and federal, should be covered by this surcharge. We believe that any state government which attempts to exempt politicians would bear a very heavy political cost. The government, I can assure you, Senator Sherry—unlike what you were about to do—believes that in the sense of equity and fairness all politicians should be liable for this surcharge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, it is very easy to do that: call it a tax, as you should have done in the first place, and impose it directly on those people and you would not have a constitutional problem in imposing it on state employees, including politicians. The problem is you have yourself a dilemma. You have yourself in an enormous hole because of the way you have put this tax provision together, the so-called surcharge. You know you cannot surcharge state politicians, but you can tax them, and you can tax state government employees directly. You have let them out of the net, Senator Kemp, and it remains to be seen. We note today you cannot give any categorical assurance that state government employees, including politicians, will be caught in this provision.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another issue, Senator Kemp, that does involve federal politicians and federal judges. There were comments by Justice Davies two weeks ago on this package of measures. His opinion, the opinion of a serving Federal Court judge, was that this whole package of legislation has serious constitutional problems. If you want to prioritise where the problems are, if there is a constitutional problem it is going to lie with judges and politicians.

We could be passing this legislation, Senator Kemp, and because of the way you have constructed this legislation not only does it not collect a tax from state government employees, including state politicians, but it may, in fact, not collect a tax from either judges or federal politicians. If there is a constitutional weakness to this package of legislation, it may not apply to federal politicians or federal judges because of what you have done, Senator Kemp, in the way you have constructed the legislation. You continued to insist it be called a surcharge right up until an hour or two ago, when it was called what it should have been in the first place—a tax.

I ask you, Senator Kemp: do you have any legal advice about the applicability of this legislation to future judges and current and future federal politicians in the light of serving Federal Court judge Justice Davies's views on this matter that he conveyed to the Senate committee two weeks ago?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —During this debate the minister has indicated several times that it is a real snap for the superannuation funds. He kept saying that all they have to do is pay the money and that it is all done in about two stages, except he forgot to say that they collect the money first. The other bit he left out is the whole process of actually calculating it when it comes to such things as non-commutable pensions or annuities. We talked about lump sums before, but the sheer nightmare of not having the ability to calculate on simple tables means it would seem that every single person that is going to be involved in this type of scheme is going to have to have a separate calculation made for them.

SPEECH.PARA: As the minister has indicated, it is based only from when the announcement is made. That is interesting, because the bill's date of commencement is from royal assent. So it will be interesting how you will collect it from the date of announcement. However, that at least is retrospective.

How difficult is it going to be when people, after 40 years of work, for instance, want to know what it is they are actually going to get as income? What kinds of calculations are going to be necessary to add this number and take away the number you first thought of—working out exactly what their commitment will be on a weekly or fortnightly basis? Whose cost will that be? Will that be the individuals? Will they have to know, or will their superannuation fund have to know? Isn't this one little part of the complexity that you have conveniently missed out when you talk about what a snap it is for the superannuation funds to be involved in this whole process?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, there has been quite a bit of debate on this whole issue of unfunded defined benefit schemes. You have noted there was a major press release put out by the Treasurer on 15 February which outlined how this would be applied to unfunded defined benefit schemes. You will be aware of the discussions on the work of actuaries and the notional surcharge contribution rates which will be established under actuarial guidelines. Individual calculations are made for every person, whether they are in a funded scheme or not. An individual calculation is a thing which the tax office and others do on a regular basis. It is not some new thing, Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: As we have said, in the case of unfunded pensions, a surcharge would be payable when the first pension payment is made by commuting part of that pension to a lump sum. There is no surprise there, Senator. That has been very well known. There was a debate earlier on whether people in unfunded defined benefits schemes can make a contribution earlier. I believe an amendment to that effect moved by Senator Sherry was passed.

Senator Sherry raised some issues. I understand the embarrassment he has, but the Attorney-General's Department has advised that the surcharge can apply to newly appointed judges—there is no exclusion there—and of course it is going to be applied to politicians. It would be a very brave Senate which stopped it being applied to politicians, Senator Sherry, let me tell you.

Senator, you have raised an issue, and there is an issue on how you deal with unfunded defined benefit funds. That has been pretty extensively canvassed in this debate. I do not think I can add too much more. I believe Senator Harradine's amendment would alter the current balance between an accumulation fund and an unfunded defined benefit scheme which we will not support.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question went quite specifically to the view of serving Justice Davies about the constitutional application of this package of bills to new judges and current and future federal politicians, because we know state politicians are exempt from this legislation because they are not covered by it.

BREAK.PARA: Have you taken advice specifically in response to the views of Justice Davies on what he identified as a serious potential problem with this package of legislation—that is, its application to future serving judges as well as current and future federal politicians?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, these sorts of issues have been raised from time to time. I said the advice that we have is that the bills are constitutionally sound. I think Judge Davies was very qualified in the comments he made.
—You weren't there!
—They were very qualified despite your efforts to push the envelope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —You were not there. You did not hear his comments. I do not know whether you have read them and his qualifying comments since he gave his written evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp, the answer you just gave is the answer you gave when Mr Rose criticised the constitutionality of this legislation some seven or eight weeks ago. You assured us there were no problems with constitutionality.

What happened, Senator Kemp? Three or four weeks later you rushed in amendments to the House of Representatives as quietly as you could to remove the particular constitutional problem that Mr Rose QC identified. And you assure us that there is no problem with this legislation constitutionally. You assure us. Well, we will see, Senator Kemp. All the advice we are getting is that there are some serious question marks not just over the constitutionality as it applies to future judges and current and future politicians but that this whole legislation has a constitutional problem over it.

I would have thought a responsible government, if it did not want federal politicians excluded from this legislation, would have looked at this in the same way that you looked at the criticisms of Mr Rose QC. I would have thought you would have brought in amendments to this chamber to ensure that federal politicians and future serving judges—not current serving judges—are covered. Where are those amendments, Senator Kemp? Where are those amendments, in response to Justice Davies's concerns, that will categorically ensure that federal politicians, past and future, and future judges will be covered by this legislation? We do not accept your assurances, Senator Kemp. We think there is a question mark there and we think it is remarkably lax of the government to leave a loophole to leave politicians and judges out of this surcharge.

We think you are slack and lax in not responding to Justice Davies's criticisms in the same way as you responded to the criticisms of Mr Rose QC. You moved to minimise any prospect of constitutional challenge in respect of Mr Rose's comments. Why did you not do the same with the comments by Justice Davies, a serving Federal Court judge, bagging your legislation in the area of judges and politicians and highlighting this critical defect in the legislation. You are willing to let this legislation go through without minimising that potential escape hole or loophole that exists.

It is an appalling approach by the Treasurer. It is an appalling approach by your government. It is an appalling approach by you to knowingly leave an escape hatch because you are embarrassed about politicians being caught up in this package of legislation. That is the truth, Senator Kemp. You have left an escape hole and you have not moved to close it off. That is the action of an irresponsible government. You have left the escape hole for state politicians—you have not moved to close it off. Where is the legislation capturing state politicians and state government employees? Where is that legislation? We know it is easy to prepare. You can do it quite directly—tax them in the same way as you propose to tax everyone else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that your hysteria and rhetorical flourishes do not cover up the fact that you almost made a total goose of yourself earlier in the afternoon when you were about to support an amendment to exempt politicians from the surcharge. My pointing that out to you, as I said, led to one of the greatest flurries of activity that I have seen on your side of the chamber in the last 13 months. Senator, be in no doubt that your effort to undermine the surcharge is legendary. You have attempted to use every device, including the pretence that low and middle income earners were going to be hit, and your attempt to argue its constitutionality. After anyone gave you half a reason, you were out there trying to undermine the surcharge, Senator, and we know what the very reasons were.

SPEECH.PARA: Your arguments ring totally hollow. They are utterly hollow. The reality is that this is a fair bill. It is an equitable bill. We are very confident of the constitutionality of the bill and of course it has been drafted to ensure its constitutionality. I can assure you that, as the Treasurer said in his budget night speech and as I say today, there is no question that federal politicians will be liable for the surcharge, and they would not have been if the amendment you are about to support had got through.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, I am pleased on behalf of the numerous organisations and individuals that have made representations to us about the problems involving this new 15 per cent tax. We are pleased to have taken into account the concerns of organisations and individuals like Lambda Consulting; Sedgwick, Noble and Lowndes Ltd; Access Economics; Actuarial Buck Consultants; the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants; KPMG; Macquarie Investment; David Knox, a professor from the University of Melbourne, and your own superannuation adviser for a period of time, Coopers and Lybrand; the AMP Society; ASFA; the Institute of Actuaries; William M. Mercer Pty Ltd; National Mutual; Bankers Trust; the Taxation Institute of Australia and many more. We are pleased to be able to represent them in this chamber to try to minimise the effects of your surcharge, now a tax, particularly when you cannot name one organisation or individual except supposedly the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley. What a great referee that makes for you. You cannot give us the name of any organisations or individuals that support your approach on this new tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit rich for the minister to be suggesting that the opposition and presumably others who are opposing this measure are using a contrived argument in this particular sphere. What is the greatest contrived argument that has been floated about this chamber and the House of Representatives during this whole time of consideration of this measure? It is a contrived argument by the government to call this measure a surcharge when in fact it is a tax and has now been recognised by this Senate as a tax. I would have thought that the government should recognise that and now, at this late stage, withdraw this measure. If it wants to achieve the objectives that its policy determines it achieve, make the collection through the taxation system. You will then not endanger lower and middle income earners. You will be striking the targets that you are after, and there would be no administrative problem in that particular way. Now you have got all of these administrative problems as a result of the fact that you have described this measure as a surcharge and not as a tax.

SPEECH.PARA: If you were able to do that, if you decided to do it that way, you would catch all politicians in Australia. It is all very well to push aside His Honour's quite deliberate and premeditated remarks about this measure but he, of course, is of the view that it will not, and cannot, apply to members of the federal parliament, let alone the state parliaments. We all know that this measure of itself cannot apply to the majority of parliamentarians in Australia. That is what the government's decision means. This measure does not, and cannot, apply to state politicians, whereas, if the government were to have adopted the realistic attitude from the start and called this for what it is, namely, a tax, it would have been able to do that.

I understand what Senator Allison said about equity of input, the fairness of what goes in, and that the tax treatment is really what comes out. She is of the view that that ought to be dealt with in some other way. But the fact is that we are dealing with this measure under the tax system as it stands. The fact is that contributors to, and the beneficiaries of, superannuation funds—those that take the benefit by way of pension or annuity—are discriminated against when compared to those who take it as a lump sum.

I am not going to say anything more about this. As I said, I will not press my proposed amendment to a division in this chamber. I think it is totally unfair of the Assistant Treasurer to accuse the opposition of proposing an amendment which would in their view improve my amendment. That is what they have done. My final word is really an appeal to the Australian Democrats because, as I recall, the Australian Democrats did say that their view was, really, to `keep the bastards honest', although that may have been some time ago.

Here we have a situation where the government was elected on the promise that there would no new taxation measures in their first term. It has now been determined by the Senate that this is a taxation measure. We all knew it was a taxation measure; now it will be regarded legislatively as a taxation measure. As I understand it, the Democrats voted for this measure to be regarded as a taxation measure. I appeal to the Democrats to oppose a third reading of this measure because, by so doing, it will keep the government honest with respect to its election statement, which many people regarded as very important in the scheme of things prior to the election.

It is my belief that, if the Democrats were to do this, there would be the numbers in the Senate to defeat this measure. The government could then take it back and rewrite the legislation so as to make it more equitable through the use of its taxation powers.
Amendment (Senator Sherry's) agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Harradine's), as amended, negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 5, page 2 (after line 21), after subclause (2), insert:

PARA.TAB: (a) the member has not quoted his or her tax file number in connection with the operation or the possible future operation of the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Collection and Assessment) Act 1997 to the superannuation provider, or one of the superannuation providers, who, at the end of a financial year, held any of the member's surchargeable contributions for that year; and
(b) the Commissioner has not, after taking all reasonable steps, found out the member's tax file number; and

(c) the Commissioner has written to the member at the member's last-known address telling the member that, if the member does not quote his or her tax file number, the rate of surcharge that will apply to the member for that year may be 15% of the member's surchargeable contributions for that year;
the following provisions have effect:

(d) if contributed amounts in respect of contributions began to be paid for or by the member to a superannuation provider before 7 May 1997 and the member's surchargeable contributions for that year exceed the surchargeable contributions threshold—the rate of surcharge that applies to the member in respect of all the contributions paid to that provider for that year is 15% of those contributions;

(e) if contributed amounts in respect of contributions began to be paid for or by the member to a superannuation provider before 7 May 1997 and the member's surchargeable contributions for that year do not exceed the surchargeable contributions threshold—the rate of surcharge that applies to the member in respect of all the contributions paid to that provider for that year is nil;

(f) if contributed amounts in respect of contributions began to be paid for or by the member to a superannuation provider on or after 7 May 1997—the rate of surcharge that applies to the member in respect of all the contributions paid to that provider for that year is 15% of those contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 5, page 3 (after line 4), after subclause (3), insert:

PARA.TAB: (4) The Commissioner shall not impose surcharge in respect of a member under paragraph (3)(f) unless, in addition to the requirements in paragraph (3)(c) the Commissioner has, if the member has not complied with the request referred to in that paragraph within three months of the letter being sent, again written to the member at an address determined by the Commissioner as most appropriate to reach the member, telling the member that, if the member does not quote his or her tax file number, the rate of surcharge that will apply to the member for that year may be 15% of the member's surchargeable contributions for that year.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 3, after clause 5 (after line 4), insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Surchargeable contributions threshold for the 1996-97 financial year

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The surchargeable contributions threshold for the 1996-97 financial year is $2,000.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Surchargeable contributions for a later financial year

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The surchargeable contributions threshold for a financial year (the relevant financial year) after the 1996-97 financial year is the amount worked out using the formula:
Current charge percentage
Previous threshold x Indexation factor x
Previous charge percentage
where:
previous threshold means the surchargeable contributions threshold for the financial year immediately before the relevant financial year.
indexation factor means the number worked out under subsections 9(4) and (5) of the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Assessment and Collection) Act 1997 for the relevant financial year.
current charge percentage means the number that is the employer's charge percentage under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 for the relevant financial year.

previous charge percentage means the number that is the employer's charge percentage under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 for the financial year immediately before the relevant financial year.

I have previously canvassed the arguments for these amendments but I will just run over them quickly. This provides for exemptions for up to $2,000 in contributions for all existing superannuation accounts established by 7 May. After that time the threshold will not apply. That will prevent high income earners from opening multiple superannuation accounts of under $2,000 and avoiding this tax. Before that tax can be applied, the tax office will have to write initially to warn them that the surcharge will apply if they do not respond to the request by the superannuation funds for their tax file number and then a second time to each of the two addresses, residential and workplace.

With these amendment we aim to protect the workers already in the superannuation system. We provide a range of extra protection in the form of additional warnings and obligations for the tax office for workers yet to come into the system. But we also ensure that tax planners miss out on that opportunity to avoid the surcharge for high income earners by rearranging their affairs. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting the amendments. The arguments have been well canvassed. We believe the amendment that we moved in respect of the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Assessment and Collection) Bill effectively would exempt from collection everyone earning less than $2,000. There was a formula in that. We believe the approach by the Democrats is too complex, too messy. It does not provide the absolute protection that is required for low and middle income earners and it has the additional disadvantage of being very costly. In the interest of time we will not be calling a division on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments Nos 9 and 10 go to what we believe is a very important principle in the event—and we know that it will occur in respect of some people—of the collection of the tax from those earning less than $70,000. Regardless of the final number and regardless of the amount that is collected from those people, it is being taken out of their superannuation account and taken into the tax office and consolidated revenue. In taking it from a superannuation account—and these are people who should not be subject to this new 15 per cent tax on superannuation; the government has said that it is refundable if people go along and collect it, but we believe there are a lot of problems with that which I will not extensively debate—people who earn less than $70,000 are forgoing money that would have gone into their superannuation account.

We believe that where the money is collected back from the tax office interest should be paid on the amount refunded to them. We believe that is a very important principle given that this is money taken from superannuation accounts that would otherwise be earning interest on interest over some period of time. We are dealing here with superannuation. We are not dealing with other forms of income and tax treatment of that income. We believe that it is very important that people who have been disadvantaged by having a tax collected when it should not have been collected should not be disadvantaged in their final retirement income by not having interest credited when they finally are able to go and collect that money from the tax office that should not have been collected in the first place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be opposing this amendment. The rate of interest in the bill is the rate which applies to all overpayments made by the Commissioner of Taxation. There is nothing particularly special about this rate. It is based on a precedent which is well established and well known in tax law. Where the earning rate of a fund is below the rate of interest, that particular fund member would be advantaged. This is based on the precedent that it is the rate which applies to all overpayments made by the Commissioner of Taxation. Your amendment would mean that the commissioner would need to know the earning rate of every fund. I do not think that is practical.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, we believe superannuation is a special case. If you look generally at the earning rates of the vast majority of funds, from our observation, they earn, over a long period of time, more than the rate that the government is applying. This is superannuation. It is for retirement purposes. These people are paying a tax that they should not have to pay. In those circumstances we believe there should be special consideration for a special form of payment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Conroy did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (before line 4), before item 1, insert:
Insert:

(2AA) Notwithstanding any other provision in this section, an employer must not claim a deduction for contributions made on behalf of an employee unless the contributions are contributions which the employer is required to make under section 20 or 21 of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992. The deduction limit for the employer must not exceed the minimum contribution that the employer is required to make under those provisions.

We are dealing now with amendments to make sure that an employer must not claim a deduction for contributions made on behalf of an employee unless the contributions are contributions which the employer is required to make under section 20 or 21 of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992.

This deals with what we call the second simple idea of the superannuation contribution schemes. The first simple idea was that the rich ought to pay a reasonable, fair amount of tax. The second simple idea is that salary sacrifice is a problem that is mostly used by the rich. We would like to avoid a situation where people use a salary sacrifice measure in conjunction with their employer to avoid tax.

The issue here is fairly straightforward. Currently the law is that if a taxpayer is employed and their employer can claim deductions under section 82AAT of the ITAA, there are limits to deductions but deductions are fairly extensive.

The first $3,000 of contributions are tax free from the standpoint of the employer. After that, only 75 per cent of contributions are deductible. The remaining 25 per cent is classed as a non-deductible contribution; hence, it cannot be used to reduce tax paid by employers at the company rate of 36 per cent. In other words, contributions equivalent to nine per cent of a salary of $461 a week are tax free and afterwards are taxed at an effective rate of nine per cent within the limits set by subsection 2A(c), which allows a maximum deduction of $25,000 for workers aged 35 to 49 and higher still for workers 50 and over.

An employee can make additional contributions, but these come from income that is already taxed at marginal rates. In the case of someone earning $70,000, this would be 47 per cent—higher than the proposed 30 per cent of current tax plus surcharge. A self-employed or partially self-employed person can make their own contributions and claim deductions for them, also under section 82AAT of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This would include people who have intermittent incomes and are subject to the equalisation measures for taxation—farmers, writers, artists, athletes and the like. Again, there are limits to the deductions that can be claimed in any year, but deductible contributions are effectively tax free.

Once the money is contributed, it is taken to be income of the superannuation company and taxed at 15 per cent under section 26 of the Income Tax Rates Act. This 15 per cent tax was imposed in 1988 by the ALP over the strenuous objections of the coalition. The simple idea is to reduce tax benefits that provide opportunities primarily for high income earners with sufficient income that they can redirect some of it away from living costs. Wealthy employees, corporate executives and the like, take advantage of this not only without feeling restricted but also in a way that results in increased overall and long-term wealth and the maintenance of their high income status long after they cease to be productively employed.

Ending this situation is valid and an idea we support; however, the mechanism the government has chosen to pursue this goal is convoluted and awful. What this government has chosen to do is create a whole new structure so that superannuation companies must effectively vary their corporate tax rates on contributions, depending on the contributor's income. This is a violation of the principle that the rates act establishes rates for various general classes of taxpayers—residents, non-residents, businesses, et cetera—and for various general levels of assessable individual income.

The actual detail about what income is assessable in the individual case is contained in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Here we see the government again muddying the waters, as they did with the family tax initiative, trying to make the rates act do the job of assessing individual circumstances, which is the proper place of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Worse than that, they have violated another principle, which is that the taxpayer is liable for paying tax. Other persons, natural or corporate, are not liable for paying someone else's tax. The superannuation funds have so far been taxed in the rates act as businesses with income. The government now wants superannuation funds to act as agents of government and collect what amounts to personal income tax from contributors. This is not constitutional, nor is it logical.

We are not simply making a change in the rate at which superannuation contributions are taxed; we are also asking superannuation companies to collect and pay some portion of the income tax owed by individuals and so get access to their financial information to do so. We should have done this in a simple way.

BREAK.PARA: If the objective was to reduce tax minimisation through salary sacrifice packages which increased employer superannuation contributions, then the obvious thing to do is to try to restrict the amount of superannuation contributions a company can make over that obliged by the superannuation guarantee legislation.

If the intention was to increase the tax obligations of the rich, an increase in the highest tax margin or the creation of a new tax margin should have been undertaken. We have got amendments here to do both. The amendment we are speaking to first would limit 82AAT deductions by employers to the level they are required to make. In other words, they get no deductions for higher levels of superannuation contributions, and so such contributions will be taxed at the company rate of 36 per cent. Salary sacrifice packages may continue since 36 per cent is lower than the current top marginal rate of 47 per cent paid by those with income of over $50,000. The level of tax would be higher, however, than the level where the contributions were deductible under the current regime and then taxed at 30 per cent—that is, 15 per cent tax plus 15 per cent surcharge, which, of course, is tax as we know it. It will also apply to any worker getting a salary sacrifice tax minimisation deal.

This will not end such schemes but it will reduce their attractiveness. It will result in less money going from the rich to superannuation. Of course, so will the government's scheme. I do not think there is much difference between our plan and the government's in terms of the effect on superannuation contributions.

Encouraging savings is obviously not on the government's agenda. I do not see why tax minimisation and higher retirement incomes for the rich should be justified by the savings argument. Our plan will have the effect of increasing tax on required employer contributions, even for the rich. Somehow it is hard to justify requiring people to put in superannuation and then penalising through it. Either superannuation is something that government is prepared to create incentives for or it is not. If it is not, the simplest thing would be to simply eliminate all deductions for contributions.

It is also possible to say that employer superannuation contributions are a fringe benefit or remuneration and thus tax liability lies with the recipient of benefits taxed as FBT or a component of employee income taxed at the appropriate marginal rate. Our plan will avoid the need for a change to the taxation of superannuation companies and avoid the need for them to try to do the ATO's business of collecting individual financial records of contributors who actually pay the taxes the ATO says are owing. It will avoid the issues of privacy and unconstitutionality arising from this. It will avoid further mucking up of the rates act. It will avoid the situation where superannuation contributions required by an employer are suddenly effectively taxed at rates of up to 30 per cent. It will avoid the situation where an employee on $69,999 suddenly finds that the addition of $1 in income can cost them $42 on a six per cent contribution or $63 on a nine per cent one, as will be required by 2002 to 2003. It will avoid problems for part‐time and casual workers in relation to tax file numbers. It will avoid the problem of industries having to come to grips with yet another new legal regime which will undoubtedly be further modified in the future.

I think our method is clean and direct. It can accomplish it by the simple addition of a few lines in the Income Tax Assessment Act rather than the establishment of seven new acts. The financial implications are uncertain since this would probably mean an end to this particular form of tax minimisation, but probably not alternative forms. It would be good for revenue. I commend my amendment on page 501 to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting the amendment. Senator Margetts said that employers can get deductions for super contributions of $3,000, plus 75 per cent for contributions over $3,000. In fact, the whole amount of the employer contributions up to the age based limits is deductible. For self‐employed people the deduction is $3,000 plus 75 per cent of contributions over $3,000 up to the age based limits. The section that I think Senator Margetts is referring to is not correctly worded. Section 82AAT relates to self‐employed people and employers are entitled to deductions under section 82AAC, I think. Is that right?

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment, of course, would not affect members of public sector schemes. The amendment would create a vast inequity between individuals who are employees and those who are self‐employed. This would result in a situation where two individuals were at the same level of income but each would have a different ability to provide for their retirement. We will therefore not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Democrats' understanding that this amendment would deny tax deductibility for superannuation contributions above the SGC threshold. We strongly oppose this amendment. The threshold is the minimum amount of superannuation. The maximum amounts are set by the age benefit levels and the reasonable benefit limits. I think we could have an argument about those maximums. I think that, in the case of lump sums, they are often too high, but we do not think that reducing them to the SGC threshold is the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: For several years now in this place the Democrats have been criticising state governments for trying to reduce the benefits of public servants from the 10 to 12 per cent plus level of super provided in public sector schemes down to the SGC level. John Fahey did it, Jeff Kennett did it and Dean Brown, I understand, tried to do it as well. Earlier this year the federal government gave a strong signal that it too wanted to reduce public servant superannuation down to SGC levels. We oppose sending that as a reference to the Senate super committee and we will oppose any legislation which tries to do so, yet this amendment seeks to sanction this approach for the private sector and for government business enterprises. Senator Margetts seeks to assure us that this is only to stop salary packaging, but we think it goes further. It says to Telstra, to BHP, to the banks and to many white‐collar employers with super schemes paying above SGC, `Reduce your superannuation benefits.' We would not support that. We think it is a bad precedent to set.

If you want to make superannuation less attractive for high income earners as a salary packaging device, you need to reduce the excessive tax concessions that drive it. That is what this bill seeks to do. That is the better approach and that is why we will support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have some sympathy for the attempt by Senator Margetts on the issue of salary sacrifice. Indeed, we believe one of the problems with the government's approach on the so-called surcharge package will be some emerging problems as a consequence of the surcharge. History will tell us what the size of that effect will be.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a blunt approach by Senator Margetts. It does have some consequences which are of some concern to us. If it is blunt, Senator Allison, it is not much blunter than the package we have in front of us and all the unintended consequences that spill over from the package of seven bills we have been considering. For that reason and for the other reasons that have been outlined, we will not be supporting the amendment.
Amendment negatived.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to go back to the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge Imposition Bill 1997?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

The second amendment—clause 5, page 2 (line 22) to page 3 (line 4), omit subclause (3)—had an unintended consequence. Therefore, I do not think we need to proceed with it. If you wish to make a comment, Senator Sherry, I will check that my explanation has been satisfactory.

If Senator Allison's amendments have clearly negated the effect of paragraph (2) on sheet 473, then we are quite happy to leave it there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak against the third reading of this package of superannuation legislation. This provision to supposedly surcharge—now tax—high income earners who earn more than $70,000 a year was announced in the budget in August last year. What do we have in reality? We have in reality a package of legislation that is seriously flawed in a significant number of ways.

SPEECH.PARA: The government attempted to call this package of legislation a surcharge when the advice from everyone, including the government's own budget papers, indicated it was a tax. Why did the government call it a surcharge? Because they did not want to be seen to be breaching the fundamental commitment they gave at election time—no increase in existing taxes and no introduction of new taxes—so they called it a surcharge.

In an endeavour to avoid embarrassment on this new tax, the government went one crucial and important step further. They were requiring the superannuation funds to collect the tax. That in itself has led to a further range of significant problems.

It was the Treasurer himself who finally confessed, when denying constitutional problems with this new 15 per cent tax, that it was actually based on the 15 per cent tax that applies when superannuation moneys are paid into superannuation. He admitted that his justification for the constitutionality of this surcharge, as he called it up to that time, was that it was based on an existing tax.

All the advice we have received from a Federal Court judge, from Mr Rose QC, from all the tax accounting, legal and superannuation experts, is that it is a tax and that it fundamentally breaches the commitment given by the Liberal and National parties at the last election and the solemn promise the Prime Minister gave that there be would no introduction of new taxes and no increase in existing taxes. It is a $½ billion new tax in the forward estimates, supposedly to be collected from higher income earners.

That is fundamentally wrong in principle. And it is fundamentally wrong in principle to call it a surcharge and not a tax even today, despite the budget papers and everyone else in the community calling it a tax. With even the Treasurer admitting that it is a tax and even Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer, referring to it as a tax in a PM interview, there is still one person who refuses to call it a tax—and that is the Prime Minister. To this day, he still refuses to call a spade a spade and a tax a tax when it is clearly a tax. It is pleasing to see—to that extent anyway—that that is what the Senate has called it.

By calling it a surcharge and collecting it indirectly through superannuation funds, a whole host of problems have arisen from this new measure. One is that the government cannot apply it to all Australians who earn more than $70,000. They cannot apply it to the states, to state politicians, judges and other state public servants, because they called it a surcharge and not a tax. The government would not be taxing those people directly because they cannot tax the states directly.

The government has had to exempt serving judges and has to rely on the states agreeing—and we have no agreement from any state yet—to somehow collect the tax that results from this package of legislation from those state employees. We are not confident that that is going to occur. The government has no agreement. It is now May; this provision was announced last August.

We believe that what will emerge is two classes of employees. There will be an extraordinary tax that taxes Commonwealth employees and private sector employees earning more than $70,000 a year—with the exception of judges—but it will not tax the same class of employees working for state governments. That would be an extraordinary application of a tax. We certainly cannot recall any other tax that applies in that way to Australians.

BREAK.PARA: There are constitutional problems and significant legal questions that still remain over the legislation we have considered in the Senate over the last week. Initially, we had a view from Mr Rose QC that the legislation was unconstitutional because of clause 34. The government said, `No, no problem, no worry. It is constitutional.' Treasurer Costello, Prime Minister Howard and Assistant Treasurer Kemp were all in the media reassuring everyone there was not a problem; it was all constitutional and there was no problem with clause 34. And what happened? A few weeks later the government rushed amendments in to the House of Representatives to take care of that problem—it believes it has taken care of it; it may have created a whole series of other legal problems as a result of what they have done—to remove clause 34.

Then, only a fortnight ago, we had strong criticism from Justice Davies, a serving Federal Court judge, as to the constitutionality of the amended package that we have considered. That criticism went to the potential problem that this package of legislation does not cover existing federal politicians or existing federal judges. That is a severe problem.

It would be absurd and ridiculous if this legislation is found not to apply to existing politicians, and yet we may face that as the minimum of constitutional problems that arise from this package of legislation. Justice Davies and indeed a number of other legal experts have put a question mark over the whole package of legislation. So the whole legislation may fall over at some future date.

The further problem that has emerged is the collection mechanism, because the government is refusing to call it a tax and is collecting it indirectly through the superannuation funds who do not have the tax file numbers to identify who earns more than or less than $70,000. If they called it a tax and applied it directly, the government would not have that problem but no, it has to be applied indirectly. By the government doing it that way, there would have been and there still will be a significant number of people earning less than $70,000 who will be caught in the tax net.

Initially, the government's approach was to hold up its hands and say that nobody who earns less than $70,000 need be caught by this tax, knowing full well that the funds do not have the tax file numbers and that the tax will apply automatically to anyone who does not provide a tax file number. We know through experience with the superannuation industry that the number of people who do not provide tax file numbers will be very significant indeed; there will be people who have to pay this tax at the full 15 per cent rate who earn less than $70,000.

There is also the issue of what happens when a worker is made redundant. The government's definition of income included eligible termination payments, leave, and such things as retention bonuses that the military receive. There were significant problems with the definition of income and the application of this new tax to people earning less than $70,000 in a redundancy situation.

We also have the problem that even today, actuaries, who are expected to provide advice in the case of defined benefit funds, cannot provide detailed advice to individuals about what their new tax liability will be. There are hundreds of thousands of persons in defined benefit funds in that situation. It is not good enough that some nine months after the budget, individuals still cannot be advised by actuaries—I do not blame the actuaries—of the extent of their tax liability.

I have touched briefly on all of the issues that we have highlighted in this debate and over the last nine months since the announcement of this measure. But there are two particular inequities that Labor will not accept under any circumstances. This measure purportedly, supposedly, is to tax high income earners, but the result will not be a tax just against high income earners. In part, we have dealt with people who are low and middle income earners earning less than $33,000 a year.

But the amendment that has been passed does not go far enough; it does not exempt lower and middle income earners who have a new fund after 7 May. Lower and middle income earners will be taxed if they do not provide tax file numbers. Given that there were one million superannuation accounts in the last year for which we were able to obtain statistics, there will still be a significant number of lower and middle income earners caught by this new tax despite the best endeavours of the tax office and the superannuation funds, which will be going through a very costly process to try to collect the tax file numbers.

The second fundamental principle was the issue of what happens to a worker who is made redundant. Some of our suggested amendments—for example, excluding leave from the definition of income—were accepted. But eligible termination payments were not. There are many workers who are paid in the form of an ETP, in addition to what is defined as a bona fide redundancy pay. There are many workers in that situation who will be caught by this new tax. That amendment did not go the whole way to addressing this second fundamental concern that Labor has with this package of legislation. Accordingly, we will be voting against the third reading of what we see as a grossly unfair tax measure.

To conclude, I might say there have been a number of undesirable side effects as a consequence of the Liberal government's announcement in the budget last year and the debate that surrounded this legislation. I know that Senator Kemp wants to attribute to me all the blame for the debate that has occurred over the last nine months. I only wish I had that sort of influence, Senator Kemp; I certainly do not.

Over the last nine months there has been a very extensive debate about the future of superannuation. One of the detrimental side effects is a lessening of confidence in superannuation, not just among high income earners making more than $70,000 but a questioning by people who earn less than $70,000 about the value of superannuation. They say to Labor, `The government has changed the goalposts on this issue. Why should we believe them? Why won't they change the goalposts again in the same way that they changed the goalposts in deeming superannuation at age 55?' They changed the goalposts then. There were significant complaints from the broader community about the change of the goalposts in that area. In the same way, I am sure many people will complain that this government committed itself to a promise to pay a further three per cent into all Australian workers' superannuation accounts and we know that they will break that promise tomorrow night.

So we have three very significant changes with respect to superannuation. A new tax will hit not just the defined higher income earners earning more than $70,000 but a significant number of people earning less than $70,000—lower and middle income earners. There are also two million people in this country earning between $35,000 and $70,000 a year. We have the fundamental effect of this surcharge package. We have the deeming of superannuation, when a person turns 55, coming in on 20 September and we will have tomorrow night's announcements.All the surveys that I have seen—and I saw one last week—show there is very significant confusion and growing concern among Australians about the future of superannuation and what people will ultimately collect when they retire.

The government's approach on this tax measure has been to say, `We will consult.' But, fundamentally, they have not listened. It is not just my voice in the media complaining about the particular problems of this new tax. We have had a whole range of media commentators—economic commentators, journalists, tax lawyers, actuaries, accountants and superannuation funds—expressing their concern about this measure.

We know that this measure is set to pass the Senate. That does not please Labor. We believe, for the reasons that we have outlined, that this is fundamentally bad legislation. It does not address the particular principles that have been raised that we sought to have addressed. It leaves a whole range of question marks over the outcome that will develop in the next year or two as a consequence of this legislation passing into law.

There will be millions of letters sent out by the tax office and by superannuation funds to millions of taxpayers in this country. The significant cost of that alone will have to be borne by every member of a superannuation fund. Lower and middle income earners and higher income earners will all have to bear the cost of that. Whether it be $50 million, $100 million or more, it is a significant cost.

To what end? The higher income earners who are supposed to be hit by this measure alone will not be, and I have dealt with that matter.
