Many of those higher income earners who have the discretion to put that money into superannuation are repackaging. Yet the tax office advises us that they do not believe one dollar will be lost as a consequence of higher income earners repackaging. All the anecdotal evidence and the advice we have been given is that such repackaging will occur. We could have the ironical situation and the perverse situation and the quite wrongful situation that more tax is collected from people earning less than $70,000 than from those earning more than $70,000—more tax collected from more people.

History will tell us whether that is an accurate assessment. History will tell us whether the estimates of the extra administrative costs are in the range of $50 million or $100 million all up. History will tell us about the effect on low and middle income earners and those others earning less than $70,000. History will tell us whether the states legislate to collect this new tax. History will tell us whether redundant workers and a significant number of lower and middle income earners are hit through ETPs. History will tell us in the next year or two whether this package of legislation is struck down because of its lack of constitutionality in respect of either judges and federal politicians or every category of employee. History will tell us that.

One thing that history has already told us is that you cannot trust the Liberal Party with superannuation. You cannot trust this government with superannuation. Every action they have taken, every law they have attempted to enact in respect of superannuation since they came to government, has had the effect of wrecking superannuation, wrecking confidence and wrecking the final payout from workers' superannuation. Unfortunately, that trend will again be highlighted and continued in the budget tomorrow night.

Labor is proud of its record on superannuation. It is proud that it has established superannuation for all in this country. It is proud that we are moving towards nine per cent superannuation contributions. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support in principle this bill, this whole initiative. I remind the Senate that it has been for many years that we have done so. We have argued for reforms of what is, in effect, $7 billion worth of tax breaks on superannuation, and most of those tax breaks have flowed to high income earners. The 15 per cent tax on super contributions gives a high income earner in the top 48 per cent tax bracket a 33c in the dollar tax break, but a worker on $20,000 gets a tax break of just 6c in the dollar. So we think this legislation goes some way to address that question which has so favoured high income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that we are interested in the fact that the ALP, having failed to address this question, is now proposing to vote against the third reading of this bill. We would, of course, have preferred an alternative collection mechanism, and we have said so on every possible occasion. This is a tax and, if it had been collected as a tax, a lot of those problems which will arise from this collection method would have been alleviated.

Senators Harradine and Sherry might be right in terms of the constitutional issues and other administrative problems which have been raised, but we take the view that the government has to wear that. The government will need to address those issues as they arise, and so it should.

We sought successfully to bring about changes to the bill which will protect low income workers. We have done that without opening up this bill to abuse and to tax avoidance. So, whilst this bill is not perfect by a long shot and it is not how we would have framed up the legislation, I indicate that the Democrats will support this bill in its current form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens quite clearly indicated that it is very rare that we do see governments moving to get a fairer tax take from the rich in society who can afford to provide a greater contribution at a time when we are seeing that there is a push to reduce taxes in general. Governments are using that as an excuse to reduce services provided to often the most vulnerable in our society, and we get an increased user-pays scenario in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens are opposed to this direction in which we are going. Therefore, we are concerned that any moves to oppose the bill in general will be used as an excuse in the future for the government to say, `Look, we made an effort to take more from those people who can afford it to contribute to tax revenue, and the Senate opposed it.'

However, I have to say that the Senate did come up with some very useful suggestions in relation to making this fairer. It was not really possible to make it a reasonable collection method. The bill was not set out as a reasonable collection method. Of course, the best way would have been for the Senate to decide as a majority that the bill should have gone back and should have been reworked over altogether. However, although there was a lot of support for that in the Senate, that approach was not supported by the Democrats. So we have been left with trying to fix up what is, in fact, an appallingly constructed bill.

There were other opportunities to improve this bill in relation to actually looking at fairness for those people who do not earn anything near $70,000. What we have ended up with is a mishmash of halfways. The only reason that mishmash has occurred is that the amendments of the ALP and some of our amendments did not get that support. In fact, the government ended up agreeing to other halfway measures.

What we have is a badly constructed bill because, unfortunately, the Democrats allowed it to happen. Unfortunately the bill has not been improved or brought up by the bootstraps in relation to issues. It is a bill that has been made a lot worse than it needed to be. That is very sad in relation to the way the Senate is currently moving at the moment.

It is with great regret that I say we will still be supporting the bill. Those who realise how bad the bill is, compared with the fact it could have been a lot better, know who they are and know who is responsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —All the issues have been extensively canvassed in this debate and in the period leading up to the debate. These are measures about equity and about fairness. I have to say that one of the most interesting developments that has come out in this debate is the fact that the Labor Party has finally revealed its true colours.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party indicated with a lot of fanfare that it sought to back out from its leader's commitment to support the 15 per cent surcharge. Make no doubt about it: Mr Beazley indicated that the Labor Party would be supportive of the 15 per cent surcharge. What do we have today? Senator Sherry backing out. The modern Labor Party is not about equity; it is not about fairness. The modern Labor Party was worried about some of its mates. The Labor Party succumbed to pressure. At the end of the day, the Labor Party will not be supporting this measure, which is about equity and fairness.

I again put on the record that I believe that no Labor Party in Australian history would have opposed such a measure, which is about fairness and which is about equity. It says a lot about the modern Labor Party. They have refused to support a measure which will reduce the tax concessions available to those on higher incomes. Even Senator Sherry indicated that the test was whether we could avoid imposing it on low and middle income concerns. I indicated that the government had taken major steps to make sure it was not imposed on low and middle income earners. Senator Allison's amendment further reinforces that. But, in the end, Senator Sherry decided that the Labor Party would, I think, very strangely—and given the historical perspective of what one would have expected a Labor party to do—not support this measure.

The issues regarding low and middle income earners have been effectively addressed. They were effectively addressed by the government. To the extent that there was any concern, they have been buttressed further by the amendment moved by the Democrats. Labor's attempt, in its support for the privi leges which are being given to higher income earners, to hide behind the pretence that low and middle income earners were going to be affected has been revealed as the utterly specious argument which was presented.

As I said, this was an important part of the last budget. It was one of the reasons why this budget was accepted as a fair budget. The government has always intended to proceed with it. We have consulted widely. Senator Sherry keeps on raising the approach or mechanism in relation to the way it has been collected. We have extensively covered that. Senator Sherry was never able to put forward any other option which was a workable option. This is a workable option. Compared to any other measure that Senator Sherry was able to put forward, it is a far more simple measure. I might say that this debate on surcharges and taxes, Senator Sherry, fools nobody.
It is interesting that Senator Sherry is so anxious—and I recognise the numbers in the Senate regarding the surcharge tax debate—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are accepting it is a tax?

—No, we don't. In relation to the amendment which was put, there were amendments put through. Senator, there is an irony here that your party was utterly opposed to the election commitments that this government made in relation to two major central issues: the workplace reform bill and Telstra. Of course you attempted every way you possibly could to defeat those clear election promises. Make no mistake about that. Your attempting to change the word from `surcharge' to `tax' and then pretending that this is a broken promise will fool nobody, let me tell you.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly support the third reading of these important bills. They are major budget measures. Once these bills have been passed, we look forward to this very fair measure being imposed.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the bills be now read a third time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present documents from the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Parer), pursuant to the order of the Senate of 7 May 1997, and I seek leave to incorporate two brief statements relating to the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statements read as follows—
Tabling of Documents covered by Senator Brown's motion of 7 May 1997 regarding the North Forest Products `degraded forest licence'.
. In considering which of the documents sought by Senator Brown's should be tabled I have been guided by the exemption provisions of the Freedom of Information Act.
. I have therefore decided not to table:
‐ documents which would be privileged from production in legal proceedings on the grounds of legal professional privilege;
‐ documents affecting the personal privacy of individuals or that could be reasonably regarded as commercial in confidence;

‐ a small number of internal working documents, including electronic versions of primary data sources collected as part of the Tasmania comprehensive regional assessment that are subject to a data agreement with the Tasmania government, whose release I do not consider to be in the public interest; and
‐ Cabinet related correspondence between Ministers.
. In addition, I have not included electronic mail messages not kept in hard copy due to the time and resources required to retrieve such documents.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Honourable John Anderson MP, has provided the documents held by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy relevant to his consideration of the application by North Forest Products for a degraded forest licence to export hardwood woodchips sourced from its Surrey Hills Estate, to facilitate an acceleration of its plantation establishment program. The minister has advised me that in providing these documents, he has sought to respect matters of commercial confidentiality, legal privilege and Cabinet‐related correspondence between Ministers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

These documents have been elicited from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, and the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, and relate to the issuing of a woodchip licence that is leading to the destruction of pure rainforest in Tasmania. The licence has ostensibly been issued under new government regulations that allow for so‐called `degraded forests' to be woodchipped and exported under the pen of those two ministers. Environmentalists have pointed out that advisers to the government itself noted that these forests in north‐west Tasmania, on the Surrey Hills estate of North Forest Products, are in fact forests where the ecosystems are essentially intact—there has not been an invasion of weeds and feral animals or destruction by fire. Their report to the government pointed out that these forests are floristically intact.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CAMPBELL

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I did give leave to Senator Brown to take note of some documents I have tabled. I would ask that Senator Brown make his comments relevant to those documents. Since the documents were only tabled something like less than a minute ago, I do not know how Senator Brown can make his comments relevant to the documents because he cannot have read them. He cannot have read one paragraph, one sentence or one word of those documents. I would suggest that it is an important issue that Senator Brown wants to talk about. But, on the concept of seeking to have documents tabled by way of return to order, which is the Senate ordering documents from the government, which we have tabled at the earliest occasion possible, if you are going to take the process seriously, you might actually bother to read the documents before you seek to debate them or take note of them.

INTERJECT.PARA: Could I further say that the public servants, in particular, who have worked for many hours to prepare these documents for the Senate might also deserve the respect of Senator Brown in actually having Senator Brown read them prior to debating them. I would put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that Senator Brown's comments are not relevant to the documents and cannot be relevant because he has not read one word or one sentence of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: the point is, of course, that I am leading very quickly to the reason why the Senate should be noting these documents, why they have been tabled in the Senate and the importance of them.

—On the point of order, I note that Senator Brown was given leave, but I am listening very carefully to his comments. I would ask him to bring his comments directly to the documents which, of course, have only just been tabled.

—The point I was leading to is that, despite the government's objections and its vote against the tabling of these documents, it has been essential that the Senate—and it has been a good move by the Senate—has insisted that the ministers table all the documents that they took into consideration when coming up with this remarkable and, on the face of it, paradoxical decision to allow North Broken Hill to woodchip and export, in tatters, intact rainforest under the banner of degraded forest. It is a very serious matter and I will be—and I am sure other senators will be—looking at these documents to try to find out what on earth possessed the ministers to make that decision.

—I raise a point of order. Senator Brown is not speaking to the motion, which is to take note of the documents. He is actually speaking to some other motion, which is to say that senators should perhaps take note of the documents. I, too, urge all senators to take note of the document, Madam Acting Deputy President, but I also urge you to suggest to Senator Brown that he is totally outside standing orders. I doubt that he could get within standing orders until he has bothered to take the time to read the documents, which he has not read. I say that he should at least show some respect to the minister and the public servants who have spent so many hours preparing these documents by spending a few minutes of his own time reading them before he wastes the time of the Senate in trying to move some spurious motion to take note of a document he has not read even one single word of.
—I am advised that relevance is a matter here, Senator Brown, and I would ask you to ensure that you are keeping within the standing orders by being relevant.

—Thank you. The government, no doubt, is very brittle about the contents of these documents. It did not want to produce them, but I will be looking at them carefully. I recommend that the other senators do the same.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks on this on 29 May at the appropriate time when the documents have been considered and, following Senator Campbell's remarks, I have no doubt he will be supporting that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot grant leave for some future date. I am sure the Senate will consider Senator Brown's seeking leave on 29 May.
—I am advised, Senator Campbell, that it is simply the same as an adjournment.
—I am quite happy to agree to an adjournment.

BREAK.XREF: RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the succeeding provisions of this resolution having effect.

(2) That the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1997, the Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 and the Retirement Savings Accounts Supervisory Levy Bill 1996 be recommitted, and that consideration of the bills in committee of the whole be an order of the day for a later hour.

(3) That the committee consider the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1997 as read a second time and the Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 and the Retirement Savings Accounts Supervisory Levy Bill 1996 as reported by the committee of the whole on 25 March 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the motion in relation to the recommittal of retirement savings accounts bills. There is no necessity for this when the government say they have a very close timetable for getting through their bills that they want to get through. They are still working on other issues that they say the Senate must work on quickly. This bill has been dealt with in the Senate and it was voted on. The vote of the Senate was that it was not good enough and was not supportable.

SPEECH.PARA: I am going to be firmly opposing this motion of the government because the bill has been dealt with. We will be seeing, if we get pushed into debating this bill unnecessarily, that what we have is not a lot better. What we have is the Senate's time being wasted again, but perhaps in fact we are going to get a bad bill through at a time when the government says we are short of time—a bill that we have dealt with before which should not be coming up again.

Surely the government can take the umpire's decision, but it might well be that the reason we are having to deal with this is that we are getting a bad bill marginally improved. That sounds like the workplace relations bill: an atrocious bill marginally improved instead of allowing a majority of the Senate to clearly say that the bill was not good enough. As far as I can see, it is still not good enough, and yet we are being asked here to agree to a motion to recommit a bill that has been dealt with in the Senate. Certainly, you do not have my support on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor does not oppose the recommittal. I share all the sentiments that Senator Margetts has outlined and we will be making some comments when we reconsider this package of legislation. I think the important point that should be made on the recommittal is that there is a government‐Democrat deal on this package of legislation. It does not meet our fundamental principles. However, we will argue that on the issues. I will flag to the government we will not be arguing to the same extent we did on the previous occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want me to? Keep interjecting if you want me to argue. Senator Kemp or Senator Campbell, do you want us to move every amendment and fight it out to the end?
—I would prefer not to, Senator Sherry.

—Thank you. I am pleased to see there are more responsible heads on the government side. We have indicated to the government we are not opposing the recommittal. When the legislation comes back before the Senate the numbers are a fait accompli; the legislation will pass. We do not agree with that legislation. In order to save the time of the Senate, we intend not to move our amendments that we moved on a previous occasion. We will address some issues of some concern to us vis‐a‐vis the Democrat amendments and we will have our say at that point in time.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —As we all know, the Senate considered this bill in the last session and only two of the several dozen amendments moved by the ALP, the Democrats and Senator Harradine were passed by the Senate. None of these was supported by the government, so the Senate denied the bill a third reading. In both of my speeches during the second and third reading stages I made it quite clear that the Democrats supported the introduction of an RSA but the conditions in the draft bill simply failed the test of fairness.

SPEECH.PARA: The morning after the bill was voted down Senator Kernot and I were invited to meet with the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and Senator Kemp. The same government which for weeks would not talk about amending the bill, which had voted against every amendment that was put and which had ignored the recommendations of the Senate committee, then decided to accept that some of our amendments had merit. Over the past five weeks we have liaised with the government and I am pleased to report to the chamber that the government has been responsive to each of the major issues which we raised.

The amendments that I will move today will replace the amendments I moved during the last sitting. Some of these are very similar. I am not proceeding with some of the amendments because the issues have been dealt with in some other way. The issues were addressed in detail when we last discussed the bill and I intend to keep my comments to very brief statements on each amendment as we go through.

I will not be moving amendments to deal with information to be provided to RSA holders on the health warning because we believe these matters are dealt with now quite adequately in the draft regulations prepared by Senator Kemp. The Democrats have given the government some comments on those regulations. I would seek assurance from Senator Kemp that the government will favourably consider those comments and ensure that the issues we have raised are adequately dealt with. I move:
(1) Clause 38, page 29 (after line 6), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (3) Regulations made in accordance with paragraph (2)(i) must further the objective of ensuring that RSAs are a low-cost product.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to ensure that regulation issued to set operating standards for RSAs must further the objective of ensuring that RSAs are a low‐cost product. This amendment had the support of the ALP, the Greens and Senator Harradine. I am pleased that the government has now decided to add its support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking to this first amendment, the Greens position was that there should be no fees. I could check that but I do not believe our position was that there should be fees.

SPEECH.PARA: The reintroduction of the retirement savings accounts bills is a rather contemptuous act. The government brought these bills in last session and faced strong criticism generally over a number of issues. It received this criticism both in the committee and in this chamber. Ultimately, the government decided to use its numbers and ignore every bit of that criticism as contained in the amendments. Unfortunately, it did not understand the numbers and the implications of denying legitimate concerns, so the bill was defeated.

At the time it might have been able to get the bill through by addressing at least the worst aspects of the legislation. They may have been able to get a senator or two on side but they did not do so. Instead, they treated the concerns raised by the Senate with such contempt that in the end the bill was defeated. The government had the numbers to stop every amendment because, in the case of a tied vote, an amendment is lost. However, it did not have the numbers to actually pass the bill.

It seems, however, that in the non-sitting period the government went to the Democrats and said, `We will make a few cosmetic changes so you can claim to have improved another awful bill.' On that issue, I would like to say plainly that the Democrats cannot in any way claim as a win a bill that might have got through if improvements had been made. We are now dealing with a bill that was defeated.

The Democrats are responsible for a Lazarus act having raised this bill from the dead. They, therefore, are solely responsible for every flaw in this bill that survives. It was dead and only lives again by their grace. They cannot claim that the government had them over a barrel and it was a tough negotiation. The government in fact had no leverage on this one and they therefore must take responsibility for every single rotten item that survives in this bill. In any case, our position remains the same. We do not like the retirement savings accounts and see no reason for them. There is no advantage for anyone but the banking industry. We do and will oppose these bills.

We continue to have specific and strenuous objections to several issues, the main one being any situation where a default option for workers is something other than superannuation. I oppose totally the situation where an employer can decide an employee will enter into an RSA. I do not believe the amendments before us totally deal with this.

I oppose totally a situation where there is any difficulty for an employee to transfer to a superannuation fund and have their employer honour that choice. I strongly dislike a system, whatever cautions are included, where the employer can put an employee in a RSA even when the employee can opt to go for a superannuation fund. This is not choice. This is allowing employers to skew the system towards banks and towards a retirement savings option that brings low returns for employees.

Superannuation funds produce better performance for virtually any employee. One might say that there are other better options which produce a better performance than superannuation funds, but that choice seems to have taken away from us a couple of years ago. I could accept a situation where the retirement fund contributions of all employees were placed into a superannuation fund unless the employees specifically asked to have them in an RSA. I could see a situation where only a specific request directly from an employee, separate from any other signed document, would result in an employer depositing an employee's money into an RSA.

I would like to see the employee nominate the RSA if they chose to belong to one. I would like to see the situation law where if there is no signature or specific request initiated by the employee, separate to anything in general employment or conditions of employment agreements, it always means that the employee wants to be in a superannuation fund.

I agreed to some of the Democrat amendments last time, including to clause 15, because the ALP amendments were opposed and, if the bill was to get up, it seemed preferable to have a clause that would at least require an employer to offer superannuation membership along with any offer of a RSA. I am not quite so disposed to support this as the price to allow this bill to pass.

I clearly reject the right of an employer to influence in any way the membership of an employee in a retirement savings account. An offer can be made in coercive ways or set up in ways that result in them being accepted if there is a lack of thought or sufficient examination of the material and options. Those people who do not think coercion exists in the workplace have a lot to learn.

There may have been some Democrat amendments that I would still support if the ALP amendments were to have been put up, but it seems that they are not going to be. Those were the ones that amplify the ALP amendments rather than substitute for them. That would indicate that there is not a lot of point in window dressing. I would, for example, have supported measures to ensure that employees are not only given accurate information about performance and investment portfolios of RSAs but also information that contains specific cautions about the low returns and the drawbacks of such accounts. I would like to have seen RSAs take on a trustee‐like duty in relation to members and ethical options offered as alternatives within a bank.

On the whole, I had intended to support the ALP amendments if they had put them again. There is also an amendment from Senator Harradine which I will support. As the ALP amendments will not be put up, I do not intend to support watered down versions of amendments put by the Democrats and potentially drafted by the government so that this bill can be raised from the dead. If the government wants these amendments, let them vote for them and make the situation here quite clear. Regardless of any amendments, I will still be opposing this bill. I do not think there are any real advantages to consumers—any advantages are mainly to banks—to be gained by having retirement savings accounts legislated in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment of the Democrats and the government that we are currently considering relates to the regulation of RSAs as a low cost product. I will make a few comments about that shortly. Firstly, Labor's fundamental concerns about RSAs as a product were extensively canvassed prior to Easter when we debated this legislation. We moved a range of amendments to address those fundamental concerns. With very few exceptions, those amendments were not accepted by the Senate and by the government. As Senator Margetts has indicated, the government discovered it had the votes of half the Senate to not have our amendments passed but it did not have a majority to pass the legislation at the end of the debate on the third reading.

SPEECH.PARA: We have since examined the package of amendments that have come from the government and Democrat negotiations over the last few weeks. Without exception, they water down, where they deal with the protections that we sought to build into retirement savings accounts, the significant concerns and the range of amendments that Labor proposed to this legislation on the last occasion. It is regrettable that the Democrats have seen fit to succumb to the government's pressure with respect to watering down the amendments. Many of the amendments that they are supporting as part of this deal today they did not support on the previous occasion. This retirement savings legislation does not involve any change to the bottom line of the budget. So the Democrats have not even got the excuse that the government will be forgoing revenue as a consequence of the defeat that they received prior to Easter.

As I remarked earlier, the Labor opposition could go back and move all of its amendments. In light of the legislative pressure and time constraints that are on the Senate, that would be an irresponsible approach given that there is a locked in deal between the govern ment and the Democrats. So one by one we will address the Democrat amendments that are being moved and indicate relatively briefly what our concerns are about those amendments.

The specific amendment that we are dealing with here relates to the regulation of RSAs as a low cost product. Senator Margetts is correct; her recollection of amendments that went to the fees and charges that could be made with respect to RSAs—which she supported, Labor supported and, as I recall, the Democrats supported on the last occasion—was that it should be a no fees and charge product, not a low cost product, whatever that will mean. It should be a no fees and charge product, because this is a low return product. It is a guaranteed low return product.

There is no doubt, no argument, no disagreement that money in RSAs will return a lower interest rate over the longer term than traditional superannuation products. Why should RSAs, in those circumstances, be subject to low fees and charges—whatever that means in the context of bank fees and charges? There is significant community concern about what exactly is meant by a low cost product with respect to RSAs and, indeed, any fees and charges that are applied by banks. From my discussions with the banking industry, they recognise that it is a significant concern in the community.

Banks have always argued—some more strenuously than others—that they need access to superannuation money. That is a fundamentally flawed argument. They have access, through their wholesale management arms, to significant proportions of superannuation savings in this country. Indeed, many of the banks have very successfully accessed, in the wholesale market, superannuation savings in this country. But fundamentally, what banks want is a retirement savings account similar in nature to the old savings account—a passbook product. It is a product that, for a range of reasons, most consumers lock themselves into for a long period of time with a low rate of return.

The banks, very successfully of course, use the significant amounts of capital accumula tion through those passbook type accounts. In many ways, retirement savings accounts represent a similar approach by a number of the banks—lock in low return savings for as long as possible. In fact RSAs as superannuation accounts lock in the money much more closely to the banks than ever the traditional passbook type account was able to do.

In the last 10 years or so, if passbook type savings had any virtue, it did have non‐existent or extremely low fee and charges. But, of course, that era of the banks has passed. We are talking about workers' retirement savings that will inevitably be locked into these products for a long period of time—not necessarily by virtue of the regulatory regime that surrounds RSAs but by the inertia of a majority in the superannuation market not understanding that fundamental distinction between RSAs, a low return product, and the type of return their product would attract in other superannuation products.

I cannot believe the naivety of people who put forward the argument that, `Yes, the customer will be informed; they will transfer their money into a higher return product.' Why would a bank want to actively pursue that course when customers are a part of a low return product? The bank fundamentally will want to keep that money there for as long as possible. The comments that I have made are but a brief overview of the issue relating to fees and charges and RSAs being a low cost product—whatever that means—in the context of the agreement between the government and the Democrats.

We do not trust this government on superannuation. We do not trust the fundamental changes they have made and will announce tomorrow night in the budget with respect to superannuation. It will add to cost, to fees and charges and, inevitably, to a lower level of savings in superannuation and a lower return and to a lower retirement outcome for Australians. That is our fundamental bottom line.

What does surprise me is that the government has not learnt from the experience of retirement savings account products in the United Kingdom. I do know that the government has in part modelled the concept and the principle of its legislation on what has occur red in the United Kingdom with respect to personal superannuation products. In the United Kingdom we do know that the individual superannuation products, under the then conservative government of Prime Minister Thatcher, encouraged people—through a variety of measures, including `incentives'—to take out these individual account type products. As a result, well in excess of a million consumers in the United Kingdom were ripped off, and that is not putting it too emotionally or too simply.

The studies that have occurred of these individual savings retirement vehicles in the United Kingdom show that well over a million people are going to have to be compensated because of the fees and charges that were made in respect of these individual superannuation savings vehicles. This government, in its ideological zeal, not learning from the conservative governments of the United Kingdom, has decided to repeat to a significant degree that approach in this country.

Labor started from the initial position that if there could be adequate safeguards built around retirement savings accounts we would accept the concept. That is why we moved our amendments on the previous occasion. We do not believe that on these amendments the safeguards are adequate and meet the minimum principle in respect of fees and charges that we put forward on the last occasion. We do not accept this particular proposal of the Democrats and the government. We do not agree with it. We know it is futile to move the amendments we moved on the previous occasion.

I note that in this area the Democrats did give support, but they have since done a retreat. I think, in the context of this issue, the overall package the Democrats have reached in respect of the government does not provide sufficient safeguards for individuals in respect of retirement savings accounts. We will obviously touch on and develop some of those issues as we move through the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the ALP is now taking a very hardline position on this issue of fees and charges. I did say that this was a fall‐back position of ours. It is true that we would have preferred there to be no fees and charges; however, I remind the opposition that nowhere in their recommendations from the Senate committee was there a mention of fees and charges. I wonder why it is that the opposition is now seeing fit to be so hard line on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We did pick up this suggestion from the credit unions, as I understand it, during the hearing. That is why we put it forward. However, since that time we have talked not just with the government but also with other consumer groups. I have to inform the committee that there is acceptance out there amongst those advocacy and consumer groups of the position we are now taking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be supporting the amendments the Democrats have moved. I will make a few brief preliminary comments. About 40 minutes ago we were subjected to a lecture from Senator Margetts about broken promises. The introduction of RSAs is an election promise of the coalition government. You, who incorrectly argued that we were breaking a promise, should bear in mind that the reason we are bringing this back is that it was an election promise. We believe there is room for such a product and we have long argued that in previous debates.

SPEECH.PARA: It is correct that, with the failure of the bills through the Senate, the government sat down and was prepared to constructively negotiate with all groups to see whether we could reach accommodation. We recognised, of course, that the government needed in some areas, in order to secure passage for the bills, to see whether we could reach particular accommodation with various other interests. That offer was made to you, Senator. We were comfortable to discuss it with the Labor Party. Although I can see a shaking head, that is not my memory of the conversation.

We have always said that RSAs are to be a low‐cost product and the amendment moved by Senator Allison states that `regulations made in accordance with paragraph (2)(i) must further the objective of ensuring that RSAs are a low‐cost product'. In a sense, this confirms the government's clear objective and will clarify the policy objective of the regulation making power.

These amendments will ensure that the power to regulate RSAs' fees is for the purpose of ensuring that the objective of a low‐cost product is met. This is, of course, as I have said, entirely consistent with the objective of the government on this matter. Draft regulations have been made available and if people have comments on those we will always enter into those negotiations in a constructive fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am forced to rise here and ask the minister to clearly identify which promise I was asking him to keep. Through the debate on superannuation, there was a very clear speech that when governments make rotten promises we are the last party to require you to keep them. Minister, if you are going to say that 40 minutes ago I was exhorting you to keep your election promise, perhaps you would like to let the committee know which particular promise I was exhorting you to keep. I think you picked the wrong person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of brief points. Firstly, Senator Allison draws our attention to the attitude of the credit unions in respect of fees and charges. As I recall, Senator, the evidence given by the credit unions to the Senate committee was that there should be no fees and charges in respect of RSA products. That is not what you are supporting here today. Secondly, Minister Kemp has referred to an election promise. The package of legislation we have before us is not consistent with your election promise, Minister, and it is not consistent with the copy of the cabinet submission that we have and will show you shortly. We will seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard at the appropriate time once you have considered your own government's cabinet‐in‐confidence document.

SPEECH.PARA: There are significant variations to RSAs in both your election promise and the cabinet‐in‐confidence recommendations which we have a copy of and will be pleased to show you. We are more than happy to have it incorporat ed in Hansard. There have been significant variations, and we can refer to those at the appropriate time in the debate. Once we have got a copy to you, we will seek the appropriate leave to have it incorporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am still waiting for an apology from the minister. I believe that, when a minister misleads the Senate in any way, they are required to stand up and acknowledge that as soon as that is possible. He is required either to tell the Senate what I said 40 minutes ago which was exhorting them to keep their promise, or apologise to the Senate. I am waiting for the apology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are very bad‐tempered, Senator. If I remember correctly, you were arguing that we had broken a promise in relation to the surcharge.
—No, I did not say that.
—You did not say that? Nothing in your speech in relation to the debate on surcharge and tax dealt with the issue that there was a broken promise? Is that right? Is that what you are saying?
—Give me the quote.

—It is going to be a real surprise to you, Senator. I do not think the copy of Hansard is available but, if you did not say that, of course I will withdraw the comment. But, on the other hand, if you did say that I expect you to stand up tomorrow and correct the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Heading to Part 5, page 33 (line 2), at the end of the heading, add "and employers".
(3) Heading to Division 3 of Part 5, page 37 (line 2), at the end of the heading, add "and applications for RSAs".
(4) Page 37 (after line 30), at the end of Division 3, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 51A Employers must provide employees with alternative options

SPEECH.PARA: (1) This section sets out the procedures that an employer must go through:

PARA.TAB: (a) if the employer gives an application form for an RSA to an employee; or
(b) before an employer makes an application for an RSA on behalf of an employee.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) An employer who gives an application form for an RSA to an employee must, at the same time, give the employee:

PARA.TAB: (a) any prescribed information about that RSA; and
(b) if the employee is paid by means of electronic funds transfer to a financial institution that is an RSA institution—an application form for an RSA provided by that RSA institution; and
(c) if there is an industry-based regulated superannuation fund that the employee is eligible to join‐an application form for that industry fund; and
(d) if there is no industry-based regulated superannuation fund that the employee is eligible to join—an application form for a regulated superannuation fund; and

(e) a written notice stating that, unless the employer is currently making contributions for the benefit of the employee to another RSA or to a regulated superannuation fund, the employer may make an application for the RSA on behalf of the employee if the employee does not, within 28 days:

TAB.TAB: (i) make an application for the RSA, for another RSA, or to become a member of a regulated superannuation fund; or
(ii) give the employer a written notice electing to become the holder of the RSA, the holder of another RSA or a member of a specified regulated superannuation fund.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) An employer must not make an application, on behalf of any particular employee, for an RSA unless the conditions in subsection (4) or (5) are satisfied.
(4) The conditions in this subsection for an employer to be able to make an application, on behalf of any particular employee, for an RSA are that:

PARA.TAB: (a) the employer has given the employee an application form for the RSA together with the other documents specified in subsection (2); and
(b) the 28 day period referred to in paragraph (2)(e) has ended; and
(c) the employee has not made an application for the RSA, for another RSA, or to become a member of a regulated superannuation fund; and
(d) the employee has not given the employer a written notice electing to become the holder of the RSA, the holder of another RSA or a member of a specified regulated superannuation fund; and
(e) the employer is not making contributions for the benefit of the employee to another RSA or to a regulated superannuation fund.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) The conditions in this subsection for an employer to be able to make an application, on behalf of any particular employee, for an RSA (the nominated RSA ) are that:

PARA.TAB: (a) the employer has given the employee an application form for an RSA (which may be the nominated RSA or another RSA) together with the other documents specified in subsection (2); and
(b) the employee has given the employer a written notice electing to become the holder of the nominated RSA.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) An employer who intentionally or recklessly contravenes subsection (2) or (3) is guilty of an offence punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding 10 penalty units.
(7) Where an employee has become the holder of an RSA as a result of:

PARA.TAB: (a) an application that was made using an application form provided by the employee's employer in contravention of subsection (2); or

(b) as a result of an application that was made by the employee's employer in contravention of subsection (3); the RSA provider must, at the request of the employee, transfer the balance in the RSA to another RSA, or a superannuation entity, specified by the employee. The request must be made within 6 months of the RSA being opened. The balance must be transferred as soon as is practicable. No exit fees may be imposed.

SPEECH.PARA: (8) An RSA provider who intentionally or recklessly contravenes subsection (7) is guilty of an offence punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding 10 penalty units.
(5) Clause 52, page 38 (lines 20 and 21), omit subclause (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) Subsection (1) does not apply if the application is made by an employer on behalf of an employee and the RSA provider is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that section 51A has been complied with

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 55, page 39 (line 26), after "sections", insert "51A,".

These amendments largely mirror amendments Nos. 15 to 17 which I moved at the last sitting and which were supported by the ALP, the Greens and Senator Harradine on that occasion. The amendments have been tidied and firmed up somewhat.

The operation of the amendment has the effect of ensuring that an employer cannot open an RSA on behalf of an employee unless the employee has been provided with application forms for the relevant industry super fund or, if there is no industry super fund, another superannuation fund and the RSA offered by their own bank. They will have 28 days in which to make up their minds before the employer can act.

This amendment also contains a significant change from my former amendment No. 15, in that the employer will not be allowed to open an RSA if they are already paying into a superannuation fund or RSA on behalf of the member. This additional requirement in 51A(4)(e) meets a key concern that has been raised by unions. I think it is a fair balance between providing employees with choice whilst also ensuring that employers are able to meet their superannuation guarantee legal obligations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question in respect of a particular provision. I think it was 51A(4)(e) that Senator Allison referred to. I note your comment—it was not an emphasis—on a new employee not paying into an existing account. Are you accepting, Senator Allison, that if an employee who starts work in a new job has an existing superannuation account, in those circumstances it is supposedly fair and reasonable for the employer to offer them an RSA when they already have an existing superannuation account, albeit they are not paying into it?

—In my opinion there is not a lot in these amendments that actually changes the fact that the employer still has the right under this legislation to take an employee's money and put it into RSAs. It is a technical change and a title change, but there is not a great deal of change in relation to the fact that, under this legislation, the employer still has the right to choose what happens to employees' money. The employer can put it into these low income bearing accounts and perhaps get a bit of a special deal for doing so. I do not think it improves the bill to any extent that it makes it acceptable.

—It is my understanding—I would be grateful if the government could confirm this—that, when an employee changes jobs, this does not necessarily oblige the new employer to send the contributions to the employee's existing super fund. That is not the case at present. There is no obligation on an employer to direct contributions to that employee's existing super fund. I believe that this makes no difference to the current situation in that respect.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, I have checked with my advisers and your understanding is correct. We will be supporting the amendments which the Democrats have moved. The amendments will ensure that employees have a choice before they are signed up to an RSA by employers. Employees can only be signed up to an RSA without their consent if, firstly, they are not a member of an existing superannuation fund and, secondly, if they do not express an alternative choice within 28 days. Otherwise employees will be given a range of options, including an RSA. They will have 28 days in which to express a choice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Who will arbitrate this issue in the event of a dispute over a person who claims that they are in an existing fund, have an existing account, and that they were coerced or pressured in some way by the employer into a particular product? Inevitably, these disputes will arise. Who is going to arbitrate?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —There cannot be any coercion. All of us would be utterly opposed to coercion. Certainly if there were an attempt at coercion, then that may be an industrial matter and may be taken up by the relevant unions. There is no acceptance by the government or anyone else around this chamber that there could be coercion.
—As I understand it, there is the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal, which I imagine would deal with this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an interesting position because we have a different position from the government and the Democrats as to who will arbitrate in the event of a dispute. It is all very well for Senator Kemp to say that there will be choice and there will be no coercion, but that is like saying there will be no theft. We all wish it would never happen, but we know to some extent it will.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp has said that presumably the industrial tribunals will determine this matter and Senator Allison has said the complaints tribunal will determine this matter. We would like to know which one it is going to be. In the course of considering this response, Senator Allison and Senator Kemp, is it proposed to leave superannuation as an industrial issue with the industrial commission? Senator Kemp obviously thinks it is because I assume he would not have given us this advice about industrial tribunals being involved if it were not going to be. We would like to know who is going to determine this particular problem.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised there would be a legal action under industrial relations law. It deals with employment. It would not go to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal until they became a member of a fund. At that stage it is simply a dispute between the employer and the employee.
—So it cannot go to the complaints tribunal?

—They are not a member of a fund. It is an industrial matter. We are all opposed to theft, Senator, and we are all opposed to the use of any coercion, but the mechanisms are there if people are forced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add to the debate a story I heard a couple of days ago—I am sure Senator Sherry has heard this, too. The story was of an employer who simply took money, which was, say, a superannuation deduction, and put it into an account under his own name. This, of course, was illegal.

SPEECH.PARA: The only reason the employee knew that they needed to get help and get help quickly was that they knew they had not filled out a form. They knew that the employer could not take their money and put it into a superannuation fund unless they had filled out a form. Hence there was a trigger to enable this employee to know they needed help. They were able to get help because there was obviously proof. They then were able to follow through the investigation.

How is the minister going to be able to deal with the fact that there may well be employers who, through ignorance or worse, believe that it is right to deduct money and put it into perhaps a retirement savings account under their own name? How long would it take before the employee might know that this had happened?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, I think you are asking whether there would be coercion. The attitude is, if there were coercion, the employee would presumably know.

SPEECH.PARA: The implication of your question was: what is the process like in this area? The employee is given application forms before their contributions are made. The employees are entitled to make their own decisions about which option they want under their own names. This is actually before this process is under way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeking some clarification from Senator Kemp. If a prospective employee in Victoria walks into a company and is handed a contract that specifies that he must take an RSA, is that going to conflict?
—Yes, they must be given the range of options.
—So you could not have an employment contract that specified?
—You would not have an employment contract that specified that Senator Steve Conroy must take an RSA. If Senator Steve Conroy were being employed, he would be given a range of options.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted the contradiction in the answer to the question I raised earlier about who is going to resolve disputes. On the last occasion when the industrial legislation came before the Senate, it was clearly the government's intention to remove superannuation as an industrial issue. Is that still the government's intention, Senator Kemp? Senator Allison, is it the intention of the Democrats to agree to the removal of superannuation as an industrial issue?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The RAS bills before us have been framed in the existing environment. That is my response to your question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We know what the existing environment is, but I drew to your attention the fact that it was the government's—
—Stated intention.

—stated intention or policy on the last occasion industrial relations legislation was before the Senate to remove superannuation as an industrial issue altogether. It was not to be one of the 18 allowable matters, I think, that we ended up with.

SPEECH.PARA: That is fact. That was government policy. As far as I know, Industrial Relations Minister Reith has not retracted that policy. I would like to know whether it is your intention, perhaps in the course of this parliament—I know you cannot give commitments forever—to remove superannuation as an industrial issue. I would also like to know from the Democrats what their position is on this very important issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I will pass your question on to the responsible minister, Mr Peter Reith. If he wishes to make a response to you, he can do that. Of course, any changes which involve changes to the legisla tion would have to come before this Senate. I can hardly see a surprise occurring in the matter. This RSA bill has been drafted within the current environment to take account of the arrangements as they now are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not sure whether Senator Allison was coming to answer my question or not, so I am paying her the courtesy of speaking while she returns. We see this as a very important and fundamental issue. Senator Kemp should be able to indicate what the government's approach will be on this—whether there have been discussions or agreement on removing superannuation as an industrial issue. Mr Reith has been very clear in his stated intention to remove it as an industrial issue.

SPEECH.PARA: It does have a very important flow‐on consequence in the way in which RSAs are applied. We are considering RSA policy and legislation here today. We would like to know the framework of the government's intentions in respect of this. That is not an unreasonable question, Senator Kemp. We would like the truth.

Similarly, the Democrats referring earlier to the issue of the complaints tribunal being the arbiter, if you like, of disputes caused me some concern because it did seem to me to indicate that the Democrats envisaged a changed environment in respect of industrial relations and superannuation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw your attention to our amendment No. 5, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Subsection (1) does not apply if the application is made by an employer on behalf of an employee and the RSA provider is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that section 51A has been complied with

It is my understanding that that would open the way for the Superannuation Compliance Tribunal to act and, in the event that that is unsatisfactory, that the matter could be referred to the ISC and then finally to the Industrial Disputes Commission. That is my reading of the way that would work.

To answer your question regarding superannuation as an allowable matter, Senator Sherry, it is still our position that superannua tion would be included as an allowable matter. Until the concerns we have expressed elsewhere on the removal of superannuation from those allowable matters have been addressed and we are much more satisfied than we currently are, that remains the Democrats' position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not really had a clear answer from the minister in relation to an issue I asked about first of all. If we are finding already that some people have noted that something was wrong only if they were having contributions taken out and they knew they had not signed a form, what will be the trigger? I do not think it is good enough to say that forms will have been given to them. There are lots of reasons why people do not sign the forms: they might not understand them properly; they might decide that they do not want any of them; and they might be people who just do not like filling out forms. There are lots of reasons why a person might not fill out the form within the 28 days. They are still left with a situation where their money would be deducted and it may be quite a long time down the track before anyone is aware that there might be any problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister is saying that I am assuming coercion. Well, we are not even talking about coercion here; we are assuming that there may well be problems for which it might be necessary for there to be an automatic trigger for someone to know that something is wrong. We know that there might be the legal requirement that forms be flashed in front of a worker in one way or another, but what will the minister do? Will the minister be taking responsibility if—and this is a big `if'; or not even a big `if', a quite possible `if'—money is being put towards incorrect purposes? How will people know that something is wrong if they have not had to sign a form for this money to be deducted for that purpose?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a clarification of—or a correction to—my previous remarks. I did not intend to suggest that the three steps that I said were available were sequential; they are in fact alternatives.

—I have another question to add, if I may. What happens to those people who were in super funds—the small accounts people who for various reasons go from account to account because they are temporary, part time or permanent? What if they are in the Australian Taxation Office's small account reserve? Will they have the choice of trying to amalgamate a superannuation amount? What will happen to that amount?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —You have raised a couple of questions, Senator. In relation to the matter of filling out a form, people do not have to fill out a form in 28 days. They only have to indicate their choice of fund in writing. No moneys will be deducted and put into an RSA if an employee is a member of a fund to which he is currently contributing. In relation to your question about the tax office and small accounts, moneys can be taken out of the SHAR and put into an account.
—Taken out of the superannuation small accounts and put into an RSA?
—On the advice of the employee and with the consent of the member. Would you have it any other way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite definitely I would, if that money has been deducted for superannuation. Perhaps it would be different if you made it quite clear that the employer could not be involved in that choice. If the money was deducted for superannuation and ends up going to an RSA, it might well be a problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator KEMP (Victoria—Assistant Treasurer) (6.02 p.m.) My advice is that the member has always had that right. It is his money; he has that right. He has the right to determine where it goes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or her, Minister.

—I do not think the minister is clear in regard to what I am asking. What will be the employer's right in relation to this issue? I am trying to work out what happens to that money. Does that money stay in the ATO's small account reserve if there is an agreement, whichever way it is signed up, that their money is now going into a retirement savings account? This is a genuine request for information. Does the money stay in that small account reserve? Or is there an automatic movement of that money into another account—whatever the choice is, including an RSA—should the person be signed up to an RSA? Is there any possibility that that money will be taken out if employers choose to put their employee on an RSA?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is entirely a matter for the employee. The employee is the one who must indicate where the funds will go. It is not a matter for the employer; it is a matter for the employee. It is his money.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens when an employee is not aware of the superannuation fund that they are in? That is not an uncommon occurrence. Clearly, if they are changing employment, the likelihood is that money is probably not going into the employee's account that they have at that time. As I read it, it is perfectly acceptable for an RSA to be entered into in those circumstances, even where the employee does not know which superannuation account or what trustee arrangement they have with another institution.

—It is my understanding that at the point of entry there is a choice of both an RSA or a superannuation fund. That is, in the event that somebody begins a new job, the employer is obliged to offer that choice. I am not sure whether that answers Senator Sherry's question, but that is my understanding of how it works. Under no circumstances can an employee be offered the choice of only an RSA.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is broadly correct. Senator Sherry has raised an interesting point. If employees do not know they are in a fund—
—Which fund?

—If they cannot specify a fund, I am not sure what one could do in those circumstances. I would imagine every effort would be made to see whether such a fund could be located. In such circumstances where there is no knowledge of a fund which they may have had, I am not sure what one could do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of this issue, what is the government's freedom of choice policy? How does it define `freedom of choice'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I want to outline in any detail the freedom of choice policy, but I think it is probably getting pretty close. We believe people should have options, and this is one of those options now being brought into the superannuation area which people will have.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same issue, I ask the Democrats what their position is on fundamental freedom of choice as a policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Freedom of choice under most circumstances has to be balanced with the costs of making that choice available. I think what Senator Sherry is driving at is that the employee does not have full freedom of choice, and that is true. The employee, as far as I know, never has had that—under superannuation provisions which your government put in place either.

SPEECH.PARA: So I would argue that there is greater choice for both employers and employees under this soon to be amended—I hope—bill. You are right in that it does not offer absolute choice. It does not offer the choice for an employee to continue to have their contributions, should they change employment, directed to the fund of their choice. That is quite true. I think it would be something that we would like perhaps to see made available to employees, but it has not ever been.

I can imagine there would be quite serious administrative problems in arranging it. I can imagine that some employers would be faced with having to make contributions to a dozen or two dozen superannuation funds—I cannot think how many there might be—if we had full choice. So that might be desirable. However, that is not what this bill seeks to do, and I do not see it being a possibility—at least in the short term.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return to the question I asked Senator Kemp. As I understand it, Senator Kemp, your 1996 election campaign very clearly states there will be five choices offered.
—Senator, I understand that was in the policy document.
—Senator Kemp, is it the government's intention, as a consequence of the passing of the RSA legislation, to ensure that there are five choices offered on employment?

—Senator, I think there are four choices which are offered in this particular bill. Of course, any change to that would be a matter for the Senate to turn its mind to, assuming this amendment is passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I want the minister to explain this: if an employee does not sign an agreement within 28 days, how will the employer know whether or not they are in another superannuation fund or RSA? As you can see, my questions revolve around this default clause, which I believe is still hugely problematical. The default says: if you do not hear anything, assume it is an RSA, and it is an RSA of the employer's choice.

SPEECH.PARA: So how will the employer know whether or not their employee is with a current superannuation fund or even, as I mentioned, these small accounts? They may have been with a superannuation fund and been working only a small amount of time. They might actually want to stay with that superannuation fund. How will the employer know that if the person has not signed anything?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the short answer would be that the employee knows through the annual disclosure requirements under SIS.
—The employer.
—How would the employer know where he is sending the money? Perhaps we will get the question down clearly and then we will give you a response.
—Senator Margetts, perhaps you could repeat the question.

—If the employee has not signed a form in 28 days, for whatever reason, how will the employer know what their current status of superannuation or RSA is? How will they know whether or not they are entitled to sign a form on their behalf, which they had not signed, to take their money and put it somewhere else, in an account of their choice?

—There is no entitlement for an employee to continue to contribute towards whatever scheme they are in. So there is no need for an employer to know which previous scheme the employee was contributing to. There is no reason for them to know. They do not have that choice. They have a choice between two products. They have the choice of an RSA or the choice of a super fund—not necessarily their own. There is no obligation on the employer to provide a choice for the employee to contribute to their existing super scheme if they change jobs. If they are in that job and if the contributions are going towards one scheme, they will continue to go that way, unless after 28—
—How will they know? That is what I am saying.

—If they maintain their employment with the same employer, presumably that employer would know what superannuation fund they are contributing to. That is my understanding of it. So we are not talking about any change.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, I think your understanding of it is the same as my understanding. The employer will know because it is the fund to which they are currently contributing—that is, the fund to which they sent the dollars last month, last week or last year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —To Senator Allison, we do know there are approximately 16 million superannuation accounts in the country at the moment. I think it is an average of about 2½ superannuation accounts per employee. Certainly all of the evidence and contact I have had from people is that they are not aware—it would require a massive campaign to do it—that you can consolidate superannuation accounts. Do you believe that this will enable a reduction in the number of accounts—on which charges are made, I might say—to occur, or do you believe, as a consequence of this choice option with RSAs, that the number of accounts will increase?

—I suggest to you, Senator Sherry, that it will make no difference. There is still the opportunity to consolidate accounts, as there was previously. This bill does not address that question. This bill is simply about new terms of employment where, on entry into a superannuation scheme, an employee is given a choice between a super fund and an RSA. It is no different from the existing arrangement, except that the employer is able to offer an RSA as a product, as an alternative to a super scheme. There is no change to the ability or otherwise of an employee to consolidate their superannuation funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us take a specific example of an industry where there is a significant number of employees and a significant turnover. Let us take the hospitality industry, where there is a large fund known as Host Plus. Now, the employee leaves their existing employer. They are in Host Plus, which is the factual situation at the moment. They go to a new employer, where they would be covered automatically by Host Plus in most circumstances, with few exceptions. Let us say they go to that new employer and an RSA product is offered. They are already in Host Plus. They are in the hospitality industry. There are no contribu tions going into their Host Plus account. They already have the Host Plus account.

SPEECH.PARA: Why should they have to rejoin or recommence payment through some sort of offer circumstance? Why should an RSA be offered in those circumstances when they are already in a fund that is appropriate for that particular employee? Why should it be offered as another option when they are already in that superannuation fund?

TALK.START.PARA: —If they are in the situation that you describe, they are in the same industry. They are required under these amendments to be offered the industry superannuation fund. As I understand it, that is how that system will work. I do not understand why that appears to you to be a problem.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just received confirming advice from my advisers that that is the case. If it is an industry fund and an industry fund which relates to the particular employment that a person is in, that will be one of the options which will be offered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure why you cannot grasp the point that Senator Margetts and Senator Sherry are trying to make. You are already in the hospitality fund. You leave one employer and go to another. The employer, under this legislation, offers you two forms—an RSA form or the industry fund form. You take them away to think about them. You say, `I'm already in the hospitality fund. I don't need to fill in this hospitality fund form. I'm not interested in the RSA.' So you put them both in the bin. What then happens is you are defaulted out of your industry fund by your employer and put into an RSA. That is the point we are trying to make, Senator Allison.

SPEECH.PARA: You have a situation here where you are going to cause, through your amendments, people to be defaulted out of their existing fund. Why are they going to resubmit an application form for a fund they are already in? They will look at this form and say, `I'm already in this fund. I don't need to fill this out.' That is what you are creating. Because they will not return the application form for the fund they are already in, you will have them defaulted into the RSA by the employer. That is the point we are trying to make. Can you explain how you see that working?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my understanding that the SIS does not currently require an employer to place superannuation in the industry fund other than to meet the award conditions of three per cent. So, in fact, what we are proposing is something which is even tighter and which even more obliges the employer to direct contributions to the industry schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: You keep talking about a default, but there is no default mechanism. It is not automatic that an RSA will be opened, for instance, if the employee does not take the trouble to nominate that they prefer their contribution to be made to either an RSA or an industry superannuation fund or an ordinary superannuation fund. There is no default mechanism here. We are simply saying that the employer will be given the choice.
