There has to be some provision for the employer to put the contribution somewhere. Provided that there is a choice and it is up front and the two options are given to the employee on entry, we think that that is a fair and reasonable approach to take. In fact, as I said to you a moment ago, it is even more than the current law provides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —The point the Australian Democrats are making is that they are trying to protect workers from being forced into RSAs. The point we are trying to make is that this amendment does not achieve that. If an employer, before your amendment, wanted to force an employee into an RSA of the employer's choice, which was a concern that the committee had—and you and the Democrats are saying that you are trying to address that here—this amendment does not achieve it.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat: if I am an employee who is already in the industry fund and I change employers within the fund, I am handed the two forms. I take them away to think about it. The employer does not get a form back from me. You have now given that employer the right to put me into an RSA. I do not return the form of the fund because I am already in the fund. I do not need to apply to join the fund. I am in the fund.

So, in my mind as an employee sitting at home thinking about it, I look at the form and say, `I don't need to fill this out. I'm already in this fund,' and I throw it away. But by my doing that you are allowing the employer then to automatically default me and put me into the RSA of the employer's choice, not the RSA that is the choice of the employee. What you are saying is that, because the employee does not return the industry fund application form, therefore the employer still then is allowed to do what the employer wants.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some other issues here that have not been canvassed yet. What is going to happen to the fact that the Senate has on previous occasions dealt with the inequity of people, having been required to sacrifice wages that go into superannuation, ending up with a whole lot of small accounts that end up getting eaten away by charges. The Senate some time ago said, `Okay, we will try and deal with this. We will put them into the ATO small account reserve.' However, having done that, guess what? We are going to do that all over again. Perhaps the government can explain. Is there a provision for small accounts for RSAs? Are we not in fact going to get the Australian Taxation Office having a small account reserve for small superannuation contribution amounts and then have, in addition to that, an RSA here from one bank and an RSA here from another bank any time that person changes their job, which of course happens very frequently in the current employment situation? Are we not going to have—having tried to deal with one nightmare of superannuation—the Mephisto Waltz of RSAs, with small accounts that really are too small to do anything decent with burgeoning everywhere?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that it is entirely up to the employee what happens to the funds he has in the small accounts held by the Taxation Office. That is a matter for his decision, and I do not think that you would want to say that he should not be able to make a decision on that. It is entirely up to him what should happen to those funds. I am not sure whether you would argue the contrary point, which is that he should be prevented from removing those funds. I do not think that is your case at all.
—Do the RSAs fall into the categories of small accounts? They don't.

—There are a lot of issues around the consolidation of small accounts, and one of the reasons that all the superannuation funds are very keen to get tax file numbers is to assist in the consolidation of small accounts. Senator Sherry has made that point on a number of occasions in debates in this chamber. The mechanisms are being put in place to assist, where people want it, consolidation of accounts. Again, it is my understanding that it is entirely up to the individuals concerned. I am not sure that I can assist you further, Senator Margetts, but they are the facts of the matter.

—I wish to refer to Senator Conroy's remarks and the questions he asked of me. I guess that what Senator Conroy is getting at is the default, as he chooses to call it. It is not actually a default. It is simply an employer being in a position of having the choice in the event that the employee does not notify the employer of their choice. I would be interested in what Senator Conroy thinks ought to be the default. I also ask him what the opposition's position is on freedom of choice for employees in respect of superannuation funds.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, I am still not sure you grasp the significant problem we have in an industry such as hospitality, which we have used as an example. I do not think that a lot of employees, if they are already in the hospitality fund, will believe they should or would have to sign another form—or a letter to their employer, or signify to their employer—to rejoin the hospitality fund. Why should they? Why would they believe that they have to do this? Why wouldn't they get sick and tired of doing it if, as is common in the hospitality industry, they move from employers three, four or five times in one year? Added to that problem is the fact that, with increasing casualisation of the work force, you often have a casual employee working for more than one employer. That is not unique to the hospitality industry, but it is certainly a major feature of employment in that industry. I will conclude with that comment.

—I need to state my point even more clearly than I tried to do before. When I talked about the ATO small accounts reserve, I knew that was about superannuation. What I asked was: is there any similar provision for small accounts for RSAs or will we see a burgeoning of small accounts of RSAs for employees who do end up working for a number of different employers over a period of time? Will we not see the very thing this Senate tried to avoid—small accounts of RSAs, not just superannuation, jumping up everywhere—or is there provision for those RSAs to be amalgamated with the Australian Taxation Office's small accounts reserve? Is there the provision for people to do that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to the remarks I made a moment ago. Senators Conroy and Sherry seem to be suggesting that we are going to have massive changes here. They cite the hospitality industry as being a likely area in which this would occur. I suggest that it is unlikely in the extreme that in that industry in particular the employers will even bother with wanting to offer an RSA. I remind the Senate that this is not an obligation on the employer to always offer an RSA. I imagine that the employer would only do so in circumstances where there was not an enormous number of employees coming and going from periods of employment. It would be much easier for the hospitality industry to continue to send contributions for those who are employed in the industry to the industry fund. I cannot imagine that there would be any change to that.

SPEECH.PARA: Remember that the employers will need to go through all the trouble of putting together two disclosure documents, for RSAs and the super funds themselves. It is highly unlikely that this will happen. You are suggesting something that is not going to happen and in any case the safeguards are there. The choice is there on entry. You are saying that employees will just toss it in the bin when they receive it, but remember that they have got to sign a declaration form when they are employed again under a new arrangement with an employer. I do not think it is by any means a highly risky thing, as you suggest—that they will not see that there is an obligation for them to inform their employer. To some degree there is an obligation on the funds themselves to see that this does not happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you have essentially conceded our points with that last contribution. Can I just lay your mind to rest. I was simply sticking to the hospitality industry so that I did not further expand the debate. But I can assure you that applies in the transport industry. As Senator Kemp frequently likes to remind the Senate, I was a hardworking superannuation officer for the TWU super fund. I just thought I would put that in for you, Senator.
—You beat us to the jump.

—Just to save you the trouble of getting to your feet. The point we are making is that in any industry if you change employer you are still covered by the same fund. It does not matter whether it is transport, hospitality, hospital or retail, as the push to casualise the work force goes on, it is more likely with casual employees that there will be an increase rather than a decrease in people faced with this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: If I am already a member of the TWU super fund and I go from Finemores to John Smith Pty Ltd—and Finemores pays into the fund so I am a member of the fund—and John Smith Pty Ltd gives me two forms and says, `Here is your choice: an RSA or you can be in the TWU super fund,' I go home to think about it and decide that I want to stay in the industry fund. I am not throwing it away without thinking about it at all. I have looked at it and thought, `I do not need to fill this industry fund form out because I am already in it.' So I throw the RSA form away because I do not want to be in it. I look at the TWU super fund application form and think, `I do not need to fill this out because I am already in the super fund,' and I put it in the bin. I will have then forfeited, under the legislation, my right to choose. What will happen is that the employer, who will not receive the form back from me, will think, `Oh, well, he didn't say anything so I can put him into the RSA.' That is the point we are trying to make. That is the point you have not addressed and which I think you have conceded by your last contribution.

You asked what our alternative would be. Our alternative was that this should not be in the legislation; this should be amended out of the legislation. The employer should not be able to put me into an RSA without my consent. That is the position that you should have fought for in your deal and that is the position that this Senate should, in my view, if the Democrats had not sold out, be passing today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be a help if we could keep the debate on a reasonably even keel. No‐one has sold out, Senator. What we are trying to do is to work out workable arrangements which meet the government's objective and an election promise to introduce RSAs and to meet the concerns, as far as we are able, of people in the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Allison. I think the bias is actually effectively towards the industry fund. The reality is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha! That is why you're doing it.

—The question is: why are you so paranoid about it? The reality is that if someone is in an industry fund and they change their employer within the same industry the employer is presumably already contributing to an industry fund. It is presumably simple for him to do that. That is the first point: there is a system already in place and, presumably, a relationship with the industry fund.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is no need to be defensive. The reality is that a choice is being given—one of which will be an industry fund—and the employee has the right to make that choice. I thought it was well explained by Senator Allison that, when they get to a new employ er, they have got to sign a new form—a declaration form as an employee—and presumably it will be indicated to them at that stage what the choice of funds is, including an RSA if the employer is so disposed to offer it.

Senator, I have to tell you that I do not see the dilemma here at all. I do not think that we need to be defensive. I do not think industry funds need to be defensive. Presumably, industry funds have got a good case to sell. They should not be worried about choice and I do not see what the particular dilemma is in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say, and I do not mean to be offensive, Senator Allison, that I think you are very naive about what will emerge. From my experience in the hospitality industry—and that is a real world experience, an industry I worked in for a long time—I think you are very naive. I can see significant problems.

SPEECH.PARA: You challenged us about the default option. If you are in a hospitality fund and you move to a new employer within the hospitality industry, and the new employer offers you optional membership of either the RSA or the hospitality industry fund, which you are already in, why would you do anything? I think most people would make the judgment that they do not need to do anything. Why should they do anything? They are already in a fund covering the hospitality industry and they are still in the hospitality industry, so they will do nothing. Why should they change that arrangement? I think a lot of people in those circumstances are not going to be active in the sense of their decision.

We would submit that if they do nothing—they do not make any notification, and, if they are still in the same industry and they are still in the fund covering that industry by virtue of their previous employment—that should be the default option. That would seem to be the logical conclusion. They are exercising their choice by doing nothing. They are happy with their current fund.

Senator Kemp made a point about people out there defending their position, selling their services, selling their fund. I am confident— very confident—that, as a consequence of this legislation, that will happen. That is one of the downsides to it all. What we worry about is that we will have banks, particularly, out there selling a product; and industry funds responding, selling a product; and agents out there selling a product—an individual type product where they can.

There is a significant cost to this supposed `choice'. There is a significant cost to this. We are going to have extensive advertising campaigns. I know that at least one of the banks has told me what another bank intends to do. This will add to cost. It will add to administrative costs, advertising costs, recruitment costs. Get out there, sell the wares, sell the RSA, sell the product, make a choice—free enterprise at its best: ra, ra, ra. To what end? Everyone will still have to be in a superannuation account of one sort or another but at significantly increased cost. Senator Kemp, take a trip to Chile and look at free enterprise at its best in respect of superannuation accounts. Plenty of ra, ra, ra—freedom of choice. They are out there flogging the product.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not going down the Chilean road.
—This is a move down the Chilean road and the UK road.
—Rubbish!
—Do you know anything about the Chilean system or the UK system?
—I actually do.

—Okay. In Chile you would know that the administrative costs—selling the products, the advertising—are around about 10 to 11 per cent of the overall moneys. That is the great fear that I have about where we are moving to in the retail product of superannuation. That is a broader comment in response to what you had to say, Senator Kemp.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, Senator Allison, I do not think you understand the reality of the workplace, the reality of the way in which it will work, the reality of the way in which some employers behave and the potential breakdown that may occur in the system and the costs that are involved in that. As I said before, with our amendments, the bottom line principle is that we could accept the concept of RSAs.

The government keeps talking about an election promise—RSAs were an election promise. If you look through the cabinet submission and their election promise, you will see that there are a number of points from which they have significantly departed in this legislation. For example, life companies are not offering RSAs. They are not able to. That was actually in the cabinet submission. Issues involving portability—

TALK.START.PARA: —Life companies are, Senator.
—Sorry, superannuation funds are not capable of offering RSAs. Where has that gone, Senator Kemp?
—They have light products.

—Yes, but why can't they offer RSAs? What has happened to that? I think the banks rang you up and said, `Look, Mr Costello, do what we want. Deliver this. Keep those life companies out of this product.'
—You're wrong. You're dead wrong.

—Mr Costello promptly says, `Yes, I have to do what the banks want. Got to keep them happy.' That includes you, Senator Kemp, in this conspiracy between Mr Costello and the banks, because, frankly, you do not count when it comes to this issue. You just do not count. You are kept out of the loop in the same way your predecessor was kept out of the loop. You are just given your marching orders by Mr Costello: `Go in there. Don't compromise. Don't back down. Don't do a backflip,' until the reality of the numbers in the Senate to some extent has forced you to reconsider your position. As I say, I sympathise with your position, Senator Kemp.

SPEECH.PARA: I regrettably think we are not going to convince the Democrats. That saddens me. I have referred to history and looked in retrospect at the consequences that flow from this sort of legislation. We have been through that in the previous debate. I think it is sad that the Democrats cannot be more visionary about where we are headed with superannuation. I dread where we are headed with superannua tion under this government. I really dread it. I say that very passionately and very sincerely.

I think when we look back in five years time we will wonder what on earth has been created. It will be a monster with the approach of this government, and the Democrats are going along with it, not because this is a budget measure that costs the government money. It was defeated clearly in the Senate and the Democrats want to go along with it. Why on earth do they want to go along with it? It does not provide the basic safeguards that we voted on in the Senate six or seven weeks ago. It does not cost the budget bottom line. Mr Costello rings you up, abuses you and berates you and you fall over. Is that the reason? Why? I cannot understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Soft touch!
—Yes, he might have adopted the soft touch. It might have been the coffee or the tea that Mr Reith used. I do not know what was in it.
—You're struggling, Nick.
—I am just taking out my frustration with the Democrats and their approach. It is not meant personally, Senator Allison. I just do not appreciate or understand your new position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The RSAs, it has been established, are low return funds. It is also established that the employee has no rights to request a particular RSA. It would be the one that the employer was signed on to if she or he were to sign on to an RSA. Therefore, to whom would the selling of the product occur? It does not seem much point the banks just going out to the employees, because they would not necessarily know with whom the employers were associated unless they deal direct with the employer.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that the selling pitch will be aimed at the employer. The employer does not necessarily get the return from the RSAs. The banks who have a lot of power—and you can hardly claim they do not—may have to gear their selling pitch onto other aspects. What could that be? Overdraft availability, whether or not they are going to foreclose on the loan—all sorts of ways that a business, particularly one that is having credit problems, may well find subtle pressures or otherwise to be involved with promoting a particular RSA.

The indications are that, unless the minister can convince me otherwise, that is what he is leading us to—a situation where the selling will be directed towards the employer and it is left only to the Senate and the community's imagination what the selling points may well be in relation to banks suggesting to employers, large or small, what the advantages might be for them to be involved with a particular bank RSA.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The paranoia is running fairly freely. We had a burst from Senator Sherry and now we have had it from you, Senator Margetts. The reality is that the employee can nominate an RSA within 28 days if he or she wants to. So the assumption on which your comments in the last three minutes were based is just not accurate.
—Not one of their choice.

—It is up to you whether you accept my answer or not. You asked the question and I will give you an answer. I have some distinguished advisers here and they have indicated to me that what you said is not correct. If you do not accept it, then that is all right. You asked a question and I gave you an answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to respond to Senator Sherry's remarks. We have not in fact changed our minds at all. This is a much tighter amendment than the one we proposed during the last debate. I draw your attention to our amendment No. 4 to 51A and item 2(e) which requires:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a written notice stating that . . . the employer may make an application for the RSA on behalf of the employee if the employee does not, within 28 days . . .

You may argue that it is likely, but at least we have put in all of the provisions we think will alert an employee to the fact that an employer may take this action. They will not necessarily take it and we do not with this legislation oblige them to put the contribu tions into an RSA, but simply put in place all of those measures, those notices and those reminders to employees that that is the option which is available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish I could live in a world where there was only one industry fund in my industry, say, the teaching profession—that is, where I would be offered one fund that covers my industry or an RSA. In the real world—for people, say, in the hospitality industry or the retail industry—there are actually competing industry funds, Senator Allison. Some of them are employer front industry funds because they could not bear the prospect of being in an industry fund with a trade union. They actually set up rival funds purely on the basis of refusing to participate in a fund that had anything to do with the trade union movement. That is actually what happens.

SPEECH.PARA: When we have designated that there are going to be two pieces of paper handed to a prospective employee to choose between an industry fund and the RSA, it is a matter of which industry fund. Who gets to choose which industry fund is being presented to the employee? It is the employer. If the employer is part of one of these industry funds or is one of those out there that hates trade unions they would perhaps not present the industry fund that the employee was previously in. This could happen because they are committed to be anti-union companies. They do exist out there. I would have thought the teaching profession in Victoria would have come across an anti-union employer in the last few years, but perhaps not.

The point I am making is that not all industry funds are the same. Not all industry funds have the same low cost structures. Not all industry funds have the same good performance. Where is the choice? Do not stand up in the chamber and say that this legislation is about increasing choice. Choice, as far as the Democrats are concerned, lasts for 28 days and after 28 days the choice is gone. This is a piece of legislation that reduces choice. Your amendments simply keep a bit of extra choice in place for 28 days and after 28 days this legislation goes back to what it was six weeks ago. It removes choice. It is not about improving choice.

It is a piece of legislation that is supposed to be about improving choice, but it reduced choice six weeks and you voted against it on the basis that it reduced choice. Your amendments simply mean that choice is there for an extra 28 days. There is no choice for the employee about which documentation he or she receives. If there is a range of different industry funds—and some of them in the transport industry, and I am sure other industries, are quite poor performers and high cost—the employee will be faced with a choice between an industry fund that is poor performing and high cost or an RSA which has a low return. That is what happens in the real world. That is what the Democrats said they were opposed to six weeks ago. You want more choice, but you have signed up to a bit of legislation that reduces choice. That is the reality of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Conroy and Senator Sherry that they voted for this amendment six weeks ago. We have returned with the amendment. We have made it tighter and for some reason you are now discovering reasons you cannot support it. I am sorry about that, but we have done our best to put in place the sorts of measures that we think should be here to protect workers. If you are now having second thoughts about that then it would be useful to have discussions with us. I am still standing by the amendments that we are putting and I urge you to support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, what I am more than curious about with regard to the Democrats' position is that you say that you have taken measures to protect workers and provide greater choice for workers, et cetera. If we take that at face value and accept that you have done those things, with regard to the amounts of money that we know are likely to go into these accounts, what are you going to do with regard to the interest that is paid to those accounts? I would also be interested in the minister's response to this. Regardless of the fact that you may think that workers will have more choice, in many cases the reality will be exactly as it has been put: there will not be the choice, as is quite often the case now where there are industry funds. Because employers do deals with insurance companies, workers are forced to have their superannuation with a particular company, whether they have got an industry fund or not.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the fundamental issues in this legislation is where people are able to put their money. We are talking about retirement savings accounts. In the main, probably small amounts of money will be involved. I am sure you are aware of the rates of interest. I know that Senator Kemp would be, but of course it would not worry him too much because he would have enough money to make sure he is earning the top interest rate. The Temporary Chair, Senator Ferguson, would too, but he might not admit it. The great bulk of Australian workers who will find themselves being lumped in RSAs—a lot of them will be part-time workers—will not get any interest on their money.

The Reserve Bank bulletin of April 1997 says that Australian banks pay no interest on $14.8 billion of Australian depositors' funds—none, zip. Senator Allison, I am sure you are fully aware of the stepped interest rates that banks apply to deposits. I would suggest that you and the Democrats look very hard at the issue of interest rates and how they might be applied to RSAs. I for one am not going to vote to give away more money of Australian workers, particularly those who are in the position to least be able to afford it. We ought to be doing everything to ensure that the money that such people are able to pay into some sort of retirement fund earns the maximum amount of interest to ensure that, at the end of the day, they have the best amount of money available to them in their retirement. You should not be voting for or even supporting legislation that in any way, shape or form will designate most of their money into funds that will earn them no interest at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has indicated that there are words in here `for another RSA', which indicates that the banks perhaps have gone to him and said, `We want there to be some indication that there is competition in here,' even though it is not real competition when there are very few banks. However, it does seem bizarre that we could not have competition in superannuation. People do not have a choice about where they put their money and they do not yet have a choice about whether they put their money into ethical investment funds; they do not have a choice about whether they support regional businesses; they do not have a lot of choices in superannuation. But here we have some choices which may in fact benefit the banks.

SPEECH.PARA: I do think the whole thing is bizarre. This bill is really the wrong direction for us to be going in in Australia. It is an indictment, unfortunately, of both the government and the Democrats if they are prepared to push this through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —You certainly did tighten up the amendment, Senator Alison. Unfortunately, it is nothing like the previous amendment. So if you stand in your place and say that this is a tighter thing and that we voted for it last time, it is absolutely misleading the Senate. Last time there were five choices. Well, five is more than two. You had to have a public offer fund; you had to have a couple of other funds. Now you are down to two. So where you can seriously claim that this is the same amendment as last time leaves me quite surprised. The ongoing health warnings—something that you and other Democrats have spoken about at length—have gone in this package.

SPEECH.PARA: So when you say that these amendments and this package is the same as that which we voted for last time, it is not the case. We are going to vote against it because, as I said earlier, we have reduced choice under this legislation. That is what has happened. The package you have agreed to is reducing choice. This is not the same amendment as last time and to stand up and say that it is is to mislead the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to let that go, but I really cannot. I have just been handed our previous amendment; here it is in its entirety. So it is not reasonable for Senator Conroy to suggest that there were five and that now there are three or two, or whatever. This amendment is the same in that respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments are okay as far as they go, but when compared with the totality of the amendments moved with respect to what is commonly known as third line forcing, they are not as strong. I do not wish to take too much of the time of the committee by going over the arguments that were traversed on the previous occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly in principle, RSA providers should not be permitted in any way, shape or form to offer any form of inducement. We do not cast aspersions on the ethical behaviour of the providers or the employers, but it is regrettable that there will be an element amongst some of the employers who will engage in such behaviour.

Labor cannot stress enough that it is very concerned about low income earning employees, particularly casual and part‐time employees, who are very vulnerable in that type of employment situation. As limited as these particular provisions the Democrats are inserting are, there will still be significant difficulties created for employees where an employer `suggests'. You can outlaw such behaviour all you like, but the majority of employees, particularly in those low paying, casual, part-time positions, are particularly open to coercion.

Employees who are in a vulnerable employment position may suffer serious, long-term consequences that will be detrimental to their future financial security. Superannuation, as we have noted, is a compulsory saving. It is money that employees go without in order to save for retirement. It is not acceptable that employers can enter into any sort of arrangement with any financial institution.

It was argued on the previous occasion that the Trade Practices Act in respect of third line forcing would prevent this type of situation. The government assured us on that occasion that this sort of behaviour would be outlawed by the Trade Practices Act.

In evidence before the Senate committee, the Australian Consumers Association certainly did not believe the Trade Practices Act would be sufficient. They also gave evidence that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission had been unable to prosecute financial institutions on the basis of section 47. I have had a number of private meetings with a number of people in this area since the Senate last considered this package of legislation. This legislation is fine as far as it goes, but it does not go far enough in protecting consumers. We regret that. We regret and are very concerned about the weaker position the Democrats have retreated to in totality with the proposed safeguards in this package since the Senate last considered this legislation.

We have already touched on our concerns about issues relating to the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, the role of trustees and a number of other concerns which are not addressed by this package of legislation, in particular the provisions outlined in the clauses we are considering in respect of the types of behaviour that certainly some employers and financial institutions may engage in. It will be interesting to look at the way in which RSAs emerge over coming years to see the pattern that emerges and, coincidentally, to see the relationship between those employees in a particular product, particularly those offered by a bank. I think we will see a not unsurprising coincidence between the RSA products that employees are in and the banking or other financial arrangements of their employer.

TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 36 (after line 5), at the end of Division 2, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 50A RSA provider to have liability as trustee

SPEECH.PARA: Except as provided otherwise in this Act, every director of an RSA institution is subject to the same duties and under the same liability in respect of an act or omission in relation to a trust or fiduciary duty as if he or she had been a trustee and as if RSA holders had been beneficiaries of such a trust, unless the director proves that the act or omission occurred without his or her knowledge and that he or she used all due diligence to prevent the act or omission.

The question remains, having regard to what we just did a moment ago, as to whether we should include the latter words relating to due diligence to prevent the act or omission. The committee might like to consider that.

When I put this forward on the last occasion on 25 March, this measure was adopted by the Senate; it was passed. It was supported by the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Greens. When it was passed, although the legislation was ultimately defeated, there was a tremendous reaction from the banking industry—an overwhelming reaction. They were cranking up their very well oiled machine to have me see the error of my ways.

BREAK.PARA: The error of my ways apparently was that there should be a fiduciary duty imposed on the banks—in respect of what? Money that is submitted and paid into retirement savings accounts for workers and their dependants for retirement. The suggestion was that that fiduciary duty would place the directors of banks in a situation of conflict with their responsibility as directors of the institution.

Frankly, before I address the issue, I believe—and I think the chamber would believe also—that it should be the case that such moneys do have protection that would be given by my amendment over the interests of, say, foreign shareholders of banks. The philosophy behind this measure is very clear: trustee duties and liabilities ought to be imposed on institutions taking money of those seeking to provide for themselves or their dependants for the vicissitudes of life and including moneys that are paid in for the benefit of retirees and their dependants.

We are not dealing with the bank's money; we are not dealing with life insurance company money; we are not even dealing with employer's money; we are dealing with the workers' money. It is money that is being set aside for workers—including those who may become disabled and thus need to retire—for their old age or for their widows and orphans.

For centuries, the law of trusts has been a body of law to which we resort in order to impose obligations where one person entrusts funds to another for the purposes of providing for others. That has been recognised in the Life Insurance Act; that was enshrined in section 38(8). Unfortunately, while that principle was in the first print of the Life Insurance Bill 1994, it somehow later got dropped out without debate as the Life Insurance Bill went through the House of Representatives. No explanation was given to parliament as to why directors of life insurance companies were to be freed from trustee obligations. I gather that the suggestion has been made that the particular statutory duties set out in the Life Insurance Act 1945 are superior.

Let me remind senators, as I did when I dealt with this matter on a previous occasion, that the first draft of the bill did not have that provision excised. I think this is a very important matter that we are dealing with. I have noted what was said in the cabinet‐in‐confidence document that happened to be lying on this particular table. That document talks about the cabinet commitment which raises significant policy issues: namely, which financial institutions may provide RSAs directly without a trust structure, the regulatory regime that should apply to RSAs and the appropriate tax treatment of RSAs.

My amendment does not suggest that there needs to be a separate trust structure at all. I know that has been suggested. I know that the banks have been running around the place frightening the life out of credit unions and so forth, making them fearful of what I am proposing to do. It is a nonsense. I know they have been doing that, and I know the government is very much behind it. My amendment does not require—and I invite the minister to prove that it does—RSA providers to set up a separate trust structure. All it does is provide a holder of an RSA with appropriate protection by imposing the duties and liabilities of trustees on RSA providers.

No doubt Senator Allison would have been told that my amendment would set up formal trust structures. That is what I heard her hint in her previous contribution. She has been told that, but it does not have to. It is recognised that some trustee obligations may be absolutely desirable. That should be recognised by the industry itself. I think that it would be unfair competition if superannuation funds holding superannuation savings were subject to trustee obligations but other institutions were not.

If the government is all about free and fair competition, what about making it free and fair? For competition to be free and fair, similar products receiving similar tax treatment for similar purposes should have similar obligations on the providers. I point out that at a technical level debtor-creditor relationships and trustee beneficiary relationships can co‐exist in one transaction. I refer to the Quistclose Investments v. Barclays Bank case. Parliament previously imposed trustee duties and obligations in respect of contracts of life insurance under the Life Insurance Act 1945, as I mentioned previously. I believe it is most important for the protection of beneficiaries that the Senate again adopts the amendment that I am proposing.

Finally, I point out that this approach is also followed in section 200 of the New South Wales Workers Compensation Act 1987, which imposes almost identical trustee duties and liabilities on the directors of insurance companies undertaking workers compensation business. Clearly the amendment that I am putting forward is consistent with existing policy and is consistent with other proposed amendments to this legislation.

By starting with the trustee concept, we will have a clear legislative framework on which to build. Any modifications or additions to trustee obligations can then be specifically set out in the act. I repeat: given the purposes for which the moneys are invested, the inequality of bargaining power and the trust and confidence which is reposed in these institutions, the law of contracts is not sufficient alone. The duties and liabilities of trustees are the essential foundations, in my view, that need to be laid for this act to work in the public interest. I again commend the amendment to the committee. I hope that the committee will do what it did only as recently as 25 March and adopt this particular amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Labor broadly agrees with the position put by Senator Harradine. Before I go into some detailed remarks, I have to say, Senator Harradine, that if the banks were trying to get you to see the error of your ways, I wish them better luck than I have had on occasions since we have known each other. It is certainly not easy, once you have taken a position, to point you on to a different path on the basis of the error of your ways. Even though we do not agree on many occasions, I think that is to your credit.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the amendment being put forward by Senator Harradine, as was pointed out by Senator Harradine, this was passed on the last occasion that the Senate considered this package of legislation. Senator Harradine's amendment goes to what I think can aptly be described as the heart of the protection mechanisms of the superannuation system. When Labor was in office in 1993, we introduced what was known as the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, which ensured one of the most rigorous protection regimes for superannuation and like products anywhere in the world. Essential to that, of course, is protection against theft and fraud.

Regrettably, we have seen in recent months—I saw this first-hand in Adelaide a week and a half ago when I met with some RetireInvest victims, but I will not go into the details of the particular problems involving RetireInvest—an increasing problem of theft and fraud in respect of post-superannuation moneys. After a person has collected their lump sum, they are then faced with making the choice of investment in a range of different entities. There do seem to be increases in theft and fraud occurring in that area, but that is not the subject of our debate tonight. We are looking at pre-retirement, where money is in the superannuation system while someone is employed.

However, the banks in this case or the credit unions with superannuation moneys—compulsory saving for a person's retirement—will not be covered by the types of protection that the SIS Act offers in respect of trustees. The SIS legislation creates a trustee duty. This fiduciary duty creates a duty on behalf of the trustee to act on behalf of the beneficiaries. This is very different, we would contend, from the duty of a board of directors for a company in the case of the banking industry. This duty is onerous, and Labor does not shy away from ensuring that this duty and the responsibilities exercised by trustees are onerous.

Trustees that are in the position of the investment management of workers' money for their retirement have an enormous responsibility. It is significantly greater than the responsibility placed on the directors of a corporation, and for good reason. Superannuation saving is a different form of saving. It is for retirement. It has to be guaranteed in the event of theft and fraud. There has to be a significant number of checks and balances that place that protection at a more significant level than other forms of saving. If the government does not accept that as a principle, then I would like them to say it. If they believe that superannuation saving should be treated in exactly the same way as most other forms of saving, with less onerous responsibilities in respect of the supervision of that saving, let them say it.

This RSA bill seeks to reduce the liability and responsibility of trustees. That is the effect of it. Labor cannot accept this position. RSAs are products relating to superannuation. As I have said, superannuation is a different type of saving from that of other bank products. As Senator Harradine and Labor senators and other senators have commented time and time again, superannuation is workers' retirement income. It is not typical of a normal bank decision where there is almost total freedom to move in and out subject to the particular requirements in respect of normal bank accounts. This is money that individuals are required to save for their old age and to live on.

One of the reasons we toughened up the regulation of superannuation considerably in the SIS Act was the Maxwell disaster in the United Kingdom. I visited first‐hand the United Kingdom during the lead-up to the preparation of that legislation, and I spent some time with those of the trustees that were around with the victims of that fraud case.

What was obvious was that, aside from the failure of the regulatory supervisors of the financial system in the United Kingdom, the trustee system in the Maxwell disaster did not work effectively. There was effectively no trustee checking the mechanism. There were trustees, but trustees in name only. The ability of Maxwell to access the life savings of thousands of members of superannuation funds that he effectively controlled is no different from the ability of bank officials on a bank board to carry out dishonest behaviour. It would be unfortunate if it were to occur, but it could happen.

RSAs as outlined in this proposed legislation, which is being supported by the Australian Democrats, do not line up with the government's election promises. Senator Harradine has already referred to the cabinet‐in‐confidence document that we have shown those responsible for the legislation in here tonight. We will support Senator Harradine's amendment. Superannuation is a different type of savings product. It is fundamentally different and there should be the most fundamental and absolute protections. In our view, Senator Harradine's amendment certainly accomplishes those fundamental and, in our view, almost absolute protections that are possible to design within a regulatory framework.
In concluding my remarks, at this stage I pass this over to you, Senator Kemp. We seek leave to incorporate the cabinet‐in‐confidence document in the Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Table it.
—You will not let us incorporate it?
—I think it is not appropriate.
—You could read it out at length.
—I could read it out at length.
—Order! You are seeking leave to incorporate a document?
—Yes, I am seeking leave.
—If you promise not to speak again.
—We are moving along very rapidly, Senator Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
CABINET-IN-CONFIDENCE
Background

The Government announced its commitment to allow banks, building societies, credit unions, life insurance companies (life offices), complying superannuation funds, and other financial intermediaries to offer Retirement Savings Accounts (RSAs) in its pre‐election "Superannuation for all—Security and Flexibility in Retirement" Statement.

2. This commitment raises significant policy issues, namely: which financial institutions may provide RSAs directly without a trust structure; the regulatory regime that should apply to RSAs; and the appropriate tax treatment of RSAs.
Issues
Rationale

3. RSAs will be a simple, low cost, low risk product especially suited to those with small amounts of superannuation, such as itinerant and casual workers, or those nearing retirement (wishing to minimise risk). Their introduction will complement existing superannuation arrangements by allowing banks and other institutions to provide cost efficient delivery of superannuation. This will enhance competition and choice in the superannuation industry, thereby putting downward pressure on fees and charges, and encouraging improved service delivery. Employers looking for a convenient vehicle for small Superannuation Guarantee contributions will benefit. Many employees will also benefit as RSAs will be convenient and flexible.

4. In light of the advantages of RSAs and the Government's firm commitment to them, I consider that RSAs should be introduced as quickly as possible. In particular, I do not consider that there is any reason to defer the introduction of RSAs until after the Financial System Inquiry has reported.
Trustee arrangements

5. At present, complying superannuation products must generally be offered through a trust arrangement, under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (SIS Act), in order to qualify for superannuation tax concessions. Under this structure, the fund trustee is the legal owner of the fund assets, with members having a beneficial interest. Fund trustees are subject to fiduciary obligations under trust law (some of which have been codified and expanded in the SIS Act), and are required to comply with the SIS operating standards, designed to maximise the likelihood that the fund is managed prudently and for genuine retirement income purposes.

6. Deposit takers such as banks, credit unions and building societies are already significant players in the superannuation market, through subsidiary companies (often life offices), which, like other superannuation providers, must currently operate their superannuation business under a trust structure.

7. Life offices and complying superannuation funds, which are more like fund managers than deposit takers, currently offer a range of market‐linked and capital stable individual and group superannuation products using `public offer' superannuation entities whose trustees are subject to approval processes administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC).

8. From a member's perspective, an RSA would be more akin to a personal deposit account than a pooled or collective investment. In effect, an RSA would be like a deposit account in the name of an individual but subject to preservation requirements.

9. Where employees have limited control over their superannuation, trustees have an important role in protecting the interests of fund members. However, the case for a trust structure is weaker where the sponsoring institution is already subject to prudential supervision and where employees are able to rollover their superannuation into another fund if they so wish, and can look after their own interests. This will be true for RSAs, as each account is envisaged as a single superannuation fund where the account holder would be able to rollover the accumulated superannuation amounts.

10. Thus, legally, the trustee/beneficiary relationship for existing superannuation fund members could be replaced by a debtor/creditor relationship; in the case of bank, building society and credit union RSAs, or a direct contractual relationship with the policy holder for life office RSAs.

11. In the absence of a trust structure, the right to offer RSAs should be confined to financial institutions which are subject to prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank of Australia, (RBA), the Australian Financial Institutions Commission (AFIC) or the ISC, that is, banks, credit unions, building societies, and life offices. (The eligibility of friendly societies to offer RSAs will be reviewed if they come under AFIC supervision.) Public offer complying superannuation funds would continue to operate through a trust structure (as this is the basis of protecting the interests of fund members). However, such funds could offer products broadly equivalent to an RSA, if they so wished.

12. The proposed arrangements are consistent with announced Government policy to allow banks, building societies, credit unions, life offices, and superannuation funds to offer RSAs for individual superannuation. However, other financial intermediaries, for example, friendly societies, do not operate under sufficiently rigorous prudential supervision arrangements to be able to offer RSAs at present. I am therefore proposing to limit RSAs to those institutions which operate under appropriate prudential regimes, pending any changes to supervision arrangements following the Financial System Inquiry.
Investment arrangements

13. For banks, building societies and credit unions, RSAs will be held directly on balance sheet and so will form part of the deposit base of the institution. As a result, funds deposited with RSAs will be invested in the same manner as other deposits of such institutions, that is, primarily in cash, securities, and bank loans. This would mean that RSAs offered by deposit taking institutions would effec tively be a capital guaranteed, low risk/low return financial product.

14. In the absence of restrictions, RSAs offered by life offices could invest in a wider range of assets (including property and equities) and so would be more akin to a higher risk/higher return managed fund. In the interests of competitive neutrality, I propose that all RSAs must be capital guaranteed. This would effectively restrict the investments which can be made by life office RSAs, but ensure that RSAs offered by the different types of institutions are broadly similar. This approach is also consistent with the basic concept of RSAs being low risk niche products which supplement existing superannuation instruments.
Regulatory regime

15. Pending any changes to the regulatory regime which might arise from the Financial System Inquiry, RSA supervision would be split into two parts: relevant prudential supervision for institutional soundness, and ISC functional supervision of compliance with retirement income standards. That is, the prudential soundness of institutions offering RSAs would continue to be the responsibility of the relevant supervisor (the RBA, ISC, or AFIC), while the ISC would oversight RSA compliance with relevant retirement income standards. (These are the requirements imposed on complying superannuation funds to ensure that benefits are used for genuine retirement income purposes.) There will be no duplication of regulation.

16. The retirement income standards to apply to RSAs will be tailored to address the particular features and risks associated with RSAs and will cover aspects such as eligibility to make contributions, controls on benefit payments (including preservation requirements), appropriate disclosure, annual reporting, registering of RSA providers, member protection for small superannuation contributions, complaints handling, allowable investments, use of Tax File Numbers, penalties and purchasing of life and disability insurance. Further details on the prudential supervision arrangements and proposed regulatory regime for RSA providers is at Attachment B.
Taxation treatment for RSAs

17. The proposed taxation treatment for RSAs is outlined in Attachment C. These arrangements are designed to ensure that the superannuation tax concessions are afforded to RSAs in an administratively simple and neutral manner.
Possible limits on RSA balances

18. Because RSAs are expected to be a relatively low return form of superannuation savings, they would not generally be suitable vehicles for accumulating superannuation savings over a whole lifetime. This has led some commentators to call for a mandatory cap on the maximum amount which an individual can hold in an RSA. I consider a mandatory cap of this kind would be difficult to enforce (an individual who wanted to keep their savings in an RSA would simply open a new RSA once they reached the cap) and would be inconsistent with individual choice. However, to protect members against accumulating too much of their superannuation in low yielding accounts, I propose that once an RSA balance reaches $10,000, the provider will be required to advise the account holder of the desirability of investigating higher yielding superannuation products. The terms of this advice may need to be determined by the ISC to ensure adequate disclosure.
Constitutional Issues
19. The introduction of RSAs raises a number of constitutional issues (outlined in Attachment D), but these should not present major difficulties.
Sensitivity/Criticism

20. Banks, building societies, and credit unions support the introduction of RSAs without a trust structure, although this may be opposed by some life offices and superannuation funds. There may also be some criticism of the disclosure requirements and the capital guaranteed nature of the product. RSAs may be perceived as a competitive threat by multi‐employer `industry funds'. Friendly societies will complain that they will not be permitted to sell RSAs directly (although some friendly societies operate building societies and credit union subsidiaries and will be able to enter this market through that means).
Legislation

21. This proposal will require new legislation governing the operation of RSAs, as well as amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, and consequential amendments to other legislation (as listed in Attachment E).
Timing

22. It is intended to develop the RSA proposal in time for approved financial institutions to be able to offer RSAs from 1 July 1997. This timing allows for a consultation period with industry following the policy announcement and for legislation to be introduced late in the Budget sittings and passed in the 1997 Autumn sittings. Time will also be required for any necessary application and approval processes, and for institutions to develop their RSA products and related systems.
Coordination Comments
23. Coordination comments are at Attachment F.
Evaluation Strategy
24. The policy and legislation framework will be reviewed by the ISC and Treasury, three years after implementation.
Financial Considerations

25. The direct revenue cost of RSAs is unquantifiable but likely to be small. (There will be a cost to revenue only to the extent that RSAs attract savings from other less concessionally taxed savings vehicles.)

26. The ISC will recoup the costs of regulating RSAs through an annual levy on institutions offering RSAs. The annual levy should be comparable to the existing levy imposed on superannuation funds (currently a basic levy of $200 for each $500,000 in a fund, up to a maximum levy of $14,000). The exact details will be finalised in consultation with industry.
Recommendations
27. I recommend that Cabinet agree:
(a) that banks, building societies, credit unions and life offices be allowed to provide Retirement Savings Accounts (RSAs) without a trust structure;
(b) that all RSAs be required to be capital guaranteed;
(c) that RSA providers be supervised in accordance with the regulatory regime outlined in Attachment B;
(d) that RSAs be subject to taxation treatment as outlined in Attachment C;
(e) that I be authorised to bring forward the legislation necessary to give effect to these proposals after appropriate consultation with industry; and
(f) that I announce these initiatives at Budget time by way of a public statement along the lines of Attachment A.
