ATTACHMENT B
REGULATORY REGIME TO APPLY TO RSA PROVIDERS
This attachment provides detail on the proposed regulatory regime for RSAs.

2. The supervision of RSAs can be split into two parts: relevant prudential supervision for institutional soundness, and ISC functional supervision for compliance with retirement income and other superannuation standards.
Prudential Supervision of Proposed RSA providers

3. Banks are required to operate within a prudential framework which covers, among others, minimum capital requirements and liquidity management. Banks are prudentially supervised by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) under the Banking Act 1959. Contributions to bank RSAs would become part of the bank's deposit base and balance sheet, and subject to the present prudential framework applying to their other business.

4. For building societies and credit unions, contributions to RSAs would also be part of the deposit base and balance sheet, and would be subject to State based supervision by the Australian Financial Institutions Commission (AFIC). (The eligibility of friendly societies to offer RSAs will be reviewed if they come under AFIC supervision.) Minimum operating standards for these institutions are broadly similar to those applying to banks. The RSA business of building societies and credit unions would be subject to the present prudential framework applying to their other business.

5. Contributions to life office RSAs would be channelled directly to a life office statutory fund and subject to ISC supervision under the Life Insurance Act 1995. Life offices are required to meet capital adequacy and other appropriate prudential standards, although on a different basis to those applying to banks, reflecting the different nature of the industry. The RSA business of life offices would be subject to the present prudential framework applying to their other business.

6. Complying superannuation funds are supervised using a trust arrangement by the ISC under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision Act 1993 (SIS Act). These arrangements would continue and would permit public offer complying superannuation funds to offer products broadly equivalent to an RSA if they so wished.
Retirement Income and Non‐Prudential Superannuation Standards

7. RSAs will generally be required to comply with retirement income and other non‐prudential superannuation standards currently outlined in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (SIS Act), income tax legislation and so on. These rules are quite detailed and the proposed treatment is outlined below. New legislation will be required to give effect to these measures.
Eligibility Rules/Contributions

8. RSAs will be subject to the same eligibility rules for contributions as currently set out in the SIS Act, Superannuation Guarantee (SG contributions for their employees, but the account should be held in the name of the employee, and the employer would not be allowed to prevent the employee from transferring the balance to another RSA or superannuation product.

9. In this context, RSAs would have to comply with the rules which currently refer to the eligibility of an individual to contribute (or have contributions made on their behalf) to a regulated superannuation fund, as currently outlined in Regulation 7.04 of the SIS Act (although under announced Government policy, these rules are likely to be relaxed). Currently, a regulated superannuation fund may generally accept contributions that are made in respect of a member who is under age 65 only if the member is in part‐time or full‐time gainful employment. "Part‐time" means gainful employment for at least 10 hours, and less than 30 hours, each week and `gainful employment' means employment or self‐employment for gain or reward in any business trade, profession, vocation, calling, occupation or employment.
10. There are several exceptions to this general rule such that:
(a) a member may contribute for up to two years after ceasing part‐time or full‐time gainful employment;
(b) a member may contribute if he or she ceased full‐time or part‐time gainful employment because of ill‐health (whether physical or mental); and

(c) a member on authorised leave from his or her employer in order to raise children may contribute for up to 7 years. The member must have a statutory or contractual right to resume employment at the end of the leave. He or she must have been a member of the fund immediately before going on leave, or the employer be a standard employer‐sponsor of the fund.
Investment Restrictions

11. Complying superannuation funds and life offices are not permitted to `gear up' their assets by borrowing, or to lend money to, or acquire certain assets from, members of a fund. It would not be appropriate or practicable for banks, building societies or credit unions to be subject to these restrictions because RSAs will not be segregated from other borrowing and lending activities of the institution. These rules will still continue to be relevant for RSAs provided by life offices.

12. The prohibition on funds allowing members to secure borrowings against their superannuation benefits will apply to RSAs. Institutions will not be permitted to make loans to RSA account holders secured against assets in an RSA account. RSAs offered by banks will not be permitted to be subject to any account combination arrangements, or interest offsetting arrangements.
RSA Returns and Investment Rules

13. RSA products provided by banks, building societies and credit unions will be intermingled with other deposits and invested in the traditional manner (eg. cash, securities, and lending against secure assets). Such RSAs would, therefore, effectively be `capital guaranteed', low risk/low return financial products. Some equity investments by banks in non‐financial businesses are possible under recently amended Reserve Bank prudential rules, but these are subject to limits and are likely to remain small in the foreseeable future.

14. This treatment implies that bank, building society and credit union RSAs would earn a rate of return broadly equivalent to that of a bank deposit. These institutions may choose to offer RSAs with a fixed interest rate (like a term deposit) or a variable rate. In general, RSAs could be expected to yield lower returns than a typical balanced fund (which invests in a wider range of assets, including equities and property).

15. To ensure that investors are aware of the returns on RSAs and can compare them to other products, RSAs should be required to report returns to account holders on a similar basis to other superannuation products, rather than use a standard bank statement. In addition, the low risk/low return nature of an RSA would need to be adequately drawn to the investor's attention at the time an account is opened.

16. Current investment rules for life office statutory funds enable life offices to invest in higher yielding `growth' portfolios with property and stock market exposures. Superannuation funds also can invest in such portfolios. Hence, life office and superannuation products could potentially be riskier, market linked products, with potentially higher rates of return.

17. In the absence of any restriction on life office investments, this would mean that RSAs sold by different agencies would be effectively two different products, notwithstanding the same generic name. This has considerable potential to cause confusion for consumers and is almost certain to give rise to `competitive neutrality' arguments by banks, credit unions and building societies.

18. To overcome this problem it is proposed that all RSAs would be required to be `capital guaranteed'. (Life offices and public offer superannuation funds already offer `capital guaranteed products.) If necessary, this issue could be reviewed following the outcome of the Financial System Inquiry.
Addressing the Expected Lower Returns from RSAs

19. As RSAs are likely to provide lower returns than other superannuation products, end benefits provided by RSAs will often be lower than provid ed by other `accumulation style' superannuation vehicles.

20. It is often argued that low, stable returns are inappropriate for superannuation, which is a long term investment. However, RSAs should be seen as a low cost/low risk niche product which may suit people with small balances or who are nearing retirement.

21. In view of the low return nature of RSAs, they would not be a suitable vehicle in which to accumulate superannuation savings over the whole of a person's working life. Modelling indicates that an increase in real returns from two to four per cent would increase a person's final benefits by about 60 per cent, from approximately five times their final salary to eight times their salary over a typical working life. There is, therefore, a strong case for encouraging RSA amounts to be transferred to higher yielding `balanced' funds at certain monetary levels. There are two options for dealing with this issue. One option is to require that the institution providing the RSA advise the account holder to assess alternative higher yielding superannuation investment opportunities when an RSA account balance reached a certain amount (say $10,000). This could be accomplished by a compulsory notice to RSA investors which describes switching options. This is the proposed approach.

22. The alternative is to require funds to be transferred out of an RSA once certain monetary levels are reached. However, this would be paternalistic, commercially intrusive and difficult to enforce. For example, people would, if they wished, be able to open a new RSA account before the limit was reached. Enforcing the use of Tax File Number linkages to ensure that people only operated one RSA could be effective, but would be cumbersome, expensive and intrusive on TFN policy. In addition, it would be inappropriate for members close to retirement, as RSA products could be used as part of a risk reduction strategy.
Tax File Number Reporting

23. Proposed amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 will require superannuation funds to collect Tax File Number (TFN) particulars from members and will enable TFNs to be passed between funds on the transfer of members' benefits, and to the Commissioner of Taxation. To ensure RSA accumulated amounts can be readily transferred to and from superannuation funds, and that RSA account holders can be identified, TFN reporting provisions will also apply to RSAs on the same voluntary basis as for other transactions.
Benefit Payment Rules/Preservation/Vesting

24. Benefit payments would be subject to the same tax treatment and Reasonable Benefit Limits that apply to existing superannuation payments, including the related record keeping requirements. Further, the same conditions of early release (such as in cases of financial hardship, or permanent departure overseas) would also apply. These rules are currently contained in the SIS Act and Income Tax legislation. Preservation and vesting rules for amounts paid into RSAs would be fully consistent with those which apply to other types of superannuation funds.

25. Deposit taking institutions which provided RSAs would be permitted to pay RSA benefits in the form of allocated pensions and lump sums only. The provision of ordinary pensions would be problematic as this would mean that banks, building societies and credit unions would be accepting mortality risk (for example, the risk of having to pay out a life pension greater than the value of the accumulated contribution and earnings, if say beneficiaries live longer than expected). Taking such risk is not readily compatible with the nature of a deposit taking institution. As RSAs will form part of the institution's deposits, any such risk would be borne by all depositors. (This issue is further discussed in paragraphs 8 and 9 of Attachment D under Constitutional issues.) RSAs offered by life offices would not face this restriction and could provide benefits in the form of an ordinary pension or annuity. This issue could be reviewed in the light of the findings of the Financial System Inquiry.
Disclosure/Member Reporting Requirements

26. It will be necessary to put in place an appropriate information disclosure regime. This could be set out in legislation or in an ISC determination enabled by legislation. There is already a determination in place for public offer superannuation funds and approved deposit funds in certain circumstances.

27. Any departures from the standard superannuation disclosure regime would require very careful consideration. However, in view of the capital guaranteed nature of RSAs, it may be appropriate for RSAs to have less onerous marketing and prospectus requirements than other forms of superannuation. At a minimum, ongoing disclosure could cover contact information, annual account balance and amount deposited, annual and historic earnings/crediting rates, and fees and charges.

28. RSA providers would also have to give prospective depositors sufficient `point of sale' information to understand the main features and benefits of the RSA, including fees and charges, the low risk, low return nature of the product, and an indication that account holders have the right to request further information.
Registering of RSA providers

29. RSA providers would not need to be licensed under the Corporations Law, as they are covered by alternative arrangements. This is provided there is appropriate point of sale disclosure and the RSA is sold by the institution's employees and not by an agent on the institution's behalf. These issues will be dealt with in the disclosure regime to be put in place by the ISC. It would seem to be appropriate, however, for all RSA providers to meet at least the capital adequacy requirements applying to a public offer, complying superannuation fund, namely that the custodian of fund assets must have minimum net tangible assets of at least $5 million. Currently, some small building societies and credit unions may not meet these requirements. An authorisation process undertaken by the ISC would be necessary. This process would include an assessment that the institution's proposed systems and staff training will be adequate to ensure compliance with retirement income and other superannuation standards.
Member Protection Rules for Small Amounts

30. RSAs will be subject to the `member protection' rules in the SIS legislation, for amounts less than $1000. For such amounts, fees and charges are not normally permitted to exceed interest credits to the account (the main exception is life insurance premiums). RSAs should provide investors with the same protection in this regard as public offer superannuation funds.
Portability/Choice of Fund

31. RSAs should be required to be fully portable (subject to any fixed term for interest payments on the deposit account). That is, an RSA provider should be required to transfer part or whole of an account balance to another RSA or superannuation fund at the account‐holder's request. Such money should remain subject to preservation rules.

32. An issue which will require further consideration, in the context of a review of portability more generally, is whether there should be any restrictions on exit fees or on up front fees/commissions that RSA providers can levy in the event of such transfers. In general, fees should only reflect legitimate administrative and investment costs and should be disclosed when the account is established.

33. Employees should be free to move from an RSA to another approved account of their choice, without leaving their existing employer, although choice of fund for new contributions will need to be exercised together with the employer where Superannuation Guarantee contributions or other employer contributions are to be made into that superannuation fund.
Complaints Handling

34. It is desirable to have a uniform approach to complaints handling for RSAs. In addition, the mechanisms for dealing with complaints about RSAs should be efficient and easily understood by all parties. The present diversity of dispute resolution schemes covering proposed RSA providers makes this problematic, and in the case of building societies, the scheme is only in the early stage of development.

35. The preferred option will be for all superannuation products to be subject to the existing ISC complaint processes for public offer superannuation funds. This would bring them under the jurisdiction of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal (SCT). However, the SCT already faces substantial work load pressures. This issue may need to be addressed should extending coverage to RSAs increase the SCT's workload significantly.
Responsible Entity and Penalties

36. A key feature of the SIS regime is that every regulated superannuation fund must have a `responsible' entity—that is a trustee—who is primarily responsible for the viability and prudent operation of the fund. The `responsible entity' concept ensures that trustees are fully accountable for any discretionary benefit payments made by the fund (eg. death and disability benefits) and are clearly liable for any gross negligence or international or reckless non‐compliance with the SIS standards. This framework of accountability is enhanced by the requirement for equal numbers of employer and employee representatives on the trustee boards of employer‐sponsored funds and for ISC approval of trustees of public offer superannuation funds.

37. To the extent that RSAs provide ancillary benefits to members, there will need to be both a responsible entity to make decisions about whether to pay such benefits in particular instances; and some entity with the financial institution will need to rake responsibility for ensuring that the SIS retirement income standards are complied with more generally.

38. One possibility would be to make the Board of Directors of the institution responsible for these matters (they in turn could delegate decision‐making authority but not responsibility down the line). To enhance this process, the Board could be required to establish a `compliance committee' which would be accountable for compliance with RSA legislative provisions.

39. Legislation would provide for the enforcement of penalties through the courts against the Board where an RSA provider breached the operating standards. Attorney‐General's Department advice is that the Commonwealth, under the Corporations power of the Constitution, could impose a regulatory regime for the provision of RSAs that involved the imposition of direct penalties on the responsible entity' of institutions offering RSAs for breaches of its regulatory requirements. Compliance with the regulatory regime by State banks (if any) offering RSAs could be negotiated voluntarily with the States or promoted through the tax system (al though any withdrawal of taxation concessions, as may be necessary because of breaches of superannuation legislation, would impact on RSA account holders, rather than the institution).

40. Given the public offer nature of RSAs there would be no requirement for equal representation on the `responsible entity' of the RSA provider. New entrants would be required to register with the ISC, and market players required to report annually, inter alia, the names of the relevant directors and to certify compliance with the SIS retirement income standards (including that a compliance and financial audit) had been undertaken by an approved external auditor.
Life and disability insurance
41. RSA providers should be permitted to offer life and disability insurance to RSA account holders subject to existing prudential requirements.
ATTACHMENT C
TAXATION TREATMENT OF RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS
This attachment examines the appropriate taxation treatment that should apply to RSAs provided by banks, building societies, credit unions, life offices and complying superannuation funds.
Taxation Treatment of RSAs
Objectives

2. The inclusion of RSAs on the balance sheet of a financial institution will have an impact on the taxation treatment that is provided for RSAs. It suggests that a financial institution would not be required to establish a separate entity to operate RSAs but could operate RSAs as part of its `general' business.
3. There are several objectives for the design of the taxation treatment of RSAs:

(a) That superannuation contributions made to an RSA, investment income credited to RSAs, and withdrawals from RSAs are taxed, as far as possible, interest he same manner as comparable superannuation transactions with a superannuation fund. (This requires the applicant of the superannuation taxation rate of 15 per cent to relevant contributions and investment earnings credited to RSAs, as well as appropriate tax arrangements for withdrawals);
(b) That RSAs offered by different financial institutions are taxed, as far as possible, in a consistent manner; and

(c) That the tax measures for RSAs should not confer any tax or commercial advantages to financial institutions which operate RSAs, compared to entities conducting traditional superannuation business.

4. However, the taxation treatment of RSAs needs to be incorporated into the taxation treatment applying to each type of financial institution. As explained below, this places some restrictions on the degree of consistency that can be achieved in the taxation treatment of RSAs operated by different financial institutions.
Possible Tax Design
5. The taxation of RSAs within any financial institution using a balance sheet approach involves two steps.
Step One
The first step is to calculate the taxable income of the financial institution as follows:
(a) Assessable income, which would include all earnings generated from RSA funds, including any fees derived from RSA account holders, less:

(b) Allowable deductions, which would include all amounts actually credited (as opposed to amounts accrued at a particular date) to each individual's RSA account during the financial year and any expenses incurred by the financial institution in undertaking RSA business.

This will generate a similar taxable income for RSA business to that arising for a deposit taking financial institution on ordinary deposit business. This will ensure that the financial institution is assessed at its relevant rate on its profit margin from operating RSA deposits, but not on the investment earnings credited to RSAs.

6. However, the rate of tax that will apply to the taxable income from RSA business will vary as it is governed by the `normal' tax rate applying to the type of financial institutions offering the account. The tax rates are:
(a) for a bank, building society and non‐mutual life office—the company tax rate (36 per cent);
(b) for a large credit union—20 per cent in 1996‐97 and 36 per cent thereafter (reflecting the legislated phase up of the taxation rates applicable to large credit unions);
(i) A large credit union is one defined in the tax legislation to generate notional taxable income higher than $150,000 per annum;

(ii) More generous taxation rates apply to medium and small credit unions (though such credit unions may not qualify to register for RSA business if they do not satisfy the capital adequacy requirements proposed in Attachment B);
(c) for a mutual life office 0 39 per cent; and
(d) for a complying superannuation fund—15 per cent.
Step Two

7. The second step is to tax the RSA in the same manner as a superannuation fund, ie at 15 per cent on contributions and investment income (net of expenses). For practical reasons, this taxation would need to be withheld by the financial institution on behalf of the individual account holder. That is, the financial institution would credit a periodic payment (net of expenses) to the RSA account but withhold 15 per cent tax, which it would remit to the Australian Taxation Office. It would also remit 15 per cent tax from `deductible contributions' made to RSAs.

8. This approach assumes that the financial institution would credit RSA accounts with returns net of expenses. However, it would be possible for the financial institution to credit gross returns and debit the RSA account with fees to cover expenses. In this case the fees would be deductible in determining the tax liability of the RSA account holder in step two, and the fees must be reflected in the assessable income of the financial institution in step one.
Assessment of the Tax Design
9. A balance sheet approach is a relatively simple method of calculating the tax on RSA business. In relation to the tax liability described above in step one:
(a) for a bank, building society, credit union or complying superannuation funds, the calculation would be part of the normal calculation of taxable income for the financial institution;

(b) for a life insurance company, the calculation would be part of the calculation of the taxable income arising on the ordinary life insurance business in the case of a mutual and the non‐statutory fund component in the case of a non‐mutual.
In relation to the tax to be withheld by each financial institution under step two on behalf of RSA account holders, an additional, but relatively simple, calculation would be required.

10. However, the proposed tax treatment for RSAs assumes that all the expenses incurred in relation to the RSA business are incurred by the financial institution, and matched against its assessable income. This approach affects the taxation rate that will be applicable to the deduction and will result in each type of financial institution attracting deductions at their appropriate tax rate (as set out in paragraph 6)., rather than the 15 per cent complying superannuation fund tax rate.

11. The proposed taxation design raises a broader concern that inefficiencies will arise from the applicant of different taxation rates and other taxation arrangements to the RSA business of different types of financial institutions. However, the proposed taxation treatment for RSAs is merely extending the taxation arrangements that presently apply to various parts of the financial industry. For instance, for tax purposes, banks currently return interest on an accruals basis whereas life offices and superannuation funds return interest on a cash basis. Other policy work is currently being undertaken address such distortions in the tax treatment of the financial sector. A review of the tax treatment of financial arrangements generally is well progressed and other reviews on the tax treatment of leasing transactions and life insurance are being undertaken. For example, a desirable outcome of the current review of the taxation of life insurance would be that the trustee rate be aligned with the company tax rate. This would reduce differences in the tax rates applying to RSA business conducted by different types of financial institutions.

12. Under the proposed arrangement there would appear to be little opportunity for the financial institution to manipulate the calculation of taxable income to gain a taxation advantage from the lower tax rate applying under step two. This is because the financial institution would claim all deductions at its relevant tax rate and thus gain no additional advantage from `shifting' expenses to the RSA business. As the concessional tax rate of 15 per cent will only apply to amounts credited by the financial institution to individual RSA accounts (amounts which are able to be audited), there would appear to be little scope for the financial institution to gain a taxation advantage for itself.
Example of the Taxation fo the RSA Business
Assumptions

On the first day of its year of income, an eligible financial institution receives contributions for its RSA business of $300,000, comprising deductible contributions of $100,000 and non‐deductible contributions of $200,000. It invests or on‐lends this money for a 10 per cent per annum return and incurs expenses of $5,000. It credits RSA account holders with a net pre‐tax return of $20,000.
Step One Tax—Taxable Income of the Financial Institution from RSA business
(a) Or the relevant tax rate for the financial institution
Step Two Tax—Tax withheld on behalf of RSA account holders
Taxation Treatment of RSA Account Holders

13. At the time that an RSA account holder withdraws money from an RSA account, the individual should receive the same tax treatment as a person receiving an Eligible Termination Payment (ETP) or an allocated pension. This would require the financial institution to keep records in relation to each RSA account holder of the undeducted contributions, and of the eligible service period in relation to ETPs that are rolled into RSAs so as to provide the necessary information to enable the account holder to calculate the rate of tax applicable to each component of the amount withdrawn.
ATTACHMENT D
Constitutional Issues
This attachment outlines several constitutional issues which may arise in the implementation of RSAs.
Direct Penalties and State Banking

2. First, there is the question of whether the Commonwealth Parliament can legislate to provide for the imposition of direct penalties on State `responsible entitles'—that is, State banks, building societies and credit unions—where the RSAs provided by those institutions breached the standards contained within SIS or equivalent legislation.

3. Attorney‐General's Department advice is that direct penalties could be imposed on banks (other than State banks), building societies and credit unions. The Parliament cannot impose restrictions directly on State banks in relation to the operation of RSAs. This is because the Commonwealth cannot make laws in relation to `State banking'. `State banking' is the business of banking conducted by a bank owned or controlled by a State. Under section 51(xxxvii) of the Constitution, a State may refer its banking power, in relation to a State bank, to the Commonwealth, as has been done several times to date. QIDC is the only State bank currently operating in Australia.
Constitutional Interpretation of `Banking'

4. Second, Attorney‐General's Department has advised that on the basis of ordinary principles of Constitutional interpretation, the High Court would be likely to give a broad meaning to the Constitutional concepts of `banking'. It therefore seems possible that the provision of an RSA could constitute `banking' in the Constitutional sense, at least to the extent that it involved taking money on deposit and repaying a like sum (or an amount or amounts bearing some predetermined mathematical relationship to that sum) to the depositor or his or her personal representatives.

5. Thus, institutions other than banks which provide RSAs could be in breach of the Banking Act 1959 unless an exemption were given under section 11 of that Act to allow such institutions to carry on any banking business in Australia (but not the general business of banking). Building societies and credit unions are already provided with a general section 11 exemption by virtue of being registered under the Financial Corporations Act 1974. However, life offices and superannuation funds which want to provide RSAs may need to obtain a section 11 exemption. This can be given by the Treasurer, by order published in the Gazette, can apply to a specific group and may be made subject to any necessary conditions which are specified in the exemption order.
Constitutional Interpretation of `Insurance'

6. Third, Attorney‐General's Department has advised that on the basis of ordinary principles of Constitutional interpretation, the High Court would be likely to give a broad meaning to the Constitutional concepts of `insurance'. It therefore seems possible that the provisions of an RSA could constitute `insurance' in the Constitutional sense to the extent that it involved the acceptance of risk by a financial institution. This issue can be resolved by ensuring that banks, building societies and credit unions only pay out allocated pensions (e.g. where there is no risk of having to pay a pension to a client greater than the value of the accumulated contributions and earnings).

7. Therefore, in line with existing restrictions on the type of liability commitments that institutions may incur, it is proposed that RSAs offered by deposit taking institutions be limited to products that do not involve incurring any mortality risk or risks associated with defined benefits in their payouts. Such RSAs will be accumulation accounts (benefits will broadly be the accumulation of contributions plus net earnings on those contributions) and will pay out benefits in a form that does not involve mortality risk, namely as lump sums or allocated pensions. In addition, as an RSA is an individual account, even a life office could not provide risk cover on it. Such cover would need to be purchased separately from a life office using member contributions.
ATTACHMENT E
Required Legislative Amendments

Allowing institutions to offer RSAs will require a separate Bill amending the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and any other affected tax legislation. A number of other issues relating to respective treatment of deposit accounts or superannuation fund moneys, also need resolution, including for example:
(a) treatment of RSAs in respect of eligibility for social security;
(b) arrangements for dealing with unclaimed benefits;
(c) bankruptcy; and
(d) identification requirements on opening an RSA.

2. There may be several other similar issues that have not yet been identified. The principle to be used in their resolution will be to ensure that treatment for RSAs be as consistent as possible with that applying to existing superannuation products except as outlined in Attachment B. Subject also to the outcome of the Financial System Inquiry, new legislation will be required to provide a general regulatory regime for RSA providers, covering aspects other than institutional prudential supervision. The relevant Acts are as follows:
(a) Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993;
(b) Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993;
(c) Banking Act 1959;
(d) Social Security Act 1991;
(e) Cash Transactions Reports Act 1988; and

ATTACHMENT F
Coordination Comment
Department of Finance

Finance supports the proposal to allow certain financial intermediaries to offer Retirement Savings Accounts (RSAs) as a means of increasing competition and choice for consumers in the area of superannuation.

RSAs provide an alternative to the Superannuation Holding Accounts Reserve (SHAR) administered by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in which small amounts are accumulated, without the value being eroded by fees and charges. RSAs should thus replace the need to continue this arrangement and it would be appropriate to review the ongoing necessity for SHAR and associated administrative costs in ATO prior to the 1998‐99 Budget.
Unlike savings invested in normal superannuation funds, savings in RSAs will be subject to State taxes such as financial institutions duty tax. This may present a revenue windfall to States.

We note that the National Commission of Audit considers existing superannuation arrangements as unnecessarily complex and in need of simplification, and recommends the Government should undertake a comprehensive review of options for improving the contributions of household saving to national saving, including in the area of superannuation. While this proposal creates a simpler superannuation product for consumers, it does not address the broader inherent complexities in superannuation arrangements.
Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet
The Department supports the Submission's recommendations.
Department of Social Security
DSS supports the recommendations at paragraph 27, sub‐paragraphs (a), (b),(c), (d), (e) and (f).
Impact on age and service pension outlays

The submission notes at paragraph 18 that `RSAs are expected to be a relatively low return form of superannuation savings, . . . not generally suitable vehicles for accumulating superannuation savings over a whole lifetime'. The effectiveness of the proposed $10,000 `voluntary' cap might be reviewed at a later date to ensure that Government targets for the future containment of age and service pension outlays are not compromised.
Competitive neutrality

DSS notes that the proposal, if implemented, would increase competition within the superannuation market, but differentiate between competitors in some respects. Complying superannuation funds would operate RSA `equivalents' under the trustee structure, which, it is argued, imposes higher administration costs than other business structures. Complying superannuation funds would be subject to limitations on the assets in which they could invest, reducing the returns they might otherwise achieve for investors. Different types of institutions would be subject to different rates of tax on their taxable income.

The impact of such differentiation, to the extent that it exists after the Financial System Inquiry and the current review of the tax treatment of financial arrangements, should be reviewed in the light of experience with the operation of RSAs.
RSAs opened by employers

DSS notes employers' legitimate concerns about being required to deal with many financial institutions if RSAs are introduced. However, permitting employers to open RSAs on behalf of employees may limit consumer choice and, for transient workers, result in multiple small accounts.

Many employers already pay salary and wages into accounts nominated by employees and it should be quite feasible for these employers to make superannuation contribution payments in the same way. DSS suggests that employers with the requisite capacity be encouraged to permit employees to nominate RSAs of their choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 12, page 50 (after line 3), before item 1 , insert:
Repeal the subsection.
Insert:
(3A) The duty and liability of a director is the same as the duty and liability that would exist if:

PARA.TAB: (a) the directors were trustees of the assets of the statutory fund under a trust for the execution of the provisions of this Part in respect of those assets; and
(b) the owners of policies referable to the fund were beneficiaries under that trust.

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "subsection (2) or (3)", substitute "subsection (2), (3) or (3A)".
Insert:

(4A) The owner of a policy referable to the fund has the same right to institute proceedings against a director in respect of a breach of the duty imposed by this section as the policy owner would have as a beneficiary under the trust referred to in paragraph (3A)(a).

I hope this amendment will be supported by the committee, despite what has been said on the previous amendment that I moved. This amendment seeks to amend the Life Insurance Act 1995 in a number of aspects but the key to it is the insertion of a new clause. The object of the amendment is, as the proposed new 1B of the Life Insurance Act indicates:
The duty and liability of a director is the same as the duty and liability that would exist if:
(a) the directors were trustees of the assets of the statutory fund under a trust for the execution of the provisions of this Part in respect of those assets; and
(b) the owners of policies referable to the fund were beneficiaries under that trust.

That is slightly different to the amendment that I moved previously. This really brings it down to the question of whether we are going to have a level playing field, whether in fact RSAs, which are offered by banks, are going to provide the protection necessary to beneficiaries of amounts of money put aside for employees for superannuation purposes, which of course they need for their old age, for their being disabled or for their widows and orphans.

If these obligations are imposed upon superannuation funds, I think it is fair enough that they be imposed upon other providers in the superannuation regime. I explain to the committee that, where my amendment relates to schedule 12, under 1A I am seeking to have subsection 34(5) of the Life Insurance Act 1995 repealed. That subsection says:

In order to avoid doubt, it is declared that nothing in this Act is intended to constitute a life company or the directors of a life company a trustee or trustees of the assets of the statutory funds of the company.

What I am proposing is really not necessarily that they be constituted in a formal structural manner but that the duties and liabilities of the directors be the same as the duties and liabilities that would exist if the directors were in fact trustees of the assets of the statutory fund under a trust for the execution of the provision of that part of the legislation.
That deals with the addition of 1A, 1B and 1C. In so far as 1D is concerned, I am seeking to have a provision inserted in subsection 48(4) of Life Insurance Act which states:

The owner of a policy referable to the fund has the same right to institute proceedings against a director in respect of a breach of the duty imposed by this section as the policy owner would have as a beneficiary under the trust referred to in paragraph (3A)(a).
As honourable senators will know, section 48 of the Life Insurance Act 1995 refers to the duties of directors in relation to statutory funds. Section 48 states:
(1) A director of a life company has a duty to the owners of policies referable to a statutory fund of the company.
(2) The director's duty is a duty to take reasonable care, and use due diligence, to see that, in the investment, administration and management of the assets of the fund, the life company:
(a) complies with this Part; and
(b) gives priority to the interests of owners and prospective owners of policies referable to the fund.

The key point we are talking about here is to give the utmost protection that is reasonable—I do not know whether it is possible—to the beneficiaries of the RSAs. Without canvassing all the arguments that have been trawled around this place previously on as late as 25 March this year and today, I would like to commend the amendments to the committee.

TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)
