TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make only some brief comments in opposing the third reading of the bills. My colleague Senator Lundy will be making some further comments. We traversed over our in‐principle concern with the concept of RSAs on the occasion when this package of legislation was debated prior to Easter. The Labor Party on that occasion, the Democrats on some occasions, I think the Greens and Senator Harradine, moved a range of amendments—a few of which were carried—and ultimately the legislation that we had before us tonight was defeated.

SPEECH.PARA: I note with some irony that amendments that were passed on that occasion were not passed on this occasion and amendments that were not passed on the last occasion were passed on this occasion. It is an intriguing little set of contradictions that we have had with respect to the amendments to the RSA bills that passed or failed when we considered them six weeks ago and again today.

One of the central concerns for Labor has been the protection of workers' retirement money. It is money that is contributed compulsorily. In a number of elements, the deal between the Democrats and the government fails the principles we enunciated six weeks ago. I do not intend on this occasion to go through those principles again. We have done so time and time again in respect of our consideration of this legislation and, I certainly believe, we have clearly demonstrated that the principles we adhere to in respect of superannuation have not been met by the final package of legislation that has been presented to the Senate today.

First and foremost, Labor has been consistent in its call for the RSA product to be prudentially regulated in a similar manner to traditional superannuation products, recognising of course that banks have a company structure. Credit unions and building societies have a somewhat different structure, but the same principles apply to superannuation currently offered, which is protected by what is regarded as a world leader of prudential regulation; that is, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993.

We do not have one of the great safeguards of superannuation products in respect of RSAs—trustees. We accept that that would not have been a realistic proposition, but adopting the common law trustee duty, as well as the statute law as exemplified by the SI(S) Act, certainly would have provided one of the essential safeguards we sought. We do not believe that in practice the types of protections, the so-called choice options, that have been agreed between the Democrats and the government will offer sufficient protection to Australian workers.
I will conclude my remarks by quoting from a Mr Tom Ross, chairman of the United Kingdom National Association of Pension Funds. In reference to products similar to RSAs he said:

And I think that it's the best illustration I have come across, in the financial world at any rate, that giving people freedom, flexibility and the ability to exercise choice without suitable education and without adequate regulation of those who are purveying the choices is a recipe for disaster.

I hope, colleagues, that the recipe for disaster we see in the superannuation policies of this government does not come to pass. If it is not disaster, it will certainly be a series of legislation, including retirement savings accounts, that will not enhance the retirement income of Australian workers.

Looking at the set of measures we considered earlier in respect of the now‐named tax and at the deeming of superannuation when a person turns 55, the interesting test of these three sets of legislation is: do they provide one dollar extra into Australian workers' superannuation? The answer is very simple. They do not. No-one is better off as a consequence of these three fundamental changes to superannuation legislation in this country. The retirement savings account is but the third very important measure which is detrimental. Not one Australian is one dollar better off as a consequence of these superannuation changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to oppose the third reading of this series of legislation. In doing so, I also want to make a few comments about its failings in the eyes of the workers who are the ones who stand to lose if this legislation is in fact passed.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of issues have been raised by my colleague Senator Sherry. I will touch upon them also. In doing so, I want to basically declare what interest I have in superannuation. It is a personal one that comes about from having been a member of an industry superannuation scheme, from about a month after I started work in the building industry when I was 16.

At that time, the furthest thing from my mind was superannuation or my retirement savings, as I am sure you can all appreciate. My introduction to that superannuation scheme did make me think, as a young person, how important it was not just to try and earn some money at the time but to think about all of these things. At the time in the building industry, it was quite controversial, I suppose, because we were basically looking at wage sacrifice to allow contributions to be made to that industry superannuation scheme. C‐BUS, as it is now known, has gone on to become one of the largest industry superannuation schemes.

Another interest is that my partner is a trustee on that board. I mention that because, from that perspective, I know exactly what the trustee's role is in industry superannuation and how important the amendment put forward by Labor, and a similar one put forward by Senator Harradine, is to ensuring that these fiduciary responsibilities of the directors of these RSAs are overridden by the same requirements as are provided by trustees for the members of superannuation funds. Both those amendments have failed and, in their failure, have left the interests of workers at the mercy of the banks.

I think there are not too many people out there that would actually feel some comfort in the banks having complete control over their money in this regard. We only need to look at what has happened with fees and charges in an unregulated environment to see whose interests the banks represent. There is now no adequate protection of members' money. The opportunity was there for the government to do that in a variety of ways, including our amendments placing restrictions on fees and charges for the RSA product.

Not supporting that amendment was a gift to the banks—nothing more. It is another way in which they can produce more profits in the interests of their shareholders, not gains in the interests of members who take out these RSA accounts. It opens up a whole new area for the banks and allows them to move into a market in which they had not previously operated, and it does so at the expense of industry funds. Industry funds, I have to say, offer more to members than just a simple superannuation product that provides a reasonable return to members. They offer a lot more in the sense that their investment policies are certainly generally geared towards the interests of members, but they are also geared towards the interests of the industry from which they seek their membership and cover in terms of membership.

The industry funds also look towards the needs of their members. In a large number of cases they offer supplementary benefits for membership, including death cover, disability insurance and so forth. As is the nature of the building industry, which is the example I am using, because employment is so transient and members and workers in this industry can expect some periods of unemployment, these benefits carry on if employer contributions cease for a short period of time. So the insurance provided by these schemes extends beyond the actual point at which an employment contract exists. These benefits came about not because the super funds came up with a good idea, but because they responded to the needs of members. How are RSAs going to do that? They are not structured on an industry basis. They are not structured in a way that is responsive to the needs of their members. They are structured in a way that is wholly and solely controlled by the boards in the interests of the shareholders.

Let me turn to the issue of choice—a pet subject of this government. It is a subject on which we hear lots of rhetoric, but we are yet to hear any substance. We have heard Minister Kemp talk about choice, both now and the previous time this legislation was debated, but here we have no choice. How can you say there is choice in a member or a worker opting for a RSA when, if no clarification is sought by the member, the default position is payment of their contribution into an RSA and not into a superannuation fund or an industry fund? That is not choice. It is about giving the banks a gift. It is about exploiting the perhaps complacency of some members who feel quite secure in their indus try fund and are confident that their retirement savings are building up with an adequate interest rate and with their interests at heart. It is exploiting that complacency—complacency that has been built up with good reason because of the success of some of the major industry funds.

Apart from RSAs denying workers real choice in their superannuation fund in that regard, they also leave casual workers, part‐time workers and lower income workers at a disadvantage. When you have transient employment, another bout of paperwork is quite often the furthest thing from your mind. When you transfer from one job to another it is hard enough forwarding your address and your details and changing your accounts and all the rest that comes with changing jobs. It is ironic that this government talks about cutting red tape for small business in this regard. We have had an increase in red tape for the workers, the consumers, who have to concern themselves with changing jobs and changing super. That applies not just to the application of an industry fund, if that is what they pursue, but also to managing what could perhaps become a multitude of RSAs under different employers.

The other issue with respect to this choice is that the workers that I have just mentioned are quite often women. It is quite often women who have the part‐time jobs, the casual jobs and the lower paid jobs. It is quite often the case that women may not have preoccupied themselves with issues relating to superannuation because of the nature of their employment. In recent times women have started to take an interest in this. Statistically, you do not need to look too far back to see how successful Labor's policies were in getting women involved in superannuation and interested in their own retirement incomes. RSAs undermine this progress. They undermine it in a way that will for ever, from here on in, once again put these people at a disadvantage.

The last thing I would like to say on this issue is what it does to superannuation and the confidence that people generally have in superannuation. I mentioned this matter when the previous superannuation legislation—the surcharge bill, now the tax bill—was debated. The tax bill went a long way toward undermining the confidence of the community in the superannuation product. This RSA legislation takes that one step further. Not only can you not have confidence that your savings will be intact if your income is over the $70,000 level, but also, just to make sure the other end of the stick is disadvantaged, you can have an RSA account as well.

Everything that this government has done has undermined the role of superannuation as a viable retirement savings option. It is unfair. It is not about choice. It is about a gift to the banks. I for one do not believe it is the banks that need assistance at this point in time; it is working people who need to have a bit of faith and a bit of confidence in the superannuation product. Unfortunately, they will not be satisfied when this legislation goes through.

Nothing has been resolved in the deal the Democrats have done with the government. The issues of concern have not been answered, they have not been addressed. The crucial amendments have not been supported. That is why we on the Labor side find ourselves opposing this third reading. As I have said, we oppose it for very good reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reiterate this issue of whether or not workers are actually going to get anything out of this. As I said before, it really comes down to the rate of interest these things are going to earn. Senator Lundy talked about promoting choice and the benefit for workers. I have heard the Treasurer (Mr Costello) say that there are going to be big benefits for savings and for families in the budget tomorrow night.
—You are not worried, are you?
—No, I would not be worried. I know who should be worried—and they probably are—and that is most of the people in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Someone who earns $400 a week—on the high end of the wages level for people who are more likely to be affected by this legislation—and makes a five per cent contribution to superannuation will in the first year have $1,040 contributed into their scheme or into some form of saving. If we take interest rates as they stood for the ANZ high performance passbook account in November 1996—and they have not gone up—the rate of interest for amounts between $1 and $1,990 was one‐quarter of one per cent.

Senator Allison, I hope you can explain to a lot of people after they have had five years worth of $1,040 why they are still earning only half of one per cent. I hope you can explain to them after they have had 20 years worth why the amount of money they have contributed into an RSA has grown very little.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're off the planet. He's off the planet.
—Minister, if I am off the mark—
—`Off the planet,' I said.

—If I am off the planet, then why don't you stand up and explain to me how people are actually going to receive any real benefit from the point of view of interest, given that the compounding rates of interest for superannuation schemes are at least, even with some of the poorer performing schemes, a long way better than one‐quarter of one per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of other benefits, most superannuation schemes provide a death benefit and disability benefits. You are not going to get those with RSAs and yet, as has been pointed out time and again, workers will be forced to take them out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—Minister, you say, `Oh!'—
—I am saying you are dead wrong; that's all.

—That is not dead wrong. I made the point before with regards to the existing arrangements that some employers—not all; most of them are fairly good—force workers to enter into superannuation schemes that are not of an industry nature or are the designated fund for that particular form of employment. That is what happens.

BREAK.PARA: You cannot tell me that some employers will not—I am not saying that all of them will—force workers to enter into an arrangement with their bank because they will be able to do a deal with that bank with regards to other factors of their financing. That is what will happen. There is nothing in your legislation that stops that from happening—nothing at all.

If you look at it from an industrial relations point of view, you do not even have any process where people can be protected. It was difficult enough under the old industrial relations act to get around and ensure that workers received appropriate protection and that their moneys were being paid into the places where they ought to be paid into. Since then you have changed the act to preclude the rights of, I suppose, the only people who really had an opportunity and did go out and represent workers—that was the unions. You now preclude them from doing their job.

I say to Senator Allison and her colleagues that I hope at the end of the day they will be able to explain why they have supported legislation that is going to deliver a worse financial deal for workers and their families in this country. Maybe at some point in time you may consider changing your mind about the whole process and get rid of this.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the bills be now read a third time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

BREAK.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received a letter from Senator Short resigning his place as a senator for the state of Victoria. Pursuant to the provisions of section 21 of the constitution, I have notified the Governor of Victoria of the vacancy in the representation of that state caused by the resignation. I table the documents.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the committee does not insist upon its amendments disagreed to by the House of Representatives.

There have been two High Court actions, seven Federal Court actions, three Supreme Court actions, a royal commission, two inquiries under federal Aboriginal heritage protection legislation, a state inquiry and an investigation by the Environment, Resources and Development Committee of state parliament. Enough is enough. The time has come for the Hindmarsh Island Bridge affair to be brought to an end once and for all.

The Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill has now been before the parliament since October last year—almost eight months. Since then, the bill has been debated extensively first in the House of Representatives, then in the Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee, then not once but twice in the Senate itself and then once more in the House of Repre sentatives. No-one could say that the issues have not been comprehensively examined.

Moreover, Labor has always said that the bridge should go ahead but, perversely, it had until recently refused to support the bill. Even when Mr Beazley said that Labor would support the bill even if the government rejected its amendment, the bill was still not passed. So senators will understand the government's considerable frustration at the fact that we are here today yet again debating the bill.

To say the least, there is no need for further extended debate on the matter. All the facts and all the arguments are well known; there is nothing new to add. Legal action has been commenced to force me to appoint another section 10 report. This action is very likely to succeed if it continues. That would result in the preparation of a fifth report. I do not know what that will cost. The Justice Mathews report cost a million dollars of taxpayers' money. There has been an estimate that another report could cost at least $200,000, and there would be no guarantee that it would lead to a finalisation of the matter, given the history of litigation surrounding the affair.

However, the legal actions have been discontinued pending the passage of the bill. My understanding is that the action will recommence if the bill is not passed now. We are presented with one final window of opportunity to apply some commonsense to all of this. It is time to pass the bill without delay. I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The one thing on which I agree with the minister is that I also see no need to prolong the debate here tonight, and I will not do so. Frankly, considering the history of this matter, I would be surprised if any senator was of another view. It is perfectly true that the issue has been comprehensively canvassed in the Senate. What is also true is that right up until this point in time the minister has not provided a cogent reason—or any cogent reasons at all—as to why the powers that are available to him have not been exercised rather than taking this route.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the reason for that has just been given in the minister's use of the word `perverse' in respect of the opposition's position on this piece of legislation. The minister said that the opposition stated clearly and publicly that we had no objection to the bridge itself being built and yet perversely would not support this bill.

That simply indicates that the minister has absolutely no conception of why the opposition and other senators oppose this bill. The reason is that it suspends the operation of a federal piece of legislation designed to protect the places of significance to Aboriginal people for the purpose of this particular construction. It is the first time—and I hope the only time—that it has been done. The bill provides for that expressly. In fact, the only really relevant clause of the bill simply removes this particular proposal from the ambit of that act.

As speaker after speaker after speaker in this debate has pointed out, there is not only clear understanding from reading the legislation itself but also a number of substantive legal decisions that make it absolutely clear that there is no way that the minister can be forced to make a declaration under this act if the minister determines that he will not do so. Indeed, some of those decisions are quite recent ones. That has never been contested by any court. Indeed, it has been confirmed by the highest legal authority in this country that the minister cannot be forced to make that decision.

The reason I make that point is that the operative clause of this bill says that the heritage protection act does not authorise the making of a declaration in relation to the preservation or protection of an area or object from any of the following activities—that is, the construction of the bridge. The minister, if he is so minded, cannot be compelled to do so.

As I said, I can go back to the genesis of this act because I was involved in the events that led to that act being introduced by the then minister for Aboriginal affairs, Clyde Holding. The very first application made under that act to the acting minister for Aboriginal affairs at that time, Susan Ryan, was rejected by the minister. You could hardly get a clearer case to support what I am saying. It was related to the construction of a dam in Western Australia where a sacred site had been damaged.

I do not think it was seriously contested by anyone that the site was damaged. A report was commissioned into the matter which confirmed that. The report was given to the minister that a site had been desecrated. Acting minister Ryan, as she then was, came down with a determination, despite that report, that in the public interest because of the importance of the dam to the local community no declaration for protection would be issued and that the construction of the dam could proceed.

That was the first cab off the rank. The reason for that is very important. The reason was that it was deliberately drafted by the government of the day to provide a degree of protection to sacred sites in Australia at the federal level because of the paucity of such protective legislation at the state level. Again, those who want to have reference to the act will see that deliberately referred to. If the minister is satisfied that state legislation provides sufficient protection, that is sufficient for the minister not to make a declaration under this act. The minister was always given—and deliberately given—by the drafters of the act a determining position in respect of protection.

I did not intend to launch into that explanation once again, but it was the minister's use of the word `perverse' that required me to do so. It is not a perverse position, Minister. I am sorry you cannot understand that there is no contradiction between saying that we have no objection to the bridge going ahead—and I understand that others do, but that is not our position—and at the same time saying that we find this avenue to get it built highly objectionable. We have pressed our case hard in here. We have placed our objections to this on the public record.

The minister made an interesting statement a few moments ago. He said, in respect of the report, that legal action has been taken to compel him to initiate—if he had done so, I might add, it would be finished by now—and he said, `I don't know what it would cost.' As the Hansard record will clearly indicate, he had no difficulty some time ago in throwing around figures of $1 million with gay abandon. A million dollars is not a problem. That was put again and again in here by the minister—six months, 12 months, $1 million.

As the minister knows, when this matter was pursued at Senate estimates—and I was pursuing it, so I know without reference to the Hansard that this, in fact, was the answer given—the officers of ATSIC, who would have been responsible for commissioning the report and paying for it, said that their best estimate based on their experience with these things was that it could have been done in two months at the cost of around $100,000. So I am interested to hear that the minister says tonight that he did not know what it would cost.

The relevant matter—and the minister has touched on it, and I agree with him—is that that legal action would almost certainly have forced the report to be commissioned by the minister. That much of administrative case law I am familiar with. He could not have unreasonably delayed for much longer, I would not have thought, actually commissioning the report. The report would, I suspect, have been completed within that two months.

The report probably would not have cost, in my view, much more than $100,000. I think that figure is about right. Inevitably, as I have said already, at the end of that process it would have been totally open to the minister to have declined to make a declaration for protection under the act. In fact, there is no question at all, in terms of what is already on the public record, that that is precisely what he would have done.

So it is for those reasons that the opposition does not intend tonight to press this matter further. There may well be a legal challenge. I think the absolute lowest point of this debate for me—particularly in the current climate, in the context of public debate in Australia on these issues at the moment—was when the government stated, not once but on several occasions, that they would have been quite confident about using the power given by one of the rare successful referenda in Australia to the federal government to make laws for the benefit of the Aboriginal people of Australia. They would have relied constitutionally for that power on the passage of this legislation.

The reason I mention that is that I do not think a High Court case in the history of the High Court has been misinterpreted deliberately by many people more than the recent decision in Wik. The High Court has been subject to the most extraordinary attacks by the most senior people in public life in Australia, including the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer).

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget Premier Borbidge.

—Indeed, the Premier of the state of Queensland; but relevant to this parliament, the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia was among those attacks. What concerned me profoundly as an Australian, who does have some concern about the institutions that our successful exercise in democracy has in this country, is that those attacks were based on utter nonsense and a total distortion, deliberate in some cases, of the actual decision taken by the High Court in Wik—clearly by people who had not bothered to read the judgments.

SPEECH.PARA: Buried among this diatribe of abuse of the High Court for making allegedly loopy decisions and stupid decisions and decisions that make no sense about the devaluation of the land, Senator Ron Boswell, on the ABC recently, talked about how appallingly disadvantaged pastoralists in Australia had been since the Wik decision because of the devaluation of their land as a result of Wik. It is a piece of nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sultan of Brunei.

—Yes, but can I say, Senator, in respect of your interjection, `The Sultan of Brunei,' absentee Los Angeles dentists—who own another property that I am familiar with—or whoever have, in fact, not lost a dollar in terms of the value of their land from Wik, and I say that authoritatively as somebody who is very close to the workface on this issue. Wik has caused a number of concerns that have to be resolved for pastoralists. One of them is not the value of their land.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that in respect of any decision taken from this action—and a lot of people are anticipating some High Court action in respect of this matter—I hope that whatever decision the High Court may take on this issue is, in fact, carefully considered by people rather than simply being thrown in as another convenient card to play in what is certainly the nastiest and the most divisive race debate that I have witnessed in my 20 years in public life in Australia.

Whatever else you can say about the current debate, from my perspective, particularly from where I come from—and I have seen a few race debates: I have stood up at platforms at `Rights for Whites' meetings on more than one occasion over the years, and that is among a number of organisations that I can recall—I have not seen a more divisive debate at the moment. But if you are going to criticise the High Court, at least criticise it for what it has done, not for what it has not done.

BREAK.PARA: Minister, you may or may not have heard an interview—on Anzac Day, interestingly enough, the 25th of April—on AM with a representative of the Australian Institute of Valuers. This is the institute in Australia which actually advises lending institutions on the value of land. The transcript of the interview is instructive. To all those who are claiming that people's land has been devalued by the Wik decision and that we suddenly have to do things like upgrade the title of pastoral leases right across Australia overnight, that representative of the institute said that nothing of the sort had happened—that the Wik decision had simply confirmed what the institute and banking institutions had known forever, because banking institutions have never lent money on the basis of the value of leasehold land. In fact, the representative of this institute said—and I thought it was instructive—that banks and lending institutions, and indeed his institute, had always based their decisions on the value of land on the actual legal status of the title held by people rather than perceptions by the titleholders as to what they might and might not have.

I must say in the context of this debate, Minister, that this ill-considered diatribe of abuse of the High Court decision in respect of Wik has been almost entirely erroneous and based on absolute nonsense rather than fact. I also know that, from talking to people at the front who are currently negotiating their loans from the banking institutions for the next financial year—and these are from people who do have problems in respect of Wik, particularly those who have multiple claims over their land—the banks have advised them that, as far as the banks are concerned, nothing has changed since Wik in respect of the value of that land, and the bank is placing exactly the same valuation on that land this year as it did last year. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats think that the Senate should insist on the amendments because, as we have said a hundred times already, this legislation discriminates against and takes away the rights of one group of Australians. We have heard all the arguments. It is a bit similar to one part of the Prime Minister's 10‐point proposal on Wik in terms of legislating to take away the rights of one group of Australians. It just happens to be the same group of Australians—Aboriginal Australians. We should think twice. We should not pass discriminatory legislation, no matter how convenient it might be for us.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bob Collins has not told us what the Labor Party is going to do on this, but we all know that it is not going to insist on its amendment to the Racial Discrimination Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did say it.
—I am sorry. I apologise. I must have been distracted when you said that. Was that at the beginning or the end?
—At the beginning.

—We know that the Labor Party is nervous about public comment on this and we know that many Aboriginal people feel especially let down. We will see what comes out of the inevitable High Court challenge. I hope something really important comes out of it, something important to assist us in our deliberations on the powers on which the federal government is relying with respect to the proposed Wik legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not changed our minds. We do not feel under pressure to pass discriminatory legislation. We think the Senate should be insisting on these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly was listening to Senator Bob Collins. He did say a lot of things. I must have blinked or turned away or something when he mentioned what the Labor Party's position was.
—Did you hear it?

—No, it must have just been that second when I lost concentration. However, what we do know is that the only reason this bill is back here is that the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, Mr Beazley, has indicated that Labor will now support the bill with or without the Racial Discrimination Act. The government is saying, `We insist you don't have it,' so we have the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just a backflip; it is a double backflip with pike. The degree of difficulty is that it is not difficult at all because there is an election coming up in South Australia. It is a populist approach. Despite all the strong arguments that have been put from this side of the chamber, it is quite easy for them now to say, `Okay, we'll go along with that. We will discriminate against this group of people in Australia because there's an election coming up'—not because it is the right thing to do, not because they know it is the wrong thing to do, but because there is an election coming up.

They are riding along, unfortunately, with that wave of scapegoatism, with that very wave that was alluded to by Senator Collins that comes along with the Wik decision, that very wave of scapegoatism that allows people to think that the taxpayers ought to, in the end, put their hands in their pockets and give large welfare payments to some of the richest people amongst the largest pastoralists in Australia. That is what it is coming to—riding the wave of scapegoat politics. Whilst we have had criticisms from the Labor Party about what the government is doing in riding the populist wave, here they are on their boogie boards getting on the same wave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not bad for this time of night.

—Sorry, too many metaphors. So we are basically in a situation where any scrap of ethics and any scrap of morality have long since flown. The Greens (WA) have not changed their position. The Ngarrindjeri women have never had a fair go to give their position. It is interesting to see that ATSIC is endeavouring to conduct an inquiry at the moment into changes to the Aboriginal Heritage Act. And guess what? Perhaps the minister might know better, but I do not see that they have been given any extra resources to conduct this, so it looks like this project which is going around Australia to get opinions is fairly under‐resourced.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as I am aware, there is only one hearing in the whole of Western Australia, and hearings are very few and far between in other parts of Australia. That is the way it is going at the moment—pull out the resources from the same group of people, belt them on the head metaphorically and then stand up and hear the cheering from the same group of people who are supporting the member for Oxley. That is what it has come to.

It is all very well for the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to begin to say, `Yes, there are people in this community who have been hurt by economic rationalism.' It is not explained what the decisions were that got them into that position. It is not explained any further what that was all about, and about the fact that both major parties were involved in that. However, we have got the Prime Minister beginning to say that and then saying, `Yes, but we would like to distance ourselves from it.' It looks like both sides of the House are joining in. Both share the blame for creating a divisive society in Australia, and I will not be part of that this time either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on this bill, and I wish to make a couple of points that need to be restated at this particular stage. The first point is that for the bridge to be built no legislation is needed—none at all. That has been established through evidence from the minister himself, Senator Herron, through evidence from ATSIC and through evidence from the Attorney‐General's Department. Even Mr Palyga, acting for the Chapmans, told the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee this at one stage. In fact, Tom Chapman himself told the committee that nothing was legally stopping it. He said there were no legal impediments and that there had not been any impediments since July last year. Mr Palyga said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have been asking . . . repeatedly since the full court decision on 7 December . . . to start constructing the bridge.
That was 7 December last year.

So legislation is not necessary, but what we have to understand about what the government is doing here is the context of it. It has come in with an agenda, which was whispered before the election but which Pauline Hanson has since shouted from the rafters, to play on the prejudices of the Australian community. They did it. They coasted into government and that helped them. When they came into government, they wanted to continue with the agenda and I do not think it is an overexaggeration to say that they used indigenous Australians as a political football.

Senator Herron was jumping out of his skin to appoint an auditor. He was jumping out of his skin to do other things and on every occasion he jumped out of his skin he was put back in it by the Federal Court. That has been the history of this particular minister in this particular portfolio since the election—voices whispering before the election now echoing and reverberating back to government members through the mouth of Pauline Hanson. This legislation was born in that climate and if the Prime Minister was serious about trying to tone down the debate and trying to take some divisiveness out of this community, he would be pulling this legislation because he knows and the minister knows that it is not necessary.

As Senator Collins said earlier today, it would have taken a couple of months and less than $100,000 or thereabouts and they would have had their bridge built, because nothing could have forced the minister to take one position or another and he himself has acknowledged that. If he had really wanted this bridge built, he would have taken that action a good few months ago and there would be no impediment now. But what he has chosen to do and what the Prime Minister has chosen to do is to play politics in a way that not only frustrates the timetable for those who want to build the bridge, but also may very well lay the groundwork for some real constitutional problems in the rest of their anti‐black agenda.

I say that because this bridge could very well have been built—and everyone knows it—under existing legislation without one entry into this parliament. But by taking this particular course, Senator Herron, you have guaranteed that you will be back in the High Court within a week—w‐e‐e‐k. You will be back in the High Court within a very short period of time and you will be back in the High Court with issues that you yourself have admitted that you did not even prepare yourself on. What is the basis of the constitutional power on which you act? We asked you that just a few weeks ago when you first brought in this legislation and you said, `I have got no problem. I haven't prepared. I haven't asked anyone about constitutional problems and power.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.

—That is precisely what you said. Have you taken advice on the constitutional foundation? You said, `No, and I don't need to.' Come in spinner, bowling full tosses! `We don't need special legislation.' Have you taken advice? `No.' You do not know that what you are doing has got some basic constitutional concerns whether it is the race power, or whether it is your playing around with special measures under the international covenant, or the RDA. Senator Herron, you have come into this parliament with this legislation without adequate preparation.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say, as one of those who has taken an interest in this debate, knowing that the minute you became minister the chances of the Aboriginal women in terms of having any say in the process would be dashed, that you have actually played right into the hands of those who have a real concern that this bridge does not get built. You have played it and you have walked into it blindfolded and it has been of your own choosing.

One good thing that will come out of this, Senator Herron, is that this will go to the High Court almost immediately and issues that are critical to the Wik debate will probably be assessed by the High Court—issues as to whether the race power can be used in a way detrimental to a particular race, particularly indigenous Australians; issues such as the duration of a special measure, and whether a special measure can be wound back in the absence of any substantive improvement of the race for which that measure was introduced. They are some of the issues—issues of course as to racial discrimination which I am sure will always come to the attention of the court when it deals with matters like the constitutional ones that I mentioned.

BREAK.PARA: At the same time as this, Senator Herron, you have before you a decision in respect of Boobera Lagoon, a decision for which there is a report recommending against the desecration of the area and about which you have refused to take any action.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's going well.

—`It's going well', he says. Well I heard you on radio 10 days ago saying that you were going to make a decision last week. I said to myself, `That is probably because he thinks Hindmarsh Island will be through next week. He will wait until Hindmarsh Island is through and then he can address Boobera Lagoon and not take the action recommended in the report.' I will bet you London to a brick that is what you are going to do. Once this is through, you will make it very clear that you had absolutely no compulsion on you to act in respect of Boobera Lagoon, but you might do one or two things to try and placate people.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Herron, you know that nothing can force you, but all of us know that you have led with your chin in respect of this legislation. Under existing legislation, the bridge could have been commenced by now. Under your legislation, it will be back in the High Court within just a few days, if not a few hours, and a bridge that could have been built by the end of last year or early this year will not be built until those High Court proceedings are over. You are, in fact, ensuring that construction of the bridge is delayed. Not only will you be held to account for that degree of gross negligence in not preparing yourself on constitutional grounds, but also I am sure the Chapmans will remember you for it. In respect of the Chapmans, let me say to them that, in urging for this legislation, I think they have actually dug themselves into a corner as well.

I go back to the point that this is actually one of the most sleazy and sordid bits of legislation this parliament has seen because there is no justification for it other than for the politics of race and prejudice. That is what has driven this, that is what drives it and that is what continues to drive this minister, who knows no better, and this Prime Minister, who wants no better. I actually think that this is one of the sorrier days in our parliamentary history.

I must admit that, for my part, I only support this legislation because it will finish up in the High Court and those issues that we are so keen to ensure are clarified will be clarified in a way that could probably pre‐empt some of the planks of your 10‐point plan in response to Wik.
I say to you, Senator Herron: do not take our position in respect of the RDA amendment as a precedent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the problem with this legislation includes what has already been mentioned in terms of the indigenous people, but I want to mention the problem for the Australian constitutional system generally.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case, there is an expectation that without this legislation there may have been a challenge over the bridge; that this legislation has anticipated, if you like, judicial proceedings and has stepped in. This is not the first time that has happened. There have been other examples of where people with a right of action at law have had their case interdicted by legislation. And that is a very bad thing. So it is not simply the indigenous people who are at risk here; it is anybody who wants to bring an action and particularly an action against the government.

The second thing I want to say is this: the Racial Discrimination Act is often mentioned here and it is usually mentioned in terms of what protection it gives to the Aboriginal people. But the Racial Discrimination Act is an act with general application for all Australians and, in a multicultural society or however you want to describe it, it is absolutely essential that there be no racial discrimination against any particular person or any particular culture. Where that is violated—as it is in this case—it is a tragedy. There should be almost sacred attention given to the Racial Discrimination Act, and that has not happened here.

Can I just add to something that Senator Bob Collins has said about the High Court. We are, and some of the debate tonight has shown this, in an era of the politics of blame. We do not look for solutions so much any more as to blame others—anybody else other than ourselves, our own party or our own position—and that is a bad thing. The subject recently of the politics of blame is the High Court. I think that once we start denigrating the High Court we start attacking the acceptance that people have of the system. Once people lose respect for the institutions—whether it is parliament, the government or the court itself—we are in trouble as to how we operate here.

Australia is distinct from other countries where law and order may be enforced by military power or similar power. In Australia, law and order is enforced by the acceptance of the population as a whole. And when you start denigrating an institution like the High Court there are real problems. In fact, the High Court is a most honourable body. It has served Australia well since federation and is presently serving Australia well. That has got to be affirmed again and again.

The Wik decision was decided—as, for example, the judgment of Mr Justice Gummow shows—in accordance with the law as it is. If we want to change the law, that is a matter for parliament. But we should not, because we get an inconvenient decision, denigrate the court, as we have. In fact, you get the impression that, had the decision gone the other way, the people who are presently condemning it would have praised it to the high heavens and would have been saying, `Look, you who now show disappointment with the decision in Wik, it being contrary to the one that actually came out, you should obey the umpire's decision.' So the people who are now inviting us not to obey the umpire's decision are the very people who would have been urging upon us the sanctity of the High Court and the necessity of obeying the umpire's decision if, in fact, the decision had gone their way.

That the motion (Senator Herron's ) be agreed to.
