TITLE.XREF: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table an additional supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government's additional amendments and request for amendments to be moved to this bill. This memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 12 May 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say very briefly that it is amazing that we are up to this legislation having had it on the Notice Paper I am not quite sure how many times. We have actually made it. Just to refresh people's memories, the amendment we are actually dealing with relates to the Murray‐Darling Basin. We believe the section of the bill that looks at how money from the trust should be spent on the Murray‐Darling Basin is rather loosely worded. Therefore, we are asking the Senate to consider improved and clearer amendments to the wording that we believe will make it easier for us to achieve the aims and objectives which this government wishes to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: While speaking to this amendment, I must just for a moment ask the government a question on an issue that has arisen today which relates to the focus of the Natural Heritage Trust. As we have seen in the media, it seems that there are some considerations by government that this trust rather than focusing on the environment may be redirected to emphasise employment aims and objectives of the government. I note with some concern an interview tonight with the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) who, when asked the question about the refocusing of the trust and the use of the money first and foremost for employment rather than the environment, said, `There are lots of surprises in tomorrow night's budget,' and he refused to further clarify. I ask the minister to clarify the prime intention of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —There will not be any surprises on this particular matter. The objectives have been and remain the environmental objectives that we have set out since day one on this bill. Not surprisingly, pursuant to those objectives, if we are able to maximise the employment uptake then we will be doubly pleased. We would make no apology about that. To use the example I might have mentioned to you earlier today, if there were two alternative projects of equal environmental merit and one had a better employment outcome than the other we would choose in favour of the one with the better employment outcome. That can be consistent with good environmental practice and I am sure with the wishes of all Australians.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too am interested in the issue that has been raised by Senator Lees. Probably like Senator Hill, I was able to read an article on page 1 of today's Australian that received a great deal of prominence. I do not know whether you have seen it, Senator Hill. I assume you have. It was headed `PM tags green money for jobs'. That article makes it clear that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has instructed that all fund spending proposals are to be vetted by the employment committee of cabinet to maximise employment creation effects. I was interested to learn whether in fact that was the case and what then the relationship of the employment committee of cabinet will be with the board as outlined in the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the article suggested in fact that each project, pursuant to the trust, would require some sanction of the employment committee. In fact, I think the article went so far as to say the sanction of the Prime Minister. That is of course not the case as is evident from the bill before the Senate. It is true that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) wants to be assured through the employment committee that we are achieving the objective that I mentioned a few moment ago—that is, consistent with the best environmental outcomes and maximising the employment opportunities. It is not surprising that he would wish that for this program as he wishes that for all major programs of the government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that partial explanation of what is occurring. Can I ask whether all natural heritage fund spend ing proposals will in fact go to the employment committee of cabinet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they will not. What the employment committee of cabinet wants to be assured of is that we are maximising the employment opportunities through the fund, as I said, consistent with the best environmental outcomes. That is basically as far as it goes. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) wrote to me in those terms some months ago. His wishes are obviously consistent with my objectives. I am sure all Australians in these difficult times would wish us to maximise the job opportunities, provided that doing so is consistent with achieving the best environmental outcomes.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to provide a fund for the restoration of our natural heritage, as you know. We believe that it has been neglected and needs a major infusion of capital to restore it to a state that we will be pleased to pass on to future generations. Much of that restoration work is in fact job intensive, so we think we can achieve the dual objectives. But it is a fund driven to achieve environmental objectives first and foremost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked these questions because of what is written in this same article. I would appreciate it if you could confirm the accuracy of one sentence in that article. Let me try to confine it to the crucial issue that is before us so that we do not take too long in this committee stage debate on the matter. One sentence from the front page article in the Australian today says:

SPEECH.PARA: Government sources told The Australian last night the Prime Minister had decided that the employment committee of Cabinet—which he chairs—should be given effective control of spending out of the Natural Heritage Trust Fund.
I was interested to know whether government sources, who one assumes have communicated that view to the Australian newspaper, are in fact well sourced.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they are not. As you know, under the structure of this bill the ultimate responsibility for the final funding decision lies with me and Minister Anderson. There is no suggestion that that will be changed. As I said, if that article had suggested that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was anxious to that ensure maximum job opportunities consistent with best environmental practice flow from the bill, I would have had no objection to it. But it seems that somebody has taken it further. I have to say that, despite my best endeavours today, I have not been able to identify that source.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer. I suppose, minister, the issue becomes a little more perplexing to those of us who are merely members of the opposition when we understand that the employment committee of cabinet does not include either you or Mr Anderson. That of itself is, I suspect, no news to you or to us, given that this was something that was made public some considerable time ago. I think it was in October last year when the Prime Minister announced the formation of the employment committee of cabinet.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested in understanding how your environmental responsibilities and imperatives and Mr Anderson's responsibilities in this matter are dealt with when one assumes neither of you will be involved in or privy to those discussions. Or would it be more accurate to say that the employment committee of cabinet would be augmented by you and Mr Anderson when these issues are being discussed? I think that is an important clarification for the committee. I would be interested to hear your response.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said some little time ago, the Prime Minister is anxious to see that all major government programs maximise job opportunities. That includes this program that we are talking about tonight. Of course, any discussion on that subject by the employment committee would include the two ministers who are responsible for the ultimate funding decisions in the bill, and they are Minister Anderson and me.
—So it will be augmented in that sense?

—I do not know whether `augmented' is the right word, but basically it would be in the discussion of the subject if the Prime Minister wants to take it further, because I have already given the assurance, which is my objective, to maximise job opportunities consistent with the environmental objective. But if he wants to take it further through the formal meeting of that employment committee, then obviously Minister Anderson and I would be present and part of that discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an interesting development we have here because, as Senator Faulkner and Senator Lees have been pointing out, final decisions are no longer necessarily going to be made by the board consisting of the two ministers. Under this legislation they are appointed for the disbursement of moneys. But the minister has said now that where you have environmental projects which are of equal merit, the employment considerations will come into play. What he has not said, of course, is why you would ever get stuck in the situation where you have two projects and you cannot decide between the two of them. If that were the case, then it might be for the minister to get in some environmental expertise—the sort in which he is lacking—so that that decision could be made for him.

SPEECH.PARA: You will find that in the real world where you have competing environmental projects, you are not going to get into that trouble if you do your homework properly. However, what the minister says is that, in that circumstance, having rejected the Greens's proposal that there be an independent committee of nine people with environmental expertise to sort out just that problem, the matter will go to a cabinet committee which will determine it on the basis of employment. So in fact what we have is not an environmental outcome but a government, economic and employment driven decision making process set there to determine what the ministers cannot determine.

In short, the minister is kidding us when he says that environmental outcomes are to the fore, because there is no mechanism set up to help him and his fellow minister, Minister Anderson, determine which of two competing decisions they cannot differentiate between on environmental merits ought to be selected. So you then pass it across to a board, in effect—a committee in cabinet—which will make the decision determined on what the Prime Minister wants to see as far as a jobs outcome. In other words, there is no committee for the environment, but there is one as far as the Prime Minister's injunction about jobs is concerned. Already we see the direction of this fund, as promised to the electorate, being changed.
Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I propose the question:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to raise an issue that I am concerned about; that is, the cutbacks in child‐care funding. Clearly, we are on the eve of a budget. I do not know precisely what is in the budget. I guess neither do many people in this chamber. But I do know that it is estimated that the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), who is responsible for child care, has 40,000 letters on her desk about child‐care cutbacks. This is gravely concerning the parents of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year's decisions in relation to drastic cutbacks in the child‐care funding sector were bad enough. Tonight there are many thousands of parents wondering just what is going to happen in the budget tomorrow night and whether there will be further cutbacks.

The Sun‐Herald ran a headline yesterday: `Mums lose child care'. That is pretty typical of the media, isn't it? Mums and dads lose child care. Mums and dads are responsible for child care. Yet, of course, the focus is just on mums. But the big cuts to child care, it is projected, will affect non-working mothers. I have never met a non-working mother. I don't quite know what that term means. All mothers and all parents work. Raising children is a hard job. Whether mothers or fathers are in the paid work force or not is really immaterial.

If, as is projected here, up to $400 million will be cut and that will impact most on so-called non-working mothers—I presume they mean mothers out of the paid work force—that is discriminatory and goes totally against John Howard's commitment to have strong family policies and to govern, as he promised, for all of us—all of us, it seems, except the mums and dads of Australia who want to have access to child care. Child care is not a luxury. Child care is not something special. Child care is a fundamental right that parents and children in Australia should have access to.
I wonder just what the women members of the coalition government have been doing in the last 12 months. When we had the last election and—

TALK.START.PARA: —There's a lot of them, Margaret.

—There are a lot of them. And I congratulated them for being there from their side of politics. But what are they doing? They are not protecting child care. I do not know what they are doing. We will look at other areas of the budget tomorrow. What are they doing to protect—
—Well, wait until tomorrow.
—I am waiting, Senator. I wish you could assure me, but the cuts from last budget are bad enough and are impacting very seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: Just last March, 50,000 women left the work force or stopped looking for work. This was the worst fall in the participation rate of women in the work force since September 1979. Why would that happen? Why would it just happen in March 1997? The increases in fees of $20 or more per child per week coincided with the decision of many women to leave the work force. Eleven thousand women left part-time work, a massive 30,000 left or were forced out of full‐time work and 8,800 unemployed women gave up looking for work. Why did this happen? It happened because they cannot continue to afford child care. I have here a press release from the Child Care and Preschool Centre at Enoggera, Queensland. It states:
A climate of distrust and anger is welling amongst families dependant on childcare assistance to maintain two parents in the work force . . .

Owner of the Mother Duck Childcare centres in Brisbane Denis Hinton has described parents reaction to cuts in April as "tears and frustration" as thousands of parents are being driven out of the workforce and on to Social Security by a Government policy which appears aimed at reducing official unemployment statistics, rather than looking after families.
The childcare industry will be campaigning fiercely against the Government up until the next election.

Quite frankly, I think it would be far more to the point for the Howard government to listen to the needs of families—listen to those 26 women, the majority of whom are on the back bench. They are not delivering in terms of child‐care policies. What about after‐school care? I have a letter here from a woman who runs an after‐school care centre called St Joachims. She has heard rumours, and she is worried. Her letter states:

. . . in my After School Care facility alone, 57% of the children who attend will be grossly affected. Their parents at present receive fee relief and can therefore afford to have their children cared for in a safe environment between the closure of school and the completion of their working day. I should add that ALL THESE parents are single parents, most with very little backup care.
We are only a small school and I would have to charge $10.00 per day per child to cover the costs of keeping the facility open—a prohibitive cost for most of my parents, not just those on fee relief.

What does the present government hope to achieve by this proposed measure, I wonder? Are they hoping to add to the already unacceptable numbers of "street kids" roaming around between the hours of 3pm and 6pm?
There is another letter from the Tamarind Gardens Child Care Centre. It says:

Following a meeting on Tuesday, 29th April, of child care centre owners in Cairns we would like to express our concerns at the recent media announcement that a further $400 million will be slashed from child care in the May 97 budget.
Parents have already suffered the effect of changes . . . namely:
Removal of the $30.00 deduction for each dependent child . . .
The non‐indexation of a fee ceiling of $115 per week
Changes to the income cut‐off for Childcare Assistance . . .
Reduction of Childcare Cash Rebate . . .
Restricting Childcare Assistance to 50 hours per week
Abolishing operational subsidies . . .
Any decision in tomorrow night's budget will come on top of quite dramatic cut backs in child care in the last budget.

I believe that, whatever is in the budget tomorrow night, it is very important—I make an appeal not just to colleagues like Senator O'Chee and Senator Ian Macdonald, but to the women members of government—to turn this government around on its family policies, particularly in relation to child care. On another occasion I will take up the issue of what this government is doing with care of the disabled and care of the elderly.

We have seen unprecedented numbers of women elected to the coalition government—that is a fact of life. From the point of view of the coalition that is a good thing. But what are they doing? That is what families in Australia are asking. Not only is the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the man committed to family values, not delivering, but also the women members are failing to deliver in terms of protecting families and particularly women.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the matter of a proposed new industrial complex planned for a picturesque stretch of coastline called Oakajee in sight of Geraldton in Western Australia. We have a scandal unfolding at Oakajee. We have a state government again acting in a hasty, arrogant and improper fashion. It is currently pushing and guillotining through the WA state parliament a state agreement act to lock in a major new industrial development without having gone through the most basic and essential processes of community consultation and open environmental and economic assessment.

BREAK.PARA: The Oakajee site itself has not been subject to formal public and environmental assessment. The way that the environmental assessments are currently being conducted is intended to prevent any comprehensive understanding of the impact of the project. In flouting due process in this way, the WA state government is contravening its own policy on state agreements acts which claims that necessary assessment and consultation processes will be concluded before such agreement acts are developed. Why are existing environmental impact assessments being seriously mishandled? Why are the concerns of the local community being ignored? Who benefits? Whose pockets will be filled?

The WA state government, in its desperation to get this project up and running without proper scrutiny, has committed itself to spending in the order of $400 million to subsidise and underwrite the development. Its coalition colleagues over east are unlikely to spend one dollar saving the Newcastle steel mill. This government is to spend $400 million on another steel mill. The question is: why?

The same government which claims it is short of money for schools and hospitals is proposing to commit massive funds from Western Australian and Commonwealth taxpayers to an enterprise which has not been properly assessed and has not been the subject of proper community consultation. This is, in my opinion, a recipe for environmental, social and economic disaster. It smells of entrepreneurial government, of risk taking of an unacceptable level—of a WA Inc. style approach. How much of this $400 million is Commonwealth money coming from state grants? Does the Commonwealth give money without regard to how it is spent?

The Commonwealth has a direct role and responsibility in this matter. The Commonwealth government has made much of its commitment to and involvement in issues to do with coastal and marine management and conservation all around Australia. In August last year, Senator MacGibbon was reported in the Australian newspaper as launching a new Commonwealth coastal planning initiative and allocating some $100 million from the sale of Telstra to implement proper coastal planning and pollution control processes. He stated:

. . . industry expansion in coastal zones presents a serious risk to the national coastline . . . a succession of small decisions has produced fragmented and inefficient coastal management . . . A co‐operative integrated approach to coastal planning and management, as outlined in the Federal government's coastal policy, would ensure that talk became action.

There is no sign of this commitment being met in the case of Oakajee. Worthy initiatives and expressions of concern from the Commonwealth are being mocked by the Oakajee development. Let me refer to an article written by Brian Miller in the April edition of WA Business News . The article castigates the state government for its lack of clear industry policy and its ad hoc and inconsistent involvement in industrial development. Mr Miller, in referring to the Oakajee project, states:
. . . what is certain is that the government is driven by short term opportunism not a long term strategy . . .

The article goes on to point out that, by subsidising the project to the tune of $300 million—it is now $400 million—the 1,000 jobs created will cost the government $300,000 each—it is now $400,000 each. The strategy of the WA government, such as it is, is to proliferate new heavy industrial sites on the WA coastline. Using this scattergun approach, they have decided that the Oakajee site is one suitable place and they seem hell‐bent on forcing the project through.

As a means to get the whole project up and running, a company called Kingstream Resources NL, which is headed by the Premier's brother, Ken Court, has been used as the lead company. I am concerned that a local company headed by the Premier's brother has made itself available to the government as a trojan horse to get this new industrial site off the ground. The project also has Taiwanese backing through the large steel company An Feng Steel Ltd.

Recent reports indicate that Kingstream Resources NL, Ken Court's company, and An Feng Australia Ltd, the Taiwanese company, are going to merge to form a subsidiary company of the large Taiwanese steel company. The public of WA and the public of the Commonwealth should be told much more about the nature of this merger and if this arrangement will lead to opportunities for the Taiwanese parent company to engage in transfer pricing or any other pricing or taxation stratagems. If transfers of profits occur and if taxes are minimised, such financial gains as might have come from this project could quickly be lost in terms of Australian benefits.

Geraldton, which is WA's third largest city, already has an established industrial estate called Narngalu. Geraldton has also established industry infrastructure, including a port. To upgrade this and use existing investment, existing facilities and existing unemployed labour would cost much less than $400 million. Again, I and the Australian Democrats ask who benefits? Whose pockets are to get filled with this Commonwealth and WA taxpayer funded $400 million?

The Narngalu industrial site six kilometres south-east of Geraldton was the original proposed site for a steel mill. The EPA conducted a public environmental review of this project and approved it. It was subsequently decided that existing pollution levels were bad enough without adding to them. It does not seem wise if Geraldton has serious pollution problems at its existing site to now look to repeating the dose on the coast to its north. Given that the Oakajee site is only some five kilometres from the nearest Geraldton residential area, Drummond Cove, it cannot be argued that this new site will protect residents from pollution.

If the state needs more heavy industry in this region, it should be located close to existing infrastructure. If the government has $400 million to spend on encouraging industry and jobs in the Geraldton area, that money would be much better spent on cleaning up the existing Geraldton industrial zone to world best industrial practice standard. This would then allow for further environmentally acceptable industries to set up in the existing zone utilising existing infrastructure and would do away with the need to destroy Oakajee.

Other sites more suitable for the steel mill project, including a cleaned up site at Narngalu, or sites inland and closer to the mine itself in the Mullewa Shire need to be publicly, independently and objectively examined and assessed on economic, social and environmental grounds. In 1993, a petition signed by some 3,500 Geraldton people was tabled in the state parliament expressing concern about the Oakajee development. There are many legitimate concerns amongst the local community over the siting of the project at Oakajee in terms of expected impacts on the marine environment, the expected and possible impacts of pollution, the site's geological suitability and the hydrological problems.

Other valuable economic uses of the area are also endangered, including fishing and international tourism based on sailboard sports, which together are worth many millions of dollars. The WA government's priorities are biased towards powerful vested interest and big industrial projects. As a result, once again, small business, fishing and tourism which currently benefit from the Oakajee area are now in danger. If the state government has $400 million to spend in the Geraldton region, there are probably many other ways the community could use that money to create lasting employment and sustainable economic benefits without having to put smokestack industries at Oakajee.

WA Inc. taught Western Australians to be suspicious of grand government schemes favouring powerful corporate interests that are not subject to full and open scrutiny. I and the Australian Democrats are not alone in our fears. I am aware that there are members of the WA coalition government who are extremely concerned about process, costs and the guarantees. They will not want to be dragged before the public at some future date. Every notion of careful, intelligent, cooperative and sustainable coastal management and development is being tossed out the window with Oakajee. The Commonwealth must not turn its back on this fact.

The state agreement bill should be scrapped and the assessment and consultation processes currently under way should be dramatically improved so that a clearer picture of the overall costs and benefits of the project and its alternatives can emerge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the exciting celebrations that will occur at the turn of the century with the Olympics and the Centenary of Federation, the Canberra community is feeling more and more like they want to stop the clock and limit the damage. In the year 2000 our largest industry group, the Public Service, will be whittled away to a shell of its previous self. By the year 2000, thousands of jobs will be lost because of the Liberal government's morbid fascination with outsourcing government services. The cuts and outsourcing will combine to severely damage the ACT economy as we watch multinationals soak up businesses and profits at our expense.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst trying to struggle with the recession the Liberal government has caused, the ACT has been shattered by the news that the Commonwealth Grants Commission has failed to consider the differences that the ACT's present population has inherited—differences that impact on our ability to cope financially as a community and the nation's capital.

In October 1988, the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Clyde Holding, said that the Australian Capital Territory (Self‐Government) Bill represented `a significant transfer of power'. He said, `The ACT and the city of Canberra have well and truly come of age.' I agree with the Hon. Mr Holding in his observations of Canberra's development and his thoughts on the uniqueness of the ACT as a city state and the nation's capital.

The most important point that members of both sides of parliament made in the debate over the ACT's debut into the political world was the fact that the ACT enjoyed the status of being a community and the seat of the federal government. This brings me to the point of this adjournment debate tonight. `Enjoy' is not a word that we are using at the moment in Canberra. It is not a word that the people of Canberra are using to describe being a regional centre and the national capital.

Under the coalition government the honour of being the capital of Australia has become a burden that members of my community are finding extremely difficult and extremely unrewarding to bear. When self‐government was introduced, the ACT Labor party worked to provide a model of government that was responsive to the needs of its members whilst maintaining a standard of infrastructure that was required of a city which is always on the national and international stage.

The people of Canberra acknowledge that their standard of living compares well. For the record, there has been an increase in the proportion of two‐income families, and that has boosted the average income. We enjoy unpolluted air, comparatively minimal traffic congestion and lots of trees. But we do so humbly, recognising that many other communities have also suffered through recessions. Such are the things that come with being the nation's capital—a city that, when held up to international standards, can thankfully hold its own.

One of Canberra's strengths of course is that we are a relatively new city. In 1927, when Parliament House was first opened, we had a population of 7,685. In 1970 it had grown to 130,000‐plus and now stands at over 300,000. Regionally, the population is over 500,000, clearly identifying Canberra as an important regional centre—a fact that is often sadly lost in the current debate about our role.

Our heritage and history are therefore contemporary. On the surface they hold little of the colonial mysticism of Sofala and the Rocks. Rather, our heritage is inextricably linked to our political development as a nation and our social and democratic progression. Perhaps this is the key to Canberra's struggles in the PR stakes with the rest of Australia. Politics, politicians, government, et cetera, are held in dubious regard by the majority of our population—with recent scandals only reinforcing this sentiment.

As a result, the readiness of some politicians to use Canberra as a convenient scratch ing post serves only their short‐sighted populist agenda and fuels `wedge politics' or the selling of a sentiment in place of a policy. Hence, Canberra bashing becomes a political tool in the hands of a conservative government such as that in power now.

How to deal with these specific challenges and fend off such attacks confronts us as a community right at this moment. As an elected representative of this place I can argue that there is victimisation and unfair targeting of cuts by virtue of our industry blend. I can demand that it stop and that due consideration of our citizens be given. And I will continue to argue those points.

But do these arguments penetrate the minds of those whose political agenda ventures not outside the driest of dry economic rationalism? Only money talks to them. So I turn my attention to the fiscal structures that underpin the Commonwealth financial contribution to this place. The Grants Commission is the body through which the Commonwealth allocates its contribution to the states and territories from revenues raised through taxes.

The methodologies that are applied therefore provide one of the few windows of opportunity through which the citizens and their representatives of the ACT can argue for a fair go. The problems with the Grants Commission's methodologies, however, are infamous. Since 1933, the commission's methodologies have changed significantly but standardisation has still resulted in a complicated model that is based on an adversarial system of states pitted against each other for funds.

The Grants Commission reviews its allocations every five years and the ACT has completed its submission to the 1999 review. Many issues were raised in this submission but, as with all states, the ACT does not enjoy bringing attention to its situation when we know that, for us to get more money, other states have to lose.

There are just three issues that I want to bring to the attention of the Senate. First, as the nation's capital, my community witnessed the security arrangements for the visit of the US President, Bill Clinton. It was hard to ignore secret service personnel in and around the parliamentary triangle and the resources that were utilised for the visit. One example of those resources was that of the police of the ACT. For the residents of Canberra, it is a pay‐off that we have to accept that, during a visit of a dignitary, above and beyond the work of security forces the level of policing will be concentrated on the safety and security of visiting dignitaries and their clean passage whilst in Canberra.

The second point that defines Canberra's uniqueness is the fact that we are landlocked within another jurisdiction. The constraints placed on the ACT because of our borders have limited our future growth potential. An issue involved in this quite specifically is having two distinct planning authorities—one representing the interests of our role as the nation's capital, the other the growth and expansion of the issues facing the territory government.

The third point that is more easily quantifiable relates to cross‐border issues. An example of this, according to the information I have received, is that an entire ACT college could be filled with students from outside the ACT. Also, the reality of health care is that New South Wales residents in surrounding regions must at times need to access the ACT's advanced health facilities.

However the Grants Commission has overlooked factors such as these when equating the financial needs of the ACT against other states. There is no parallel. The Grants Commission has been slow to recognise that the ACT cannot be treated like any other state or territory in their process of calculating finances. With up to 20 per cent of ACT services being used by non‐residents of the ACT, we are unique.

The infrastructure and ongoing maintenance of the roads networks has translated into the ACT inheriting a liability. And that can be used as another example of paying up‐front on a liability inherited from the past.

On the local front, unfortunately, misguided priorities have become a feature of the local Liberals' budget strategies, with unsustainable budget revenue sources used to pay for flawed programs sadly contributing to the territory's dilemma rather than offering sound solutions.

When the state of New South Wales lost 2,368 square kilometres of its land in 1911, the nation's capital was born. On 11 May 1989, self‐government was proclaimed and the people said we had come of age. In 1997, at 86 years young, the current federal government has abandoned the nation's capital in more ways than one and the people of the ACT are feeling decidedly beleaguered.

This government must take responsibility for the nation's capital. The targeting of Canberra and the refusal of John Howard to live here show an immaturity attributable to no other government and it does not do Australia proud at all.

I say these things tonight not to put in yet another plea for the ACT to this government with the pending budget, but to bring to the attention of people all around Australia that the ACT is unique in some very special ways, including the fact that it is the nation's capital. I ask that this government take into account those issues before they embark upon their next round of cutting funding which will not just affect the public sector or public sector employees here, but also severely damage and limit the growth of the private sector as we move from the emphasis being on our public sector to being on our private sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to put on the public record my concerns that, despite the warm and fuzzy words of governments over the decades, many young Australians face poverty. This is not about sympathy or paying for the problem to go away; this is about justice and equity and that much talked about civil society. It is about complex social relationships, cooperation, social capital, civic culture and positive social outcomes. By poverty, I am talking about relative poverty where a standard of living taking into account assets, income, diet, housing, health care, lack of access to or depravation of resources, et cetera is below a standard of living that we as the majority of people in this community find acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: I say at the outset that poverty is a structural issue for our society. It is about how we accommodate and care for a group in our community and the way we structure our government's policies and actions to care for that particular group's interests. Blaming poor people for being poor and hassling them to do something about their predicament without providing them with a means to do so does not solve problems. Telling homeless people or long-term unemployed young people to get a job to better themselves does not solve their poverty, as they do not have some of the basics that are necessary for getting a job, such as a contact address, interview clothes for a good impression, transport to the interview, and the list goes on.

I also want to point out that there is a divide occurring in Australia between the haves and the have nots and that this is a move away from our country's egalitarian goals. The number of households earning what we might consider a good income has increased, but so has the number earning what is a poor income. This division shows the increased representation of the lower income group for whom poverty becomes a real concern.
In an address to ACOSS in October 1995, the Prime Minister, John Howard, said:
All Australians should have access to an adequate income, affordable housing, quality health care and a level of education that enables them to fully achieve their potential.

Supposedly, the present government began with good intentions and initiated a youth homeless pilot program and an early intervention and prevention program with community groups. These programs are a start, but they are a long way short of the serious action needed to address youth poverty.

What we see from the government is a drive to reform welfare by injecting market principles into social life, moving to re‐establish the primacy of family responsibility so that turning to government funded welfare becomes the second or the last resort. This places a burden of responsibility on the individual for their predicament and fuels the perception that welfare programs are too large.

The Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in its report in 1992 viewed unemployment as the single greatest contributor to poverty. Australian studies, such as Whiteford, Bradbury and Saunders in 1988, link unemployment with poverty. The Morgan and Banks job index, February to April 1997, asked a large number of organisations what government policies and programs would make their organisations more likely to employ young people. The answers provide an interesting view of what employers think.

The results showed that only three per cent of organisations think that high quality job placement services are likely to result in increased attractiveness to employing young people. Fifteen per cent of organisations think cash or tax incentives and wage subsidies are likely to result in increased attractiveness to employing young people, and 24 per cent of employers think industry relevant training is likely to result in increased attractiveness to employing young people.

Sadly, this survey also showed that 11 per cent of organisations would not consider employing a young or unemployed person. Morgan and Banks attribute this to negative stereotypes and generalisations about young people and the unemployed. I must say that many of those negative perceptions have been perpetuated in this very place. The survey also shows that some organisations are not prepared to participate in the training of young people and want someone else to foot that training bill.

I have talked before about the numbers of unemployed young people and the cutting of youth employment programs. What I have said shows that the present government's commitment, as set out in their election policies, has not been followed. They continue to wait for the egg to hatch, already knowing it will not happen. The Morgan and Banks survey challenges the government's reliance on employers and highlights the requirement for industry relevant training.

BREAK.PARA: What is of great concern is the body of evidence which shows that young people without jobs are being increasingly marginalised. The Williams study in 1987, which followed a number of young people from 1975 to 1986, showed that people from poorer families were more likely to leave school early. Without training, they tend to make up the ranks of the unemployed, as they are unable to compete against more qualified and trained people and, in the part-time job market, against competing students. These young people then become the long-term unemployed subsisting on benefits. These marginalised young people face barriers to gaining or regaining employment.

In 1993 ACOSS research conducted for the task force on employment opportunities identified barriers to employment for the long‐term unemployed, including not enough appropriate jobs, not enough financial resources, not enough income, lack of relevant vocational training, employer discrimination, low self‐esteem, low motivation and presentation, poor health, lack of housing, et cetera.

Measuring poverty is difficult because it relies on economic and social conditions. The make‐up of the family grouping and the particular necessary expenses of individuals all add up to make the measure difficult. However, there are benchmark measures which have been examined since 1973 and presented as a disposable income per week to satisfy the basic needs of a family of two adults and two children.

Based on the June quarter 1995 data, the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research suggested the single person poverty line was around $177 per week. At that time, social security entitlements for a similar person were around $185 a week. Social security is not the lifestyle of riches and leisure and does not provide a great opportunity to get ahead, contrary to some suggestions that are often floated in this place.

Welfare reform must be based on real politics and a real understanding of the barriers to escaping poverty. Idealised concepts of labour markets, the ability of families to deal with welfare on their own scarce resources, an exclusive rather than inclusive definition of the public good and the perception that welfare programs are too big all need to be addressed. The pursuit of economic numbers to the exclusion of all else fails a just and equitable community and that much talked about civil society. These are difficult issues and they require concerted action. Madam President, let us hope this government will soon act—hopefully as of tomorrow night's budget—as there is a desperate need for federal leadership in this area.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: For the most recent 12 months for which figures are available:
(1) What is the total number and amount of overpayments made by the department.
(2) How many and what amount of these overpayments were due to: (a) administrative error; (b) fraud; and (c) other reasons, please specify where possible.

(3) Can an accurate figure be placed on the cost to the department of actual fraud, for example where there was proven intent on the part of the customer; if so, can this be broken down by State; if not, can a reasonably accurate estimate be made on the level of fraud.

(4) (a) Does the department agree with the findings of the study conducted in 1993 by Dr Richard Weatherley that `compared to other domains, public and private, the incidence of social security fraud is modest'; and (b) is it still the case , as Dr Weatherley found in 1993, that most overpayments `involve relatively small amounts identified on the basis of information volunteered by clients and most of the money was recovered'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the current legislation not all amounts paid in excess of entitlement are legally recoverable debts. Data is not maintained on the value of these excess payments which are not legally recoverable debts. However, in the 12 month period from 1 March 1996 to 28 February 1997 there were 863,695 legally recoverable debts raised under the Social Security Act 1991 (the Act) with a value of $471.88M, and 4,314 debts raised under the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 (in respect of Youth Training Allowance administered by the Department) with a value of $1.03M.

(2)(a)‐(c) It is not possible to provide the precise information requested. However, in 1996 it was estimated that 4.4% of legally recoverable debts arose because of administrative error. It was also estimated that 52.1% of debts arose as a result of failure by the recipient to comply with their notification obligations under the legislation, a portion only of which involved false statements or false representation. Although these debts involve some element of `fault' on the recipient's part, not all would have involved a deliberate attempt to defraud the Department.
Other major reasons or categories of debts were estimated as follows:
‐ 11.6% of debts were outstanding Newstart advance payments;
‐ 10.6% were prepayment debts (where, because of public holidays, payment is made before custom ers lodge regular review forms to avoid delays which would otherwise occur); and
‐ 8.8% of debts were from customers transferring to other payments with overlapping entitlements.

(3) There is no available reliable total estimate of the cost of fraud to DSS. Serious cases of fraud are prosecuted where the Director of Public Prosecutions considers it is in the public interest to do so; based on the guidelines set out in the Prosecution Policy of the Commonwealth; including whether there are reasonable prospects of a conviction. There is no available figure on the total number of cases which involved deliberate intent on the part of a customer or other person. As noted above, a significant number of debts arise because of failure to advise a change in circumstances, although not all of these instances would be fraudulent.

(4)(a) The Department is not in a position to assess the incidence of fraud in other areas. The Department accepts that relative to total outlays, the incidence of fraud in the social security system is modest, but notes that even a small proportion involves a significant amount of money.

(4)(b) It is agreed that most overpayments are relatively small amounts and most of the money is recovered. However, as outlined in (2) above, it is not correct that most overpayments are identified by information volunteered by customers.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States Government Doctrine on Nuclear Deterrence: Australia's Role

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Government's understanding of the current United States (US) Government doctrine on nuclear deterrence.
(2) What part is Australia playing in the US Government's current strategy on nuclear deterrence.
(3) What specific role does the Joint Australian and US facility at North West Cape have in supporting the US Government's strategy on nuclear deterrence

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The United States maintains nuclear forces to deter their use by others and to contribute to the deterrence of conventional warfare between the major powers. The end of the Cold War has allowed the status of nuclear weapons as weapons of last resort to be further emphasised through significant reductions in the number of deployed strategic and tactical systems; through agreements between the United States and the Russian Federation to de‐target strategic nuclear missiles so that their aim points while on alert are a point in the ocean rather than targets in the other country; and through the removal of all tactical nuclear weapons from surface naval vessels.

(2) Joint Defence Facility Nurrungar continues to make an essential contribution to the stability of nuclear deterrence by providing early warning of ballistic missile launches. It further contributes to global and regional security by inhibiting the proliferation of ballistic missiles. The Joint Defence Facility Pine Gap contributes to monitoring of compliance with arms control agreements, including the agreements that seek to make deterrence more stable and provide for lower levels of nuclear armament.

(3) The capability of the facility at North West Cape to relay communications from US command centres to submerged strategic ballistic missile submarines contributed significantly to the stability of deterrence by underlining the inevitability of retaliation in the event of a nuclear attack. This function is now less urgent, but the capability of the station to communicate with Australian and US ships and submarines in the Indian Ocean and the Western Pacific remains important to both the RAN and the USN. The joint facility is now run entirely by the RAN, under the command of an RAN officer; it will be come an Australian Naval Communication Station in 1999.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Widow Allowance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) If recipients of Widow Allowance should obtain full‐time employment but then discover that they are unable to handle that employment, are they able to return to the Widow Allowance or will they need to serve another 12 months on Newstart.
(2) Will this depend on whether the work was for more than 13 weeks.

(3) If, in these circumstances, they would be required to serve an extended period on Newstart: (a) would this not be a disincentive to recipients of the Widow Allowance to seeking employment, given there are no jobsearch requirements on the Widow Allowance; and (b) what benefits and disadvantages would there be in allowing those women to return to the Widow Allowance immediately upon leaving their employment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) If a Widow Allowance recipient obtained full‐time employment and within 13 weeks decided that she was not able to continue that employment, in most cases she could return to Widow Allowance. However, if her period of full‐time employment was 13 weeks or more, she would not immediately requalify for Widow Allowance because she would have `recent workforce experience'. (`Recent workforce experience' is defined as work of at least 20 hours per week for 13 weeks or more, at any time during the 12 months prior to claiming Widow Allowance.) In this situation, the woman would need to apply for Newstart Allowance. If the woman was unsuccessful at finding further employment after 9 months in receipt of Newstart Allowance, she may then requalify for Widow Allowance.
(2) Yes. See response to question (1).

(3) (a) The requirement for no `recent workforce experience' is not a disincentive to participate in the workforce. Instead, this provision ensures that women who are able to support themselves through employment are encouraged to do so. A woman with `recent workforce experience' is considered to be more job ready and more able to benefit from the active job seeking emphasis of Newstart Allowance.

(3) (b) It might be regarded by some as a benefit for women with `recent workforce experience' to be able to requalify immediately for Widow Allowance and not have to meet the activity test. The disadvantage of allowing these women to requalify immediately for Widow Allowance is the reduced exposure to the active job seeking emphasis of Newstart Allowance and the lack of incentive to participate in employment. As participation in employment provides greater long term financial security than long term dependence on income support, any perceived benefit needs to be carefully weighed against the loss of access to the opportunity for long term employment.
