QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 26 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under its 7‐point plan, what vaccinations does the Government require children to undertake and at what safest minimum age.

(2) For each of the diseases being treated in the immunisation program: in the case of an epidemic, what are the relative risks to a child: (a) not having been vaccinated; and (b) having been vaccinated.
(3) What are the types and risks levels of side effects associated with each vaccine.
(4) Is it necessary to recognise differences in children's immune development, by weight, age or medical history, in determining the appropriate dosage of vaccine.
(5) What animal or human tissue or other means is used to acculturate each type of vaccine.
(6) Does the Government have any plan to extend the numbers of diseases being treated by vaccination.
(7) At the time a child is vaccinated, will the child's parents or guardians be provided with information outlining possible adverse symptoms or reactions and action they should take in such cases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The vaccines included under the 7 point plan are those recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). The NHMRC recommends that children receive the first dose of Oral Poliomyelitis Vaccine (OPV), Diphtheria‐Tetanus‐Pertussis (DTP) and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) at 2 months of age. Measles‐Mumps‐Rubella (MMR) is recommended at 12 months of age.2.
(2) (a) Due to the varying nature of individual diseases and the efficacy of vaccines, two examples only are addressed.

(i) Pertussis (whooping cough) is an extremely infectious disease. Up to 90 per cent of unimmunised individuals in households where there is a case of pertussis contract the disease. Since whooping cough is not only highly infectious, but also causes severe disease, the risks of complications or even death for each unimmunised child are high.

(ii) Measles is virtually universal amongst unimmunised children in all countries. Eventually, 99.9 per cent of people who have not been immunised will contract measles, and 90 per cent will do so before the age of 20.

Vaccine efficacy is a measure of the level of protection against a disease in children who have been vaccinated compared with the attack rate in children who have not been vaccinated. Pertussis vaccine has generally been shown to be 85‐95 per cent efficacious. Measles vaccine has been shown to be 95 per cent efficacious.

(3) Many children experience some symptoms following vaccination. Most of these only last a short time and the child recovers without any problems. Reactions can include swelling and redness at the injection site, moderate fever, crying or irritability. Measles Mumps and Rubella vaccination may be followed about 10 days later by a fever lasting 2‐3 days, malaise and/or rash. These reactions do not contraindicate further vaccination.

(4) Doctors and other immunisation providers should ensure that the individual to be vaccinated does not have a condition (or history of a previous condition) which increases the risk of a severe reaction. The NHMRC has endorsed a protocol which has been developed to assist immunisation providers assess the fitness of a person for vaccination. Immunisation providers should determine if the person to be vaccinated:
. Is unwell today;
. Is having treatment which lowers immunity;
. Has had a severe reaction to any vaccine;
. Has any severe allergies to vaccine components;
. Has a disease which lowers immunity (e.g. leukemia, cancer, HIV/AIDS);
. Lives with someone who has a disease which lowers immunity or lives with someone who is having treatment which lowers immunity;
. Has had a vaccine containing live virus within the last month, or an injection of immunoglobulin or a blood transfusion within the last 3 months;
. Is pregnant;
. Has a disease of the brain or spinal cord; and
. Lives with someone who is not immunised.

Generally babies born preterm or have a low‐birth weight, provided they are otherwise well, should be immunised at the usual chronological age (i.e. beginning at 2 months after birth, without `correcting' for prematurity).

(5) Some vaccines contain a very small dose of a live, non‐harmful form of a virus. Some vaccines contain a very small dose of killed bacteria, and other vaccines contain a small dose of a modified toxin produced by bacteria or small parts of bacteria. Vaccines also contain either a small amount of preservative or a small amount of an antibiotic to preserve the vaccine. Some vaccines also contain a small amount of an aluminium salt which helps the immune response.

Some vaccines are cultured on a growth media which may include bovine, ovine, porcine, or monkey components. Other vaccines can be grown in cell cultures of chick embryo or in human diploid cell cultures. Other vaccines have no animal or human component.

(6) Hepatitis B vaccine will be added to the NHMRC Standard Childhood Vaccination Schedule when a multi‐valent vaccine is approved for use in Australia. The addition of other vaccines to the NHMRC Schedule will be considered as new vaccines become available.

(7) Yes. The NHMRC recommends that a valid consent be obtained prior to vaccination and has endorsed a protocol to assist immunisation providers. Information is also generally provided to parents and guardians outlining possible adverse symptoms or reactions and the action that should be taken should these occur.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon Notice, on 27 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1)Is there any dispute on the findings by the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations that 70 percent of the world's commercially important marine fish stocks are either fully fished, over exploited, depleted or only recovering slowly.

(2) Given that global stocks of southern bluefin tuna are at an all-time low, with catches having declined from a high of more than 80,000 metric tonnes in 1961, to less than 15,000 metric tonnes in 1990, will the Federal Government nominate southern bluefin tuna for listing under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora ahead of a major meeting of the convention in June: if not, why not.

(3) Recognising that the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) has legislative responsibility for managing all foreign fishing within the Australian fishing zone with its legislative objectives specified under the Act, `to ensure that the exploitation of fisheries resources and the carrying on of any related activities are conducted in a manner consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development, in particular the need to have regard to the impact of fishing activities on non-target species and the marine environment', can it be confirmed; a) that the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) audit on the AFMA found that the stock assessment indicates that southern bluefin tuna stocks are below desired ecologically sustainable development biological levels; (b)that the same ANAO report noted deficiencies in compliance with the logbook system; (c) that two inquiries and the ANAO found there were insufficient penalties to deter non- compliance in reporting; (d) that the ANAO noted the lack of environmental impact assessments for AFMA fisheries management decisions and that no referrals have ever been made to the Environment Protection Agency;.

(4) In the wake of these ANAO findings, can assurances be given that arrangements within the new Australian-Japan fishing agreement; (a) conform to the ecologically sustainable development objectives of AFMA; if so, on what scientific evidence is this assurance based; if not, on what grounds can AFMA breach its legislative requirements; (b) provide for proper logbook keeping and accurate monitoring of southern bluefin tuna stocks; if so, what are these arrangements; (c) satisfied an environmental impact assessment (EIA) by AFMA prior to the agreement; if so, what was the nature and content of the EIA, if not, why not; (d) are subject to sufficient penalties to deter non-compliance; if so, what are these penalties compared to the value of a typical catch by a Japanese longline vessel; (e) (i) sufficiently protect marlin, billfish and other fish stock not part of the Agreement; and (ii) on what evidence is the answer based;

(5) Given that a World Wide fund for nature study in the southern ocean found that 44,000 albatross were being killed annually by Japanese longliners, what is the Government's scientific advice about the level of reduction of incidental catch of albatross and other seabirds that will be achieved when operating south of latitude 30 degrees through the use of tori pole devices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: OPENING REMARKS

The management of Commonwealth Fisheries is currently subject to an inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs following the tabling of the ANAO report. Further, the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties has tabled its report into the Bilateral Agreement and a Government response is pending.

The Committees are considering a number of the matters raised by Senator Margetts making it inappropriate to comment on them at length. Of the ANAO's 39 recommendations, AFMA accepts twelve (and part of another), accepts in principle a further fifteen (and part of two others) and disagrees with ten.

The response provided below relates to foreign fishing in the AFZ and, specifically, to the new bilateral fishing agreement with Japan. However, it should be noted that the questions asked appear to mix domestic issues with foreign issues and have been answered only in terms of foreign fishing. This is particularly the case with the issues raised in 3(b), 3(c) and 3(d).

The Bilateral Agreement enables the operators of Japanese vessels to take tuna and associated species within the terms and conditions of access specified in an annually negotiated agreement. The predominant species is yellowfin tuna followed by big-eye tuna and broadbill swordfish. The SBT catch by Japanese vessels in the AFZ is limited to 400 tonnes and any catch against this amount is deducted from Japan's national catch allocation granted to it by the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT).

(1) The 1996 FAO report on the state of world fisheries and aquaculture provides analysis of trends in 200 of the major fish resources of the world, which account for 77 percent of the world's fisheries landed catch. The analysis suggests that 35 percent are overfished, 35 percent are fully fished and 40 percent of fisheries are still developing.
In considering these figures two important features should be borne in mind:

PARA.TAB: 1) that the FAO compiles these figures on a global basis from information provided by member nations and that the data and analysis and by their nature broad and subject to the accuracy of the data supplied. As such, the Government is not in a position to assess the veracity of them;

2) the figures provided by FAO incorporates `commercial' fishing, which by implication suggests that any fishery subject to commercial fishing would have its total biomass reduced, to the point of being `fully fished'. In this context, it is misleading to interpret the aggregated figure as an indicator of the state of degradation of fisheries. Clearly a fully fished commercial fishery may be an ideal situation to be in from both an economic and conservation perspective.

ANSWER.PARA: In this context it is not realistic to use either the overall figure or its component figures to do anything more than to draw the inference, as the FAO report does, that the worlds fisheries need effective management, a proposition that the Government accepts fully.

The FAO report goes on to comment that with improved, sustainable management of the worlds fisheries and aquaculture, substantial increases in catch are possible. The report suggests a range of approaches to achieve this, particularly noting the need to address the globalisation of fisheries, related to expanding global trade and the international mobility of investment capital. Fisheries management, to a large extent, is subject to such influences and its effectiveness is becoming increasingly dependent on addressing these issues.

In this context, Australia has played a major participatory role in developing a series of instruments aimed at managing the world's fisheries in a sustainable and responsible way. Australia played a key role in developing and establishing international conventions and agreements, including the United Nations Agreement on Highly Migratory Fish Stocks and Straddling Fish Stocks. Core elements of the new instruments are being given effect through Australia's active participation in regional management regimes, including the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna, the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission, as well as the Forum Fisheries Agency and the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources. Australia is recognised internationally as having some of the best managed fisheries in the world, and as being a producer of high quality seafood.

(2) The Government does not intend to make such a nomination. I understand representations requesting that southern bluefin tuna be listed on Appendix II to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) were received by my colleague, the Minister for the Environment. The Minister and I have had consultations on a listing under the Convention. The listing of southern bluefin tuna will not now be considered at the forthcoming conference of parties to the Convention.

In this respect, it is important to note that international co-operation in the conservation and management of SBT is well established through the CCSBT. A recovery program is in place for the stock; a global total allowable catch (TAC) and national quota allocations apply to member countries; and vigorous attempts are being made to encourage non-member countries whose fishing fleets take SBT to join the Commission.

The conservation and management of highly migratory fish stocks and straddling fish stocks requires the co-operation of both coastal States and distant water fishing nations (DWFNs). Such co-operation is embodied in the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), and the related UN Fish Stocks Agreement, which establishes a comprehensive regime for the conservation and management of transboundary fisheries resources. The provisions of UNCLOS and the UN Fish Stocks Agreement are to be given effect through regional fisheries regimes such as the CCSBT.

However, the broader issue of marine fish species subject to large scale commercial harvesting and international trade will be discussed at the forthcoming conference of the parties to CITES. The USA has proposed that, in response to concerns about the technical and practical issues associated with listing such fish on the Convention, a working group will be established to analyse these issues and make recommendations on how they should be dealt with.

(3) a) AFMA agrees that southern bluefin tuna (SBT) stocks are below desired ESD biological levels and has played an active role in having this issue addressed internationally. Australia has been involved in the international management of SBT since 1983, through an informal Trilateral Management Group, which was formalised in 1994 through the CCSBT. The CCSBT is an international Commission to which Australia, Japan and New Zealand are parties. It's primary function is to manage the global SBT stock. The CCSBT has a key biological management objective of rebuilding the parental stock to the 1980 level by the year 2020. A major focus of the Commission is to encourage non-parties, principally Indonesia, Taiwan and Korea, whose catches are increasing in significance, to join CCSBT or introduce complementary management.
(b) This ANAO comment appears to refer to domestic fisheries arrangements rather than to foreign fishing.

With regard to data collection from the Japanese fleet the level of compliance is very high. Operators are required to report position, effort and catch of target and non target species to AFMA on a daily basis via satellite based vessel monitoring systems (VMS). The data includes catch by weight and number of target species and non target species, and individual lengths and weights of each SBT taken. Catch data is verified through the use of an on-board observer programme.

The requirement to report via VMS was introduced in 1996 to replace the daily radio reporting system. As the collection of data via VMS is a recent innovation, the Japanese vessel operators are required at this stage to also complete logbooks on a daily basis, as was the case with radio reporting.
(c) Again the ANAO comment appears to refer to domestic fisheries arrangements rather than to foreign fishing.

In relation to foreign fishing, AFMA has implemented a number of measures to ensure compliance arrangements are adhered to by foreign operators. Under the terms and conditions of the Bilateral Agreement, the Japanese longline fleet are required to report position, effort and catch on a daily basis, are subject to pre and post fishing inspections, and at sea inspections. At the pre fishing inspection Japanese fishing masters are thoroughly briefed on the conditions on their licence and the codes of conduct in place under the Bilateral Agreement.

Further, AFMA has in place an on-board observer programme which, depending on the region in the AFZ, covers between 10 and 30% of all fishing trips in the AFZ by Japanese vessels. This assists in the verification of figures provided by the Japanese and also enables AFMA to gain information to continuously improve the bilateral management arrangements.

In 1991 a Japanese boat was detected misreporting catch made in the AFZ. Subsequent prosecution of the Master of this boat for breaching conditions of his foreign fishing licence lead to the forfeiture of the Japanese longline boat and its catch. At the time this amounted to a $4.5 million penalty. Subsequent to this prosecution Japanese boats have been subject to more rigorous controls including freezer hold inspections in port and at sea, a higher level of observer coverage and daily catch reporting.

AFMA is generally very confident in the reporting of retained catch by Japanese longline boats. Since 1991 the detected offences and associated prosecutions have been related to a much lower level of misreporting.
(d) This ANAO comment and response relates to domestic fisheries management arrangements, noting that the bilateral process will be covered under the response to 4(c) below.

AFMA has been working closely with the Environment Protection Agency (now the Environ ment Protection Group (EPG) within Environment Australia) since late 1994 on Commonwealth fishery decisions which have environmental significance. AFMA has designated as environmentally significant under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, the South East Trawl, East Coast Tuna and Southern Shark management plans along with the Macquarie Island and Heard/McDonald Island management policies and the 1997 total allowable catch (TAC) for eastern gemfish.

(4) (a) AFMA is of the view that the Bilateral Agreement conforms to AFMA's ecologically sustainable development objective, noting that tuna species targeted by the Japanese while fishing in the AFZ are part of wider stocks that extend well beyond the boundaries of the AFZ.

In developing Australia's position for the bilateral negotiations AFMA and DPIE seek the views of a wide range of Government and non Government bodies, and incorporates the views of scientists, industry (through Management Advisory Committees), environment agencies, conservation groups, recreational fishing groups and State Governments. Consideration is given to the impacts of fishing on both target and non target species. The negotiating position is cleared through the Prime Minister and the relevant Commonwealth Ministers.

The tuna and billfish stocks are managed through a variety of international fora, including CCSBT, the Forum Fisheries Committee and the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission. Advice on stock status is provided by either a Scientific Committee or a scientific body associated with each management regime, and Australian scientists have a major input in provision of this advice.

AFMA provides advice on the status of those parts of the stocks that exist in the AFZ through an annual fishery assessment process. These fisheries assessments, which draw together all available scientific advice, are available as public documents. AFMA's assessments form part of the Australian view on tuna fisheries in the wider Indo-Pacific region which it takes to international fisheries meetings.

It should also be noted that Australia has signed and ratified the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea which, whilst bringing benefits, also requires it to give consideration to providing access to foreign fishing operations where domestic operators are not yet able to take full advantage of a fishery. In short, Japanese vessels take the fish that domestic operators are unable to take, and their combined catches are believed to be sustainable.

(b) As indicated in the response to question 3(c), the Japanese bilateral vessels are subjected to a wide range of monitoring provisions to enable monitoring and assessment of fisheries stocks, including southern bluefin tuna. These include pre and post fishing inspections, observer coverage, and daily position, effort and catch reporting amongst others.

With regard to stock monitoring, a number of long-term research programs are in place to monitor the distribution, abundance, age structure and length-frequency on SBT in the AFZ. This comprises both Australian research and collaborative work between Australian and Japanese scientists.
(c) The Bilateral Agreement is between the Japanese and Australian Governments, therefore matters relating to Australia's part in it are determined by the Minister for Resources and Energy.

The Minister for Resources and Energy (the Minister) considers the Agreement in relation to, among other things, the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (EPIP Act), which requires proposals that are environmentally significant to be referred to Environment Australia for examination. If a decision is believed to be environmentally significant by the Minister then s/he can designate it under the EPIP Act. With regard to designation, DPIE provides advice to the Minister on the Agreement and its implications, including environmental significance and other relevant matters. The Minister is currently considering the application of the EPIP Act to the 1997 Bilateral Agreement.
(d) The response provided to question 3(c) addresses this question and in conjunction with the attached table, clearly indicate that the penalties are sufficient to deter non-compliance.
The attached table provides a summary of prosecutions of Japanese longline vessels since 1990 (Bilateral and joint venture).
(e) The Bilateral Agreement makes specific reference to billfish, including marlin, and sharks which are taken incidentally in longline operations.

Under the Agreement billfish (except broadbill swordfish) are not to be targeted deliberately by Japanese fishing vessels, and there is a voluntary code under which all blue marlin and black marlin which are alive at the time of longline retrieval are released. AFMA monitors this through the daily catch reports and the observer program. For the 1995/1996 year, there is no evidence of billfish targeting.

Historically, in recognition of concerns over the catch of billfish a range of area closures and restrictions on fishing methods have been applied to the Japanese fleet. These include the exclusion from the East Coast Tuna and Billfish Fishery area off Cairns known as Area E, and 50 nautical mile closures off the east and west coasts of Australia.

Japan has historically finned sharks and discarded the carcasses. The shark code of conduct requires the carcasses to be retained and `trunked'. This is to reduce wastage and encourage the development of a market for sharks. Through the observer program compliance with the code appears to be generally good, although AFMA remains concerned that some token trunking does still occur. Australia has requested Japan to take this matter up directly with its fleet.

(5) Given that a World Wide fund for nature study in the southern ocean found that 44,000 albatross were being killed annually by Japanese longliners, what is the Government's scientific advice about the level of reduction of incidental catch of albatross and other seabirds that will be achieved when operating south of latitude 30 degrees through the use of tori pole devices.

The 44,000 figure was an estimate based on observations made on Japanese longline vessels in waters adjacent to Tasmania in 1988 when the SBT quota levels were considerably higher than they are now. In 1988 Japan's national SBT catch allocation was 19,500 tonnes compared to 6065 tonnes since 1990. As a result the number of hooks set by Japan now are considerably less than in 1988. Japanese longline effort in the Southern Ocean is now approximately half what it was in the mid to late 1980s.

It is also important to note that, of a national SBT allocation of 6065 tonnes, Japan has only sought to fish 600 tonnes of its allocation in the AFZ under the Bilateral Agreement in recent years. Much of Japan's catch is taken on the high seas where Australian regulations do not apply. The seabird issue is being addressed more broadly through the Ecologically Related Species Working Group of CCSBT which is a forum to focus on high seas fishing operations.
Tori poles became mandatory in the AFZ south of 30 degrees for the 1995/1996 Agreement and for the 1996/1997 Agreement SBT catches in the AFZ by Japanese boats has been reduced to 400 tonnes.

Although there is no information on the specific effect of tori poles in reducing seabird bycatch, a recent report by CSIRO suggests that seabird bycatch (including albatross) within the AFZ has reduced by a half to one eighth since 1988. Tori poles would certainly have contributed to this reduction. It has been noted that many Japanese vessels use tori poles and other mitigation measures when operating outside the AFZ.

Through the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992, a Threat Abatement Plan to reduce the threat of longline fishing on seabirds is being prepared. Additionally, under that legislation a Recovery Plan for the Macquarie Island population of wandering albatross is being prepared. Both of these plans will provide for specific targets and monitoring and research to enable the efficacy of mitigation measures, including tori poles, to be quantitatively assessed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Japanese terms of operation in the AFZ were changed following the prosecutions in 1990. The present rigorous inspection process and daily reporting requirement was instituted as was a minimum of 10% observer coverage, in 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do ships carrying petroleum products as cargo pass within the boundaries of the Ningaloo Marine Park; if so (a) how many on an annual basis; and (b) under what environmental protection conditions.
(2) Who monitors these shipping movements within the marine park and who is responsible for enforcing compliance with laws and conditions that apply to such shipping within the Ningaloo Marine Park.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)& (2) The Commonwealth does not track specific vessel routes along Australia's coastline other than through the Great Barrier Reef. Therefore specific information on ship movements through the Ningaloo Marine Park is not available. While the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) is advised of ships' positions through the AUSREP system for safety, search and rescue purposes, the system is not structured to provide details of cargoes or specific ship routes.
I understand that neither the Western Australian Department of Transport nor the Department of Conservation and Land Management monitor ship movements along this part of the coast.

All vessels travelling in Australian waters are required to meet the standards of several International Maritime Organisation Conventions. These include the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL) which aims to control harmful discharges from ships, and the International Convention on Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) dealing with all aspects of shipping safety, including construction and navigation.

The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) is responsible for ensuring that vessels on international or interstate voyages that are subject to the above Conventions, comply with these international Conventions. AMSA surveyors based in Port Hedland and Karratha regularly inspect eligible vessels travelling along the north western Australian coast to ensure that safety and environmental standards are met.
Vessels on intrastate voyages are subject to the provisions of State legislation, administered by the WA Department of Transport, which applies the same international standards.

In addition, all Charterers of tankers applying to the Commonwealth Department of Transport and Regional Development for a single voyage permit or continuous voyage permit under the Commonwealth's Navigation Act 1912 are required to provide an independent inspection report and statement by the Charterers that the vessel complies with international standards for environment protection and vessel safety.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Indus tries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which countries export pig meat to Australia.
(2) Which countries have applied for access to the Australian market.
(3) What industry support arrangements are in place for the pork industries in those countries which export to Australia or have applied to export to Australia.
(4) What fiscal and other arrangements are in place in those countries to promote and assist their exports.
(5) Are there policies in place in the above countries that limit access by exporting countries to their domestic pork market; if so:
(a) what is the nature of those policies;
(b) do they comply with the post‐Uruguay General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangements; and
(c) how do they compare with the access conditions imposed by Australia on access to our domestic pork market.
(6) What fiscal and other arrangements are in place in Australia to promote and assist exports of Australia's pork.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Currently Australia imports uncanned, uncooked pig meat from Canada and the South Island of New Zealand. Canned pig meat may be imported from approved plants in any country, provided they meet certain conditions.
(2) Current formal access requests for uncooked pig meat include Denmark, the European Union, the United States of America and Mexico.

(3) The overall level of support to pig meat industries in Canada and EU as measured by the OECD Producer Subsidy Equivalents (PSE) are 16% and 9% respectively. This compares with the Australian PSE for pig meat of 5% and the OECD average of 16%.

The PSE is a measure of assistance to producers as reflected through the net return received by producers. It is measured by the level of market price support (difference between the world price and the producer price in that country), plus direct payments to producers plus other support and general services (R&D etc) less levies on output and an adjustment for feed. The calculation also allows for input subsidies. The market price support component includes the effect of any tariff protection applied.
Industry support arrangements for Denmark are delivered through the EU's Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) support arrangements for the pig meat sector.
(4) In the case of Canada, no direct export subsidies are payable on exports of pig meat.

Export subsidies are payable on exports of pig meat from Denmark in principle within limits set by the EU's Uruguay Round commitments. These commitments apply to export of live swine, fresh chilled and frozen pig meat and also processed pig meat (hams, sausages, canned meat etc). The EU has Uruguay Round commitments to reduce the level of export subsidies progressively up to the year 2000. Consequently, there are limits to the level of export subsidies that the EU may apply in terms of both budgetary outlays and the quantity of subsidised product that may be exported.

Base rate subsidy levels were ECU 183.4 mil reducing to ECU 117.4 mil by the year 2,000. Quantity reductions for the same period will be from 5,086,000 tonnes to 4,018,000 tonnes. These levels apply to exports to all markets and Australia may not necessarily be targeted for the export of subsidised product.
As far as can be ascertained, other than the above, I am not aware of any publicly funded promotion programs to assist the export of pig meat in either Denmark or Canada.
(5) Both Canada and the European Union restrict access for imports of pig meat through either tariff or tariff quotas.

(a) Canada and the EU WTO tariff commitments and the tariffs applied on pig meat are outlined in the following table. The WTO commitments detail the base rate of duty and the level this is to be progressively reduced to by year 2,000 (the bound rate). The applied rates of duty must be equal to or lower than the bound rate by the year 2,000.

ANSWER.PARA: The EU applies a series of tariff quotas for both uncooked and cooked pig meat. For uncooked pig meat the initial tariff quota was an aggregate of 13,500 tonnes increasing to 66,500 tonnes by the year 2,000. The initial aggregated tariff quota for cooked pig meat was zero increasing to 6,100 tonnes by year 2,000.
(b) The import arrangements for pig meat in Canada and the EU are consistent with commitments that these countries have entered under the WTO.

(c) Australia applies no tariffs on uncooked pig meat and the tariff binding on uncooked pig meat is zero. Australia has a tariff binding on cooked pig meat which ranges between 12.5% and 20% depending on the specific product. This tariff binding will be reduced to between 10% and 11% by the year 2,000 in line with our Uruguay Round commitments. Our current applied rate of duty for cooked pig meat is 5%, however, imports of cooked pig meat from Canada would not be subject to duty under concessional arrangements as part of the Canada Australia Trade Agreement.

(6) There are no specific Government programs in place other than the marketing and promotional program managed by the Australian Pork Corporation, which is funded by statutory industry levies; and the research and development (R&D) program managed by the Pig Research and Development Corporation, which receives a Commonwealth contribution to match industry R&D expenditure.

There are however, a range of generic programs available which would assist eligible applicants from the pork industry. Examples of such programs include the Rural Adjustment Scheme, AusIndustry programs and Export Market Development Scheme, and other programs administered by AusTrade. For example, should the members of the pork industry apply, AusTrade could assist with trade shows, contacts and promotion. Assistance would be provided on a fee paying basis, but this fee does not fully recover costs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism upon notice, on 10 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What programs and/or grants administered by the Minister's portfolio provide assistance to people living in the following federal electorates:
(a) the Northern Territory; (b) Kalgoorlie; (c) Leichhardt; (d) Herbert (e) Kennedy; and (f) Capricornia.

(2) (a) What was the level of funding provided through the programs or grants in (1) to each electorate for the 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years; and (b) What level of funding was budgeted for in each electorate for each program or grant for the 1996‐97 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1) The portfolio administers a range of programs. These programs have a national focus and are available to eligible applicants irrespective of their particular electorate.

(2) (a) Funding from programs administered by the portfolio which was provided to individuals/organisations located in the nominated electorates during 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 is shown in the attached table.

(b) While program management and delivery arrangements differ from program to program, the programs are administered on a national basis. Decisions made in determining assistance are not made on an electorate basis. Program funds are allocated in accordance with the guidelines of the particular programs and there are no specific budget allocations made in respect of any electorate. While some of the Department's program funding involves initiatives located in some or all of these electorates, no specific funding was budgeted for in any of these electorates for the 1996‐97 financial year.
Funding provided to individuals/organisations located in the listed electorates during 1994/95 and 1995/96

ROW.ENTRY: IR&D Board Tax Concession for Research & Development

BREAK.PARA: (1) This $100,000 in funding was provided to organisations/individuals in the electorates of Kennedy and Herbert.
(2) The AusIndustry Enterprise Improvement Program is a joint program of Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments.
The program is delivered by State/Territory Governments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Imported Food Inspection Program: Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service Staff

TALK.START.PARA: To ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 10 April 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) How many Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) officers were employed in the Imported Food Inspection Program (IFIP) in the 1994, 1995, 1996 and 1997 calendar years.
(2) (a) How many agents were employed by AQIS in this program in each year specified in (1) and (b) where were those agents normally employed.
(3) (a) What was the cost to the AQIS budget of IFIP in the 1994‐5 and 1995‐6 financial years; and (b) what funding was allocated for the 1996‐7 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the Imported Food Inspection Program the average staff utilisation (including a relief component) was;
1994—Field officers—36; Canberra based staff—3;
1995—Field officers—35; Canberra based staff—2;
1996—Field officers—31; Canberra based staff—2;

1997 As a result of the current restructure the Imported Food Inspection Program staff have now been incorporated into the Quarantine Import Clearance Program. There is thus no breakdown of IFIP numbers available for 1997 as staff have effectively been integrated into Quarantine.
(2) No agents have ever been employed by AQIS in the Imported Food Inspection Program.
(3) The total cost of the Imported Food Inspection Program for; 1994‐5 financial year was $3,454,000 and for 1995‐6 financial year was $3,015,000.

In the 1996‐7 financial year the Imported Food Inspection Program is reported as part of the Quarantine Import Clearance program as such there is no individual figure available for the Imported Food Inspection Program for this financial year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 24 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what date did the Prime Minister request the head of his department to undertake a review of ministerial guidelines tabled by him in April 1996.
(2) Has the review been completed; if so, when; if not, why not.
(3) Does the Prime Minister intend to table an amended code in the Parliament; if so: (a) when; and (b) will the amended code provide for blind trusts; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I did not ask the head of my department to undertake a review of the Guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility tabled by me in April 1996 (House of Representatives Hansard, 30 April 1996, page 14). In October 1996 I commissioned a report on the possible use of blind trust or similar arrangements by Commonwealth office‐holders in the context of the guide's provisions on ministerial shareholdings.

(2) The report was completed by the secretaries to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Attorney‐General's Department and the Treasury in November 1996. I released the report for public comment on 3 February 1997, and sent a copy to the Leader of the Opposition and to the Leader of the Australian Democrats on that day, seeking their comments.

(3) The Government is still awaiting comments from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. The report will be considered further in the light of any comments received. If any change to the guide were warranted, a revision would of course be tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister, on 11 February 1997 (Hansard page 441), representing the Minister for Defence a question without notice concerning the application of the superannuation surcharge to military funds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government intends to apply the superannuation surcharge to superannuation schemes applying to defence force personnel.
